Not for Redistribution Letter of Transmittal To Members and Governors of the Fund June 21, 1979 Dear Sir: I have the honor to t ransm it to you a copy of the In terna t ional Monetary Fund's Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions, 1979, which has been prepared in accordance w i th the provisions of Article XIV, Section 3 of the Articles of Agreement. The Report continues, under a modified title, the series of Annual Reports on Exchange Restrictions published by the Fund since 1950. The change in its title was decided upon by the Executive Board in the light of the provisions on exchange arrangemen ts in Article IV, Section 2( a) under the Second Amendment of the Articles of Agreement, which came in to e f fect on April 1, 1978. On behalf of the Executive Board, I should like to express our appreciation of the cooperation of member countries in the prepara t ion of the second part of the Report. Sincerely yours, /s/ J. Introduction: The world economic situation remained unsatis- fac tory in several impor tant respects d u r i ng 1978. Total produc t ion grew at below-average rates in many countries, inc lud ing most of the large industrial countries whose activities tend to set the pace for the world economy. For the indus t r ial countries as a group, the increase in real gross na t ional product (GNP) in 1978 is estimated at 33/4 per cent, the same as in the prev ious year. This ra te is appreciably below the 1962-72 average ra te of growth of about 4l/2 per cent, but is probably roughly in line with the current rate of increase in po ten t ial output. Among the non indus t r ial coun t r ies other than the ma jor oil expor ters, a somewhat s im i lar shor tfa ll of average grow th ra tes was also ev iden t. The slower growth rates we re associated w i th a sub s tan t ial unde ru t i l iza- tion of resources, i n c l u d i ng h igh levels of unemp loy- men t, and the emergence of p ro found s t ruc tu ral problems in many countries. This s i tua t ion was accen- tua ted by low ra tes of inv e s tm en t, s lugg ishness in the growth of wor ld t rade, the spread of pro tec t ion ist t rade measures, and the m a in t en an ce of res tr ic t ions on cu r r ent p aym en t s. These deve lopmen ts have been accompanied by a d i s t u r b i n g ly h igh ra te of price increase in m any coun t r ies. A l though subs tan t ial im p r o v em e nt in the average price pe r fo rmance of the i n d u s t r i al coun t r i es occurred f rom 1974 to 1976, f u r- th er progress s ince t h en on ba lance has been negligi- ble, w i th a resu rgence of i n f l a t i on occu r r ing in some of these coun t r i es in the ea r ly pa rt of 1979. Very h igh i n f l a t i on ra tes have also persisted in m any pr i- ma ry p r o d u c i ng coun t r ies. The g row th of world t r a de rema ined subdued in 1978, a f t er a sh a rp r e d u c t i on in the ra te of g row th in the p r ev ious yea r. In te rms of vo lume, wo r ld t rade grew at an e s t ima ted 5 per cen t, the same as the increase recorded in 1977, and well below the aver- age ra te of g row th of about 9 per cent in the period 1962-72. In t e rms of U.S. do l la r s, the va lue of world t r ade in 1978 rose at about the same ra te as in the p rev ious year. These global t r ends were accom- pan ied by a d ive rgence be tween the developed and d ev e lop ing c o u n t r i es w i th respect to t r a de pa t- t e rns and the te rms of trade. Wh i le export volumes rose at a faster pace in 1978 for the non-oil primary producing countries as a group, when compared with the previous year, both the developed and the developing countries in this group experienced a weakening in the terms of trade. The major oil exporters experienced a marked decline in their combined trade surplus in 1978 because of a sharp decline in the terms of trade and an appreciable fall in export volume; the terms of trade improved somewhat early in 1979 as a result of increases in oil prices. In 1978, the counterpart of the foregoing changes in terms of trade of pr imary producing coun- tr ies was a substantial improvement in those of the indus t r ial countries. There was a very sizable increase ( f rom approxi- ma te balance to US$28 billion) in the current account surplus of the industrial countries in 1978, a result wh ich included substantially enlarged surpluses by several countries, particularly the Federal Repub- lic of Ge rmany and Japan, and another large deficit by the Un i ted States. Among the non indus tr ial coun- tr ies, the combined balance of paymen ts deficit on cu r rent account for the non-oil developing countries rose again in 1978, a f t er a marked reduction from 1975 to 1977. This deficit is estimated at US$32 bil- lion for 1978, compared w i th US$21 billion in 1977 and a peak level of US$38 billion in 1975. The def ic it of th is group of countries is expected to rise f u r t h er in 1979. As a group, the non-oil developing coun t r ies obtained inflows of capital and other financ- ing assistance in 1978 that were considerably larger th an t h e ir combined cu r rent account deficit, permit- t ing sub s t an t i al add i t ions to the ir official reserves for the t h i rd consecutive yea r; the increase amounted to US$11 .5 b i l l ion in 1978. However, the d is tr ibu t ion of the combined def ic it among ind iv idual members of t h is g roup was un ev en, and a n um b er of these coun t r ie s, espec ia l ly in A f r ica, encoun tered severe problems of e x t e r n al financing. A few of the more developed p r im a ry p roduc ing coun tr ies also experi- enced d i f f i c u lt ex te rnal positions, despite the fact that the aggregate cu r rent account def ic it of th is group was ha lved in 1978 a f t er several years of severe bal- ance of paymen ts problems. The combined surp lus of the g roup of m a jor oil expor t ing countries fell f rom US$33 b i l l ion in 1977 to an estimated US$7 billion in 1978. The Second Amendment of the Fund's Articles of Agreement, wh ich entered into force on April 1, 1978, brought in to effect the provisions of a new Ar t ic le IV wh ich stresses the objective of a "continuing development of the orderly unde r ly ing conditions that are necessary for f inanc ial and economic stability" and makes it an obligation of each member "to collaborate w i th the Fund and other members to assure orderly exchange arrangements and to promote a stable system of exchange rates." The principles and procedures for surveillance over exchange ra te policies endorsed by the Fund's In ter im Committee (In ter im Committee of the Board of Governors on the International Monetary System) and approved by the Executive Board in Apr il 19774 went into effect under the Second Amend- men t. In the commun ique issued at the conclusion of its meeting in Mexico City on Apr il 29-30, 1978, the In te r im Committee noted with approval that the Fund had recently adapted its consultation procedures and practices to take account of surveillance, and that particular attention would be focused on those cases in which there were questions as to whether the exchange rate policies of members were consistent with the agreed exchange rate principles. In this respect, the Interim Committee observed that the Fund has always concerned itself with situations in which the value of a currency is not compatible with the smooth 4 The decision of the Executive Board (Decision No. 5392- ( 7 7 / 6 3) adopted Ap r il 29, 1977) and the text of the memo randum, "Surveillance over Exchange Rate Policies," were reproduced in the 28th Annual Report on Exchange Restrictions, pages 5-6 and 23-24. ©International Monetary Fund. The Interim Committee noted that the Fund now has both the obligation and the means through surveillance to make a greater contribution than before to the effec- tive working of the exchange rate system. Under Section 2 (a) of Article IV of the amended Articles of Agreement, members incurred an obliga- tion to no t ify the Fund of the exchange arrangements they intend to apply in fu l f i l lment of their obligations under Article IV, Section 1. In addition, members are obliged to no t i fy the Fund promptly of any changes in the ir exchange arrangemen ts. The notifi- cations submitted by members in fu lf i l lment of these obligations fo rm the basis of the section on the Exchange Rate System in the survey for each mem- ber coun try appearing in Part Two of th is Report. During 1978 there were several rea l ignmen ts of exchange rates of currenc ies of the countries partici- pating in the European common ma rg ins arrange- ment. In February 1978 Norway established new intervention points for the Norwegian krone, repre- senting a depreciation of 8 per cent in terms of the value of the k rone vis-a-vis the SDR (as previously defined in terms of gold) which was used as a numera ire for establishing in te rven t ion points under the common margins arrangemen t. A fu r ther realign- ment of the exchange rates at which central banks stood ready to buy or sell currencies of countries participating in the European common margins arrangement took place in October 1978. The adjustment in exchange rates led to a shift, as measured by central rates, of 4 per cent between the deutsche mark and the Danish krone and the Norwegian krone, respectively, and 2 per cent between the deutsche mark and the Netherlands guilder, the Belgian f ranc, and the Luxembourg franc, respectively. In December 1978 Norway discontinued its association with the arrangement. Following a meeting of the Heads of State and Government of the EEC countries5 ( the European Council) on December 4-5, 1978, an agreement was announced regarding the establishment of a European Monetary System (EM S )6 aimed at the creation of a zone of monetary stability in Europe. All EEC countries except the United Kingdom declared sub- 5 Belgium, Denmark, France, Federal Republic of Ger- many, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and United Kingdom. 6 An extract f rom the text of the Resolution of the Euro- pean Council on the establishment of the EMS, which was issued on December 5, 1978, is reproduced in the Annex to Part One of this Report. See pages 29-30. sequently that they would participate in the exchange ra te and intervention system of the EMS. The United Kingdom stated that it might decide to jo in at a later date. It was also agreed that a European Mon- etary Fund would be established not later than two years f rom the commencement of the EMS. The func t ion ing of the EMS was to be centered on a European Currency Un it (ECU ), to be identical in value and composition to the European Unit of Account (EUA ). The currency of each member of the EMS would have a central rate in terms of the ECU, which would be used to establish a grid of bilateral exchange rates. The margin of fluctuations around these rates with respect to the currencies of pa r t ic ipa t ing countries was established at plus or m inus 2.25 per cent. EEC countries whose cur- rencies presently were not included in the European common margins a r rangement could, on a temporary basis, establish fluctuation margins of up to plus or m inus 6 per cen t; these marg ins would be gradually reduced as economic conditions permitted. Italy decided to make use of this option. The EMS would also expand the credit facilities within the EEC. Following a meeting of the European Council on March 12-13, 1979, the member countries par- t ic ipa t ing in the EMS informed the Fund that the system entered into force with effect from March 13, 1979. A number of ma jor policy actions affecting exchange rates were announced by the United States du r ing the period under review. In January 1978 the United States reaffirmed that it would intervene to the extent necessary to counter disorderly condi- tions in the exchange markets and that for this pur- pose it would utilize the Exchange Stabilization Fund of the U.S. Treasury and the US$20 billion swap network of the U.S. Federal Reserve System. In addition, a swap agreement was put into effect between the U.S. Treasury and the Deutsche Bundes- bank. In March 1978 the United States and the Federal Republic of Germany jo in t ly announced fu r th er steps to counter disorderly market conditions, including the use of an augmented swap agreement between the central banks of the two countries, and an arrangement by the U.S. Treasury for the sale of part of its holdings of SDRs to purchase deutsche mark. Following a period of strong pressure on the U.S. dollar in the foreign exchange markets, the U.S. authorities on November 1, 1978 announced a series of measures. These included, in addition to a tighten- ing of domestic monetary policy, increases in the Federal Reserve Board's reciprocal currency (swap) 5 ©International Monetary Fund. In addition, the U.S. Treasury announced increases in the volume of mon th ly gold sales; these sales had been ins t i tu ted in May 1978.7 Dur ing the period under review, a number of other member countries adopted new exchange arrangements or modified the ir existing exchange arrangements. These changes reflected a continuation of the trend observed in recent years for members to adapt existing exchange arrangements to their own institutional circumstances and ind iv idual policy needs. Thus, there was a fu r th er reduction in the number of members m a i n t a i n i ng a fixed relationship between their currenc ies and ano ther denom ina tor. In o ther cases, increased flexibility in exchange arrangemen ts involved the use of w ider marg ins in respect of the peg of a currency to a composite of o ther currenc ies. In add i t ion, several members began to declare o f f ic ial ma rket exchange rates for up to one year in advance, based p r ima r i ly on an t ic ipa ted va r ia t ions in in f la t ion rates at home and abroad. At the end of March 1979, 61 members pegged the ir currenc ies to ano ther currency, of wh ich 40 were pegged to the U.S. dollar, 14 to the French f r an c, 3 to the pound sterling, and 4 to other currencies. Ano ther 12 cu r renc ies were pegged to the SDR, wh i le a f u r t h er 20 ma in ta ined a fixed re la t ionsh ip between the ir currencies and ano ther cu r rency com- posite. Last year's Report noted that in response to the large paymen ts imbalances occu r r ing in the wake of the oil and other price increases of 1973 and the subsequent wor ldw ide recession, most Fund members generally had been successful in l im i t ing recourse to trade and paymen ts res tr ic t ions for ba lance of 7 In Ap r il 1979 the U.S. T r e a su ry announced that the vo lume of gold sales wou ld be reduced f rom 1,500,000 ounces a mon th to 750,000 ounces a mon th. 6 payments reasons. Nevertheless, there had been a perceptible increase in pressures for protection in many countries in recent years. These pressures continued dur ing 1978 and early 1979, with no evidence of any significant change in the overall trade policies of the developed countries. Some of these countries introduced new or intensified existing restraints on imports during this period. There were also a number of other developing countries in which restrictions on current payments and transactions were continued or intensified. During this period, however, a number of developing countries libera- lized trade and payments restrictions in response to an easing of balance of payments difficulties and in some of these cases the liberalization took place in association with financial programs supported by use of the Fund's resources. The continued use of restrictive trade policies by some of the major trading nations during the period under review resulted partly from cyclical factors, particularly the persistence of high levels of unemp loyment and lower rates of economic ac t iv i ty, but also reflected longer-term problems of s t ruc tu ral ad jus tmen t. Some of these problems were compounded by increased competition from imports in key indus tr ial sectors, and the emergence of some developing countries as important competitors in a w iden ing array of products. Significant measures of protection were in evidence in such sectors as steel, shipbuilding, textiles and clothing, and a va r ie ty of other manu fac tu res, especially consumer electrical goods. In one or more of these fields, the EEC, the United States, and Canada as well as some o ther developed countries ma in ta ined or introduced new measures of import res tra int a f fec t ing trade among the developed countries —particularly trade between a number of these countries and Japan— as well as t rade w i th the developing countries. How- ever, du r ing the period under review Japan signifi- can t ly liberalized its imports. In general, the methods and ins t rumen ts of restrict- ing trade rema ined largely unchanged, and continued to involve cost and quan t i ta t ive res tra in ts on imports. There were instances of resort to restrictions which va ry au toma t ica l ly in severity w i th the un it cost of impor ts — thereby applying more severely to "low- cost" imports —or the degree of import penetration. There was also con t inued use of export restraint agreements negotiated bilaterally between trad ing p a r tn e r s. The w iden ing application by many devel- oped coun tr ies of the various forms of import res t ra int men t ioned above is a ma t ter for serious ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INTRODUCTION concern. Such measures fail to address the funda- mental problems of structural change, and over time tend to become entrenched, thereby imparting a strongly negative bias to prospects for growth in world production and trade. The rise in protec- tionism has had a deleterious effect on the efforts of those developing countries seeking to enhance economic growth through outward-looking economic policies. An early reversal of recent protectionist trends is necessary for an improved performance in the world economy and the Fund therefore attaches great importance to the effective implementation of the agreements resulting from the Tokyo Round of the Multilateral Trade Negotiations (MTN ). Several of the developing countries which intro- duced measures to liberalize their trade and payments systems during the period under review had been relying heavily on restrictive external policies to buttress weak balance of payments positions and to support medium-term to long-term development plans. As payments pressures eased in these coun- tries, the opportunity was taken to adopt more open economic policies in the external sector. Most of the developing countries which registered significant progress in liberalization were in Asia and, to a lesser extent, in Latin America. In contrast to these favorable developments, there were a number of other developing countries, many of them in Afr ica, which experienced increasing problems in financing widening current account deficits and which found it necessary to continue, and in some instances to extend, reliance on exchange and trade restrictions. In a disconcerting number of cases, these develop- ments led to a substantial accumulation of payments arrears, with damaging effects on partner countries. Restrictions arising from these arrears have a particu- larly negative effect on a coun try's s tand ing in world financial markets, thereby render ing more d i f f icu lt their task of restoring a sound balance of payments management. The w iden ing spread of arrears reflects in most cases internal in f la t iona ry developments and, as indicated above, inadequa te balance of paymen ts management. But in some cases it may also be the consequence of unexpected price movemen ts in world markets. The Tokyo Round of the MTN which opened in September 1973 under the auspices of the General Agreement on Ta r i f fs and Trade (GATT) reached its final phase in Apr il 1979 w i th the opening for s igna ture of a proces-verbal, w i thout time limit. The outcome of the Tokyo Round signals a ma jor liberali- zation of trade and includes provision for the removal of some of the existing obstacles to trade and reinforcement of the framework for the conduct of international trade. The principal results of the MTN are an average reduction of about one third in the level of all industrial duties taken together if measured on the basis of customs collections, and agreement on a number of codes of conduct and arrangements designed to clarify and strengthen existing trade rules. The new MTN codes relate to subsidies and countervailing duties, customs valua- tion, government procurement, technical barriers to trade, and import licensing procedures. With respect to agriculture, the MTN provide for a number of bilateral market access commitments, and interna- tional arrangements on bovine meat and dairy products. The code on multilateral safeguards is still under negotiation. Common elements of most of the above codes and arrangements are improved procedures for notification, consultation, surveillance, and for the settlement of disputes. An important result of the Tokyo Round is the provision of a legal basis for the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP ), for preferential trade relations among devel- oping countries, and for other forms of special d i f fe r- ential trea tment for these countries, including special treatment for the least developed countries. How- ever, some developing countries have expressed the view that progress in certain areas of the Tokyo Round has fallen below the expectations of the developing countries. These qualifications have been related to nontariff barriers such as quantitative restrictions, and such areas as customs valuation and administration of an t idump ing regulations. In some of these areas, the developing countries have put fo rwa rd alternative proposals. In June 1978 the Council of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD )8 and member governments of the OECD renewed, for a fu r th er year, the trade declaration first adopted in May 1974 which called for the avoidance by the par t ic ipa t ing countries of use of trade restrictions for balance of paymen ts purposes. In renewing the Declaration, the Council noted that the economic situation in the countries of the member governments of the OECD d iffered in some respects from that which prevailed when the Declaration was adopted, and emphasized that difficulties now present in these 8 Member coun t r ies of the OECD are Australia, Austria, Be lg ium, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Federal Re- pub l ic of Ge rmany, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Sw i tzer land, Turkey, United Kingdom, and United States. 7 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS countries continue to be a source of tension in the trade field, leading to the risk that un i la teral trade and other measures a f fec t ing the current account of the balance of payments could touch off a chain reaction of protectionism. Adaptations of policies on capital flows among the indus t r ial countries du r ing the period under review were associated, as in other recent years, w i th a t temp ts by some countries to prevent excessive instability in exchange marke ts and depar tures f rom domestic policy objectives. Such measures as were introduced were of short du ra t ion as pressures on the exchange ma rket eased. For some of the other developed countries, however, changes in policies on capital flows reflected longer-term considerations, in some instances being designed to encourage capital in f lows and in other cases to relax controls on out- flows. The developing coun tr ies in general sought to fac i l i ta te inf lows of capital and to encourage the deve lopment of in s t i tu t ional arrangemen ts fac i l i ta t ing such inf lows. In a few instances controls on inflows were tightened in support of domestic mone tary policy or management of external debt. In 1978 and early 1979 there was f u r t h er progress in regional economic cooperation. In addition to the establishment of the European Monetary System, described above, developments in Europe included progress in the negotiations by several countries on the ir application to jo in the EEC. Under some other regional arrangements, f u r t h er steps were taken to reduce barriers to trade. A description of the main developments in regional arrangemen ts between members is g iven in Section III, below. Dur ing the period under review, six countries, Cape Verde, D j ibou t i, Dominica, Maldives, Solomon Islands, and Su r iname became members of the Fund, b r ing ing the membersh ip to 138 coun tr ies. Two countries, Seychelles and Sur iname, accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund's Articles of Agreement, raising to 47 the number of members that have fo rma l ly accepted these obligations, while four new members, Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Maldives, and Sao Tome and Principe, informed the Fund that they were availing themselves of the transitional arrangements under Article XIV, Section 2. II. Main Developments in Restrictive Practices 1. Imports and Import Payments a. Quantitative Import Controls The application of new or the intensification of existing quantitative barriers to imports in the 8 developed countries was generally related to con- tinued changes in the international competitiveness of particular industries, notably in regard to steel, textiles, transpor ta t ion, equ ipmen t, and certain dura- ble consumer goods. The EEC's restraint measures on steel imports came into effect on Janua ry 1, 1978. The measures consisted ma in ly of the establishment of basic reference prices9 for steel imports, based on the lowest production costs in an exporting country in which the EEC deems "normal conditions of competition" to exist, and an arrangement for the levy ing of provisional an t idump ing duties should the actual import price be lower than the basic reference price. Moreover, dur ing the year, the EEC con- cluded bilateral agreements w i th most major steel expo r t ing coun tr ies, specifying the quan t i ty of exports to the EEC and containing commitments on the observance of the EEC rules regarding basic prices.10 The agreements w i th state-trading countries provide for specified qu an t i t a t ive limits, those with EFTA coun tr ies aim at ma in ta in ing traditional trade flows, wh i le the arrangemen ts with non-EFTA market economies include under tak ings by the respective expo r t ing countries to respect the traditional product mix of exports and their d is tr ibu t ion among regions. In addition to the measures applied through the EEC, the U.K. authorities, as f rom February 1, 1978, l im i ted imports of iron and steel products f rom Romania to those under individual licenses, and imposed a prohibition on steel imports f rom the U.S.S.R. The EEC also concluded bilateral export restraint agreements with several countries, introducing and, in some cases, extending quantitative restrictions on impor ts of textiles and clothing items under the Mu l t if iber Arrangement (MFA ). Similar agreements were concluded by the EEC with a number of countries not par t ic ipa t ing in the Multifiber Arrange- ment. Quan t i ta t ive restrictions on imports of shirts and cotton yarn from Colombia, Egypt, India, Macao, Morocco, Pakistan, Spain, Tunisia, and Turkey, which were applied unilaterally by the EEC f rom July 1977 to December 1977, were replaced 9 The compulsory base price applicable within the EEC and to transactions in those countries of the European Free Trade Association—EFTA (Austria, Finland, Iceland, Nor- way, Portugal, Sweden, and Switzerland) with which the EEC has concluded free trade agreements for products of the European Coal and Steel Community. 10 Provisional an t idump ing duties introduced in January 1978 were subsequently suspended in respect of countries with which the EEC had concluded bilateral export restraint agreements. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES in the latter month by other measures that were in turn l if ted in April 1978, w i th the exception of those that were incorporated in bilateral agreements or considered jus t i f ied under safeguard clauses con- tained in prevailing EEC trade agreements with individual countries. In June 1978 the EEC con- firmed certain restrictions on textile imports f rom state-trading countries, and in July 1978 quan t i ta t ive restrictions for 1978 were imposed by the EEC on imports of wool cloth from Argentina. In July 1978 EEC imports of specified textile products f rom Greece were made subject to quan t i ta t ive limits in Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, and the Netherlands. The United Kingdom in July 1978 also introduced quan t i ta t ive restrictions on imports of certain clothing items f rom the Philippines; in September 1978 similar restrictions were extended to Singapore. Among other European countries, Aus t r ia con- cluded agreements establishing quan t i ta t ive ceilings on imports of certain textiles f rom India, Korea, and Macao; on the other hand, quan t i ta t ive controls on textile imports f rom Egypt were replaced by a con- sultation clause in the event of d isrup t ion of the Aus tr ian market. No rway reached agreements on limits for imports of textiles f rom six impor tant exporting countries and imposed quotas on imports of the most important textile products f rom sources other than the EEC and EFTA countries. Sweden concluded export restraint agreements dur ing 1978 with a number of textile exporting countries; in February 1978 Sweden also introduced a system of mandatory licensing of steel imports, for surveillance purposes. The trigger price system for steel imports announced by the U.S. authorities in December 1977 came into effect in February 1978. Under th is sys- tem, the U.S. au thor i t ies mon i tor prevailing import prices and initiate investigations to determine whether dumping has taken place whenever import prices are below the established trigger prices.11 The trigger prices are calculated on the basis of the cost of production in Japan, which is deemed to be the most efficient producer of steel. At the end of 1978, over 80 steel items were covered under the system, compared with fewer than 20 items in February 1978. The United States in August 1978 also 11 In the last quarter of 1978, the U.S. authorities initiated the first investigations under the trigger price mechanism. On February 1, 1979, the U.S. Treasury made a tentative determination that steel imports f rom Poland were being sold at "less than fa ir value." introduced new rules for determining when import sales to the United States by nonmarket economies could be deemed to have been made at less than fa ir va lue: the principal criteria are the prices of comparable products in other countries at similar levels of development, or, when such comparison is not available, the cost of production calculated on the basis of import values in market economies, or the price of competing U.S. products. As regards textiles and clothing, the United States during 1978 renewed expiring bilateral export restraint arrange- men ts, or concluded new ones under the Multifiber Arrangemen t; this arrangement covers 80 per cent of U.S. imports of textiles and clothing. Toward the end of 1978, the United States concluded trade res tra int agreements in respect of exports of tele- vision sets by the Republic of China and Korea; in September 1978 it also signed a res tra int agreement on exports of footwear by Hong Kong. Import quotas applied by the United States on specialty steel products were renewed dur ing the year, w i th slight modifications. The quota on beef imports into the United States established under an export restraint agreement was raised in June 1978. In Canada, interim global quotas on clothing imports were extended from February 1978 until the end of the year. These were replaced by bilateral agreements concluded by Canada w i th the People's Republic of China, the Republic of China, Hong Kong, Korea, the Philippines, Poland, and Romania, thereby making exports of textile items to Canada subject to quan t i ta t ive limits with effect f rom Janu- ary 1, 1979. Japan, on the other hand, removed quota controls on some agricultural goods and anthracite coal, and increased import quotas for beef and citrus products. In March 1978 Japan also announced a special financing program for increased imports of petroleum, aircraft, and certain metal products. There was a tightening of quantitative import restrictions within the group of more developed pri- mary producing countries. Australia in mid-1978 imposed quantitative restrictions on imports of sheets and plates of steel and specified iron and steel products as well as on wool worsted yarns. Finland imposed a licensing requirement on imports of certain iron and steel products and introduced minimum import prices for some textiles. In Greece, import licensing requirements were introduced for a number of products such as fresh and frozen meat, tires, and certain types of cotton, wool, and synthetic yarns and fibers, while the import of paper was freed 9 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS from licensing requirements. New Zealand made imports of sugar subject to special authorization. On the other hand, Spain in July 1978 liberalized imports of a few equipment goods previously subject to quota. In several developing countries, steps were taken in varying degrees to liberalize import regimes. India, Korea, and Sri Lanka made notable progress in import liberalization, reflecting improvements in their external paymen ts positions and /or on-going adapta- tions in development strategies. India in April 1978 simplified its import licensing system and increased the coverage of the open general licenses; Korea removed all goods from the list of prohibited imports, transferred a large number of commodities to the automatic approval list, and abolished the system whereby the import of certain items solely for domes- tic production was linked to the f irm's export per- formance; and Sri Lanka deleted a number of basic inpu ts such as newspr int and paper, fer t i l izer, sugar, and cer ta in base metals from the list of import items subject to prior licensing. Several other developing coun tr ies eased quan t i ta t ive import restrictions. Bangladesh expanded the scope for imports under the Wage Earners' Scheme,12 and Barbados l if ted import licensing requ iremen ts for a large number of goods, wh i le in t roduc ing such requ iremen ts for a few others. Colombia liberalized the regime of minor impo r ts in J a n u a ry 1978 but added some commodities, including j u te and sisal, to the list of goods requ i r ing prior import licenses. Egypt in June 1978 increased the number of goods covered by the open general license to about 10 per cent of total imports. F i ji freed some iron and steel products f rom import licensing requ iremen ts, but lowered the import quota on passenger cars and imposed a quo ta on imports of cer ta in other types of motor vehicles. Mexico du r ing 1978 continued to e l im ina te import licensing requ i remen ts for a w ide range of commodities; for certain other items, however, quan- t i ta t ive restrictions were extended on a tempo ra ry basis. Automatic licensing for all permitted impor ts f rom countries other than Ind ia was in troduced in Nepal in March 1978; at the same time, however, impor ts of a few commodities were res tr ic ted. Other countries wh ich liberalized the impor ta t ion of some items included Chile, Pak is tan, and Paraguay. 12 Und er th is scheme, Bang ladesh n a t ion a ls and persons of Bangladesh o r ig in who are wo rk ing abroad are pe rm i t ted to open fo re ign cu r rency accoun ts denom ina ted in pounds sterling or U.S. dollars. These accounts may be debited, in ter a l ia, for paymen ts for specified imports. 10 A number of other developing countries, however, took steps to tighten quantitative import restrictions. In July 1978 Dominica imposed import licensing requirements on many clothing items. Ethiopia issued a list of commodities, mainly consumer goods, for which no official sale of foreign exchange would be made. Iraq in February 1978 restricted imports from the Federal Republic of Germany by the public sector and in July of the same year banned most imports f rom the United Kingdom. In February 1978 Kenya imposed a ban on imports of textiles which are close substitutes for those domestically produced; to protect domestic production, Liberia in April 1978 prohibited the importation of sugar. Malta imposed licensing requirements on imports of a large number of goods and prohibited imports of textiles f rom the United Kingdom. Morocco expanded the list of prohibited goods and imposed tighter import licensing requirements or quotas on several other import items. Nigeria in April 1978 added a large number of items to the list of prohibited goods and imposed tighter import licensing require- ments on several other commodities. In addition to placing a quota on imports of refined coconut oil, the Philippines restricted the importation of parts and components of television and radio equipment. Senegal made imports of most textiles and certain other goods subject to licensing, and prohibited imports of used cars. In Thailand, imports of certain motor cars and motorcycles were prohibited. Vene- zuela prohibited imports of certain passenger cars and consumer goods, but eased the import prohibi- tion for some investment goods as part of the process of imp lemen ta t ion of the Andean Pact. Zaire tightened recourse to imports without purchase of fore ign exchange if such imports gave rise to repay- ment obligations or involved luxury items. b. Import Surcharges and Import Taxation There was no clear worldwide or regional trend w i th respect to the introduction or use of import surcharges du r ing the period under review. While some coun t r ies reduced surcharges or increased exemp t ions, an approximately equal number of coun t r ies in troduced new or raised existing sur- charges. W i th effect f rom J anu a ry 1, 1978, Bolivia ex tended the system of import surcharges to imports of whea t. In a j o i nt move, Botswana, Lesotho, South A f r i c a, and Swaziland in March 1978 reduced the surcharge levied by the ir customs union from 15 per cent to 12.5 per cent. In April 1978 Iceland exempted imports of trac tors and trucks f rom the ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES 25 per cent customs surcharge. In May Peru imposed a temporary surcharge of 10 per cent, valid until December 31, 1978, on all imports except food, fertilizers, pharmaceutical products, and imports under regional trade agreements. Portugal in Octo- ber 1978 reduced from 30 per cent to 20 per cent the surcharge applying to about 30 per cent of 1977 imports. In March 1978 Tunisia imposed a special tax, ranging from 5 per cent to 300 per cent, on imports of a wide range of consumer goods. Turkey in January 1978 raised the stamp duty on all imports from 9-9.25 per cent to 22.5-25 per cent. In Uruguay, the highest import surcharge rates were reduced from 150 per cent to 110 per cent and from 110 per cent to 90 per cent, with effect from January 1, 1979. There were a number of countries which made important tariff reductions dur ing the period under review. Among the developed countries, reductions or exemptions in import ta r i f fs were made by France in respect of agricultural products imported from the EEC. Japan in March 1978 unilaterally lowered ta r i f fs on 318 tariff items, representing about 4 per cent of 1976 imports, by a weighted average of 23 per cent, in advance of the conclusion of the Tokyo Round. These reductions included the elimination of duties on automobiles. In Norway, ta r i f fs were lowered on imports of agricultural products from the EEC and the EFTA. Among the more developed p r ima ry producing countries, New Zealand in July 1978 introduced a new customs tariff fea tur ing a reduction of the overall level of tariff protection. Spain reduced import ta r i f fs on nonagricultural goods subject to duties greater than 10 per cent and established quotas free of import duties for coal and a number of steel products and other goods. Within the group of developing countries, Argentina reduced import duties on a large number of manu fac tu res. With the introduction of a new tar iff in February 1978, Benin suspended customs duties while con- t inu ing to apply fiscal import duties. Chile continued to make tariff reductions as part of a program to reduce all import ta r i f fs to a un i fo rm level of 10 per cent by mid-19 79. Import duties on certain in termed ia te and capital goods were reduced in India, and Indonesia allowed import du ty reductions and exemptions for raw materials and certain other goods. In Mexico, the elimination of licensing requirements in Janua ry and June 1978 for a large number of imports was accompanied by increases in import duties on many of these items; in September, however, duties were lowered on a number of agricultural, forestry, and fishing products. Uruguay lowered the basic rate of customs du ty and exempted many agricultural products from import levies. Import duties were increased in a number of member countries. Canada revoked the temporary tariff cuts for specified food items and certain other consumer goods, and withdrew the preferential tariff rates for some imports from Ireland and the United Kingdom, while extending other temporary tariff cuts. The United States increased tariffs on some metals and metal products. Australia introduced temporary additional duties on imports (other than from New Zealand) of wool worsted yarns exceeding certain quota levels, polyester, and certain finished goods already subject to tariff quotas or import licensing; it also introduced new or higher import duties on certain electrical equipment and steel products, while announcing a phased reduction or the elimina- tion of duties on machine tools. Iceland raised the licensing fee for imports except petroleum from 0.1-0.5 per cent to 1 per cent with effect from January 1, 1978, and in May 1978 introduced a temporary equalization tax of 3 per cent on imports of certain manufactures. Among the developing countries, Bolivia raised import taxes on selected items, mainly motor vehicles. Iran raised import taxes on a large number of goods primarily for revenue purposes, and Malawi introduced a 5 per cent tariff on imports of capital goods. In Morocco, the special import tax was raised f rom 8 per cent to 12 per cent; in addition, customs duties were increased on imports of textiles, shoes, and fu rn i tu re. Peru in May 1978 reduced import duty exemptions for imports of capital and intermediate goods. Saudi Arabia increased duties on imports of certain manu- factures for which there were domestically produced substitutes. In Thailand, a special import fee was imposed on imports of certain intermediate goods, and import t a r i f fs were raised on specified luxury goods. Developments relating to the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) dur ing the period under review included the addition by the United States of 133 items to the list of goods eligible for duty-free trea tment under the system; this move was, however, partly offset by the removal of 95 other items from the list. Dur ing the year, Australia and New Zealand included the People's Republic of China among the countries eligible for GSP benefits, and Norway extended GSP privileges to Bulgaria. 11 ©International Monetary Fund. Advance Import Deposits During the period under rev iew, four countries abolished their advance import deposit schemes and several others lowered the applicable rates and increased exemptions under the ir import deposit schemes. On the other hand, six member countries introduced advance import deposit requirements, mainly as a result of de te r io ra t ing ex ternal paymen ts positions. Bu rund i, Indonesia, Mau r i t ius, and New Zealand abolished the ir advance impo rt deposit requ iremen ts du r ing 1978. In Janua ry 1979 Bolivia exempted certain imports under the Andean Pact f rom advance import deposit requirements. Du r ing 1978 Brazil exempted a few specified items, inc lud ing soybeans, f rom the impo rt deposit scheme. As part of the liberalization measures in troduced in J anu a ry 1979, Brazil reduced the 100 per cent advance import deposit requ i rement by 10 percentage points and announced its in ten t ion to abolish the scheme, th rough reduc t ions in sem iannual steps of 10 per cent, by mid-1983. Chile raised the va lue of impor ts of a noncommercial charac ter th at are free of advance deposits and exempted ce r ta in used motor vehicles f rom the 10,000 per cent deposit require- men t. Colombia freed cer ta in types of capital goods f rom import deposit requ iremen ts. A reduction of advance impo rt deposit rates combined with the elimination of the deposit requ i rement for imports paid for by means of sight letters of credit or docu- ments against acceptance was also effected in Korea du r ing 1978. On the o ther hand, import deposit schemes were introduced or t igh tened in a number of developing countries. A fghan i s tan in October 1978 introduced a 20-30 per cent advance import deposit requirement for all private sector imports. In December 1978 Kenya imposed a temporary advance deposit require- ment of 25-100 per cent for six mon ths on almost all imports. With the exception of essential food- s tu f fs and certain capital goods, imports became subject to a 25 per cent advance import deposit requirement in Morocco in June 1978, and Nigeria in April 1978 introduced advance deposits of 100 per cent for imports of certain consumer goods by the private sector. In February 1979 Nicaragua imposed an advance import deposit requirement of 100 per cent on 50 per cent of all imports for varying periods of between 30 and 60 days, depend- ing on the type of commodity. 12 d. Payments Arrears The period under review witnessed a rise in the incidence of paymen ts arrears in member countries. These arrears mostly involve restrictions on payments and t ran s fe rs for current international transactions relating to commercial payments or to invisibles, such as remittances of income or debt service pay- men ts. Among the countries that had arrears in one or more of these categories of payments, Guyana, in connection w i th a program supported by the use of Fund resources, registered a reduction in outstand- ing arrears over the period. In Portugal, arrears on certain cu r rent invisibles which had emerged in 1977 declined d u r i ng the period under review. In the o ther countries for which data are available, there was, w i thout exception, an increase in ou ts tand ing paymen ts arrears over the period. In a number of these coun t r ies (Ghana, Jamaica, Nicaragua, Sudan, and Zamb ia) targets have been established for the phased reduction of arrears in connection with pro- grams supported by use of the Fund's resources. A r rea rs on commercial payments and /or other specified paymen ts for invisibles also emerged or increased in the Dominican Republic, Guinea, Gu inea -B issau, Madagascar, Sierra Leone, Sudan, Tanzan ia, Tu rkey, Uganda, and Zaire. In some of these coun tr ies, steps were taken du r ing the period aimed at reduc ing or e l im ina t ing ou ts tand ing arrears. e. Other Measures Affecting Import Payments Off ic ial regulations on import paymen ts were relaxed in a number of countries. Among industrial coun tr ies, Italy in August 1978 liberalized the regu- lations regarding prepayment of imports. Among other countries, Chile relaxed the regulations on for- eign credits for import financing. Finland in May 1978 and in November 1978 curtailed the coverage of the "cash paymen ts scheme" under which payment for specified imports must be made before the goods are released by the customs authorities. Greece in July 1978 abolished prepayments for imports, and importers were required to present entry documents before obtaining foreign exchange for imports. Paki- stan in the course of 1978 reduced the minimum deposit margin requirement against the opening of letters of credit for some goods, abolished it for other items, and liberalized some other regulations affecting import payments. In October 1978 the minimum foreign financing terms for imports were relaxed in Peru. Minimum deposit margin requirements appli- cable to import letters of credit were reduced to a un i fo rm rate of 20 per cent in the Yemen Arab ©International Monetary Fund. Other countries which took steps to liberalize regulations on import payments, mainly for capital goods, were Argen t ina, Colombia, and Indonesia. Regulations on import payments were tightened in several countries. Colombia suspended the use of Coffee Savings Bonds for payment abroad, while Korea tightened the regulations regarding the repay- ment period for short-term import credits. In No- vember 1978 Nicaragua lowered the allocation of foreign exchange for urgently needed imports. From October 1978 Nigeria required official registration of all import payments above N 100,000. Paraguay tightened the documentation requirements for import payments and specified m in imum terms for accept- ance credit f inanc ing for imports. Regulations which entered into force in Romania limited the conclusion of import contracts denominated in deutsche mark, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, and Swiss francs. While widening the foreign exchange allocation scheme for the financing of import requirements of exporters, Turkey repealed similar privileges applying to holders of convertible Turkish lira accounts and tightened regulations on the retained foreign exchange holdings of banks. Za ire tightened regula- tions regarding the use of retained foreign exchange holdings of banks for import payments. f. State Trading In February 1978 Algeria gave the public sector a monopoly over foreign trade, and the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya in October 1978 announced that imports could be effected only by the public sector, coopera- tive societies, or by "popularly managed firms." Fol- lowing the effective expiration of the trade agreement between India and Pakistan, trade between the two countries was again conducted on a government to government basis. While the list of imports subject to obligatory canalization through the state trading agency was reduced in India in April 1978, imports of ju te were added to the list in June 1978. 2. Exports and Export Proceeds During the period under review, there were numer- ous adaptations or extensions of various forms of export incentives or other direct support schemes by member countries. Colombia increased the rates for tax credit certificates (CATs) relating to exports of nontraditional products, with a view to strengthening export incentives in labor-intensive industries and small or medium-sized firms. Costa Rica ratified the Central American Agreement on Fiscal Incentives for Industrial Development, formally introduced in the previous year. Ecuador extended the eligibility of tax credit certificates to exporters of Manila hemp. India raised the "duty drawback rates" for ungalvanized steel items and extended for an additional period of three years the cash assistance scheme for exporters; subsidies were also extended to Indian exporters of rubber products. New Zealand extended its tax incentive scheme for exports until March 31,1980. In Turkey, additional manufactures and certain proc- essed agricultural products were added to the list of exportable goods eligible for rebates of certain taxes, while the ceiling on the rebate for these products, a f ter being reduced early in the year, was subse- quently raised. On the other hand, there was a curtailment of export subsidy schemes in some developing countries, mostly in connection with on-going liberalization of the exchange system. Thus, as part of trade liberali- zation measures announced in January 1979, Brazil reduced by 10 per cent the tax credits given to export- ers of manu fac tu red goods in respect of federal and state taxes on value added; Brazil also declared its intention to phase out the tax credits, through quar- terly reductions of 5 per cent, by mid-1983. Costa Rica removed fish and various other sea products from the list of export items eligible for tax credit certificates. In Ghana, following a depreciation of the cedi, the rate for the export bonus scheme was lowered to a un iform 10 per cent for eligible prod- ucts. Export subsidies in India were eliminated or reduced for a wide range of items, notably cotton textiles, chemicals, and certain processed foods. In Uruguay, export rebates for leather goods were reduced by 50 per cent in January 1978, and for all goods by 15 per cent in June 1978. Several countries modified their systems of export financing facilities. The Arrangement on Guidelines for Officially Supported Export Credits was accepted by the members of the OECD Group on Export Credits and Credit Guarantees13 and came into effect on April 1, 1978. This arrangement replaced the Consensus of Converging Export Credit Policies of July 1976, which had been adopted in February 1977 by 20 OECD member governments with the objective 13 Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Federal Republic of Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, Netherlands, New Zealand, Nor- way, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, and United States. 13 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS of preventing the distortion of trade which may result from excessive competition in officially supported export credits. The new arrangement provides, inter alia, for (1) a m in imum cash payment of 15 per cent of the export contract value; (2) a max imum repay- ment term, with specified exceptions, of Sl/2 years for "relatively rich" and "intermediate" countries, and 10 years for "relatively poor" countries; and ( 3) interest rate norms under which m in imum inter- est rates range from 7.75-8 per cent for relatively rich countries, 7.25-7.75 per cent for intermediate countries, and 7.25-7.5 for relatively poor countries. Among ind iv idual European countries, Aus tr ia expanded the scope of its export f inanc ing fac i l i ty, and Denmark announced the creation of an export pro- motion fund. In Italy, the partial foreign f inanc ing requirement for exports on deferred payment terms, which had been in effect since 1976, was term ina ted. Spain du r ing the year increased the amount of credit available for export f inanc ing by almost 30 per cent. In Turkey, the p re fe ren t ial foreign exchange entitle- ments of exporters of manu fac tu res and m i n i ng prod- ucts were widened considerably and m anu f a c tu r e rs who had export orders on hand, or were willing to guarantee exports of a specific value, were allowed to arrange for credits abroad in order to f inance their input needs. Several developing countries took steps dur ing the year to improve the ir export financing facilities. Korea raised the l im i ts on amoun ts loanable by the banks for export-related bills, and the previously existing ceilings for export financing were eliminated. Mexico introduced a special rediscount facility at preferential rates for export documents of up to 90 days. In Pak is tan, access to the Export Finance Scheme was enlarged and concessional in terest rates on export credits under this scheme were reduced. Argentina, Chile, and Colombia broadened the ir export financing schemes du r ing the year. On the o ther hand, ex is t ing export financing schemes were tightened in a number of cases. With effect f rom Apr il 1978, expor ters in the Un i ted King- dom ceased to have access to concessionary finance for goods sold to other EEC members on credit terms of two years or more. In Korea, the Government raised the interest rate applicable to domestic loans in support of exports. A number of countries adapted the ir a r rangemen ts relating to guaran tees or risk insurance for export credits. Among the indus tr ial countries, Switzerland introduced a new scheme involving the sales of options for foreign exchange by the Swiss National Bank 14 to guarantee the Swiss franc value of fu ture export proceeds for up to two years; the scheme replaced the gentlemen's agreement between the National Bank and various export industries. In other cases, a new export credit insurance system was established by Brazil, and a system of official bank guarantees was introduced for banks providing export credit in the form of suppliers' credits and buyers' credits; the latter was intended to facilitate payments by the for- eign buyer by means of credit from a Brazilian bank. In Pakistan, exporters of textiles to Sudan and Uganda were allowed to grant deferred payment terms for up to two years if the transaction was guar- anteed by a bank of international reputation or by the central bank or government of the importing country; a forward cover arrangement at the author- ized dealers' prevailing buying and selling rates vis-a- vis the public was also introduced for exports under bar ter agreements. For all other exports, the four- mon th negotiation limit continued to apply. Com- mercial banks in Sri Lanka were authorized to pro- vide, without prior permission from the Central Bank, guaran tees involving current payments abroad to non- residents for payments in foreign currency, and to extend guarantees to a resident of Sri Lanka on behalf of a nonresident. In Uruguay, a new advance export surrender scheme designed to reduce exchange r isk was established, whereby exporters were allowed to sell fo rwa rd to the Central Bank at the current exchange rate up to 6 months in advance of receipts of exchange for traditional exports, and up to 14 mon ths in advance for nontraditional exports. Regulations governing the surrender of export pro- ceeds were modified in several countries. In Argen- t ina, the time limit for the surrender of the proceeds of promoted exports was abolished, and the author- ized fo rms of payment were expanded to include d r a f t s. In Peru, exporters were given the right to purchase the equivalent of surrendered export pro- ceeds in foreign exchange certificates to meet their fore ign obligations or to repay loans denominated in fore ign currency granted by local banks; there were also various changes in surrender requirements applied to commercial banks. In Portugal, penalties were imposed for the deferral of liquidation of export earnings beyond 120 days af ter shipment, when such de fe r ral was for noncommercial reasons. In Zaire, the regime of foreign currency accounts by which export- ers were permitted to re ta in a specified proportion of export earn ings was abolished, and the authorized banks were required to surrender the corresponding amoun ts of foreign exchange to the Bank of Zaire. A number of countries took steps to ease quantita- tive restrictions on exports. As domestic supply con- ditions for foodstuffs improved, Colombia lifted the suspension of exports of certain types of poultry and set quotas for exports of rice. Ecuador resumed exports of unprocessed cacao, subject to a limit amounting to 25 per cent of total domestic produc- tion. In India, export firms were granted additional licenses, over and above normal import replenish- ment licenses, in respect of products manufactured by small-scale and cottage industries for which they act as agents; export quotas were also raised for cer- tain agricultural products while the ban on exports to the People's Republic of China was lifted. Nepal greatly simplified its licensing procedures for exports to countries other than India. Sri Lanka abolished prior licensing requirements for a wide range of commodities, and Zaire simplified its export regime by authorizing bank branches to validate export licenses. Quantitative restrictions on exports were intensified in a number of countries, often with a view to the easing of domestic shortages, particularly of food items. Prohibitions, quantitative limitations, or sur- veillance licensing were imposed on specified exports, largely foodstuff and other agricultural products, in many developing countries including Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, the Dominican Republic, India, Indo- nesia, Malaysia, Nigeria, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and Thailand. While previously no export licensing sys- tem existed, Nicaragua introduced a law making most exports subject to prior authorization by the Central Bank. Among other countries, Australia announced that exporters of coal, iron ore, bauxite, and alumina would be required to obtain specific government approval before making export offers or commitments. Other quantitative export restrictions were associated with voluntary export restraint agreements of the type referred to in the section on Imports and Import Pay- ments, above. Thus, Hong Kong during the year signed an agreement limiting the amount of footwear that could be shipped to the United States. Japan announced restrictive guidelines for a wide range of industrial exports, including steel, color television sets, ships, motorcycles, copying machines, and automobiles. 3. Current Invisibles Among the major industrial countries, there were few changes in regulations relating to current pay- ments for invisibles dur ing the period under review; but there were important developments in several developing countries. A number of countries eased restrictions on the provision of foreign exchange for travel, the transfer of income abroad, and in some cases for personal remittances, although these adjustments were often designed merely to maintain the real value of exchange allocations. There were, on the other hand, some countries in which serious payments difficulties resulted in the imposition of new restrictions, or the intensification of existing restrictions, on payments for invisibles. Chad increased the exchange allocation for tourist and business travel to countries outside the former French Franc Area, and Colombia raised the maxi- mum entitlements for foreign travel while exempting foreign travel payments f rom the 60 per cent advance deposit scheme. In Costa Rica, the amount of for- eign exchange that may be purchased per person for any purpose was raised; such purchases, which pre- viously could be made every six months, could now be made every three months. Foreign exchange allo- cations for tourist and business travel were reintro- duced in Ghana. Iceland increased exchange alloca- tions for foreign travel, and requirements regarding the permissible frequency of exchange sales for travel abroad were liberalized in India. Among the several revisions to its foreign exchange regulations, Korea simplified procedures and increased the basic exchange allocations in respect of foreign travel. Paki- stan increased the daily exchange allocations for busi- ness travel abroad, and introduced for the first time a special, lower exchange allowance for business travel to India; the exchange allowance for private trips to India and Bangladesh was also raised. In addition to raising the business allowances for travel to all coun- tries, Sri Lanka increased the basic travel allowance for neighboring countries. Zambia raised the basic exchange allowance for business travel and the exchange allowances for medical travel and educa- tion support. Limits on sales of foreign exchange for travel abroad were also raised dur ing the year in Cyprus, Portugal, and Spain. On the other hand, a number of countries intensi- fied restrictions on the purchase of foreign exchange for travel abroad. Afghanistan sharply reduced the exchange allocations for travel, although larger amounts could be made available upon application to commercial banks by persons satisfactorily demon- strating to the Government a legitimate travel pur- pose. In Kenya, all sales of tickets to residents for nongovernment travel outside the country became 15 ©International Monetary Fund. Turkey reduced the ava i lab i l i ty of the US$500 a person fo re ign exchange a l lowance for travel to once every two yea rs; exchange allowances for business travel were reduced by 50 per cent except for expor ters of goods and services; fu r th e rmo r e, w i th e f fect f rom J anu a ry 1, 1979, the fore ign exchange allowance for travel abroad was again reduced to US$500 a person for three calendar years. Among the indus t r ial coun tr ies, Japan, as part of a series of measures announced by Japan and the Un i ted States ( the Ushiba-Strauss Jo int S t a t em en t ), raised the ceilings on ou tward remittances. In Janua ry 1978 fo re ign exchange regulations were liberalized in Italy, as fo l lows: ( 1) banks were au thor- ized to effect paymen ts for services abroad up to 60 days before and up to 360 days after the actual date on which the services were rendered; and (2) payments f rom abroad for services rendered in Italy could be made up to 360 days in advance of, or up to 120 days af ter, the date rendered. In the United Kingdom, increases were made in the limits up to which banks may authorize payments abroad without reference to the Bank of England: these payments may be made for a variety of purposes, ranging from advertising expenses to income tax. Early in 1978 the U.S. Treasury announced that it 16 would allow U.S. res iden ts to remit up to US$500 a qua r ter to close relatives in Cuba and US$300 a qua r ter to close relatives in Viet Nam (rem i t tances to these coun t r ies had previously been b a n n e d ); au tho r iza t ion was also granted for rem i t tances of up to US$500 to Cuba and US$750 to V iet Nam to help re la t ives to emigrate f rom those countries. Multiple Currency Practices Dur ing the period under review, steps to abolish or simplify multiple currency practices occurred in a number of countries, notably Egypt, Ghana, Jamaica, the Lao People's Democratic Republic, Nepal, Peru, Uruguay, and Viet Nam. In many of these cases, the measures were taken in the context of financial pro- grams supported by the use of Fund resources. In Egypt, additional imports and transactions in invisi- bles were transferred f rom the official to the parallel exchange market in July 1978; on Janua ry 1, 1979 Egypt un if ied the official and parallel exchange rates by sh i f t ing the rema in ing transactions to the more depreciated rate in the parallel ma rke t .14 In May 1978 Jamaica and the Lao People's Democratic Republic ceased to apply dual exchange rate systems. In October 1978 the dual exchange market in Uru- guay was de facto unified when the central bank announced its intention to buy and sell any amount of foreign exchange at the prevailing commercial exchange rate. Peru in Ju ly 1978 expanded the certificate market by authorizing resi- den ts to use foreign currency travelers checks and fore ign notes and coin to purchase the certificates; previously, foreign currency certificates of deposit could be acquired only against draf ts, checks, or bank t r an s f e r s; this measure, together with f requent adjust- ments of the official exchange rate beginning in May 1978 reduced the prem ium in the market for certifi- cates of deposit f rom a high level of nearly 50 per cent in early 1978 to about 5 per cent at the end of the year. In Turkey, the separate rate for workers' rem i t tances ceased to be in effect on March 1, 1978; however, new multiple currency practices arose from the in troduc t ion of a 50 per cent tax on purchases of fore ign exchange for travel and f rom the provision which enables exporters to choose to sell export pro- ceeds at a ra te other than that prevailing on the date of su r rende r. Viet Nam in May 1978 w i thdrew both the South Vietnamese dong and the Nor th Vietna- mese dong and introduced a new currency, the dong. Iceland in September 1978 imposed a temporary 10 per cent tax on tourist expend i ture abroad based on fore ign exchange purchases for travel. Iran, on November 14, 1978, term ina ted the Central Bank's support of the noncommercial market by discontinu- ing sales of U.S. dollars to match supply with demand for foreign exchange in that marke t; certain pay- ments for invisibles were also shifted f rom the non- commercial to the official rate market. Nicaragua introduced a dual exchange market in September 1978, consisting of an official market, and a market in which the exchange rate fluctuates freely. The law establishing the dual market specified those foreign exchange transactions which had to be effected at the official exchange rate; purchases and sales of foreign exchange outside these stipulated categories were to be made at the free market rate. T he B e l g i a n - L u x em b o u rg E c o n om ic U n i on (BLEU) decided during the year to maintain all pay- ments and receipts relating to trade in diamonds in the financial marke t; such transactions had been shifted on December 1, 1977 on a temporary basis f rom the official to the financial marke t. In Ecuador the dual exchange market which had existed since 1971 was maintained during the review period but with a widened spread between the exchange rates in the two markets; this was also the case in the Domini- can Republic. There was no significant change in the 17 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS dual market system in Paraguay. In the first half of 1978 Bangladesh eliminated the m in imum exchange rate guaran tee introduced in late 1977 for the U.S. dollar, a measure which had given rise to broken cross rates. Bangladesh's exchange system, however, still con ta ins two other multiple currency practices: (1) the Wage Earners' Scheme, under which balances held in domestic commercial banks by Bangladesh emigrant workers are sold through daily auctions at fluctuating exchange rates; and (2) the Export Performance License Scheme under which additional import licenses are granted on the basis of export performance, w i th the option of t ran s fe r r ing such licenses to th i rd parties at a pre- mium. Indonesia on December 13, 1978 eliminated the mu l t ip le currency practice involved in the require- ment of an advance deposit for specified imports, a financial guaran tee amoun t ing to 100 per cent of the value of these imports, and the advance payment of du t ies on such impor ts; the measures had been in force since Janua ry 1, 1977. Moreover, the o f f ic ial buy ing ra te of Af 44.70 per US$1 for convertible cu r rency salaries of fo re ign employees was e l im ina ted. In the United Kingdom, some regulations concerning the investment currency market were modified with effect from January 1, 1978 in line with the United Kingdom's undertakings under the terms of its acces- sion to the EEC: the requirement to convert 25 per cent of the net proceeds of sale of a holding of invest- ment currency or foreign currency securities through official foreign exchange markets was abolished. In 1978 the effective premium in the investment cur- rency market in the United Kingdom was on average slightly higher than in 1977, viz., about 42 per cent. In South Africa the discount in the market for freely negotiable securities fluctuated markedly during 1978 and stood at 43.5 per cent at the end of the year, compared with 37.7 per cent at the end of 1977. 5. Bilateral Payments Arrangements There was a fu r ther reduction in the number of bilateral payments arrangements, both among Fund members and between members and nonmembers. Among members of the Fund, 11 arrangements were e l im ina ted, compared with 5 during the previous year. Egypt terminated its arrangements with Ghana, Greece, and Somalia; Ghana, in addition, terminated its arrangement with Yugoslavia; Guinea terminated its arrangements w i th three members, Morocco, Sene- gal, and Sierra Leone; Romania discontinued its arrangemen ts with Mali as did India with Afghanistan; the arrangements between Singapore and Romania, and Mexico and Iran were reclassified. Two new arrangements arose f rom Cape Verde's accession to Fund membership in November 1978, and Bangla- desh negotiated a new arrangement with Viet Nam. N ine paymen ts arrangements between members and nonmembers were terminated in 1978. Algeria dis- continued its arrangements with Bulgaria and North Korea, Chile with the People's Republic of China, Cyprus with Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia, Egypt w i th Czechoslovakia, and India with Bulgaria and No r th Korea. The arrangement between Ethiopia and the German Democratic Republic was reclassi- fied, and Sao Tome and Principe negotiated a new arrangement w i th the German Democratic Republic. At the end of 1978, 36 Fund member countries were m a in t a in ing bilateral payments arrangements with o ther members. The number of bilateral arrange- men ts among members declined from 95 in 1964 to about 44 at the end of 1978. The number of bilateral ©International Monetary Fund. Over the period 1964-78, the overall number of bilateral payments arrange- ments with both members and nonmembers declined by 46 per cent ( f rom 322 in 1964 to 174 in 1978). During the same period Fund membership grew from 101 to 138. 6. Capital Flows Measures aimed at controlling international capital movements during the review period represented in general an adaptation of existing policy trends. This was particularly true of the industrial countries, where capital control measures essentially reflected attempts to avert unwan ted departures from domestic l iqu id i ty growth targets or levels of international competitiveness. Among the developing countries, measures to influence capital movements were gen- erally aimed at the encouragement of capital inflows, though there were instances in which capital inflow regulations were tightened as a means of strengthen- ing the management of domestic liquidity or exter- nal debt. As the main conduit of fund s, the bank ing system continued to be the primary focus of the new measures, though several other measures were also introduced with respect to capital flows through nonbanks. In August 1978 the U.S. Federal Reserve System announced changes in reserve requirements, aimed at encouraging member banks to subs t i tu te Eurodollar borrowing for domestic borrowing; at the same time, the existing 4 per cent reserve requ irement on exter- nal borrowing by member banks f rom the ir foreign branches or f rom foreign banks and the 1 per cent reserve requ irement on foreign branch loans to U.S. residents were abolished. The policy measures an- nounced by the Treasury and the Federal Reserve System on November 1, 1978 to f u r t h er strengthen the dollar and to counter domestic in f la t iona ry pres- sures included a supplementary reserve requ irement of 2 per cent of time deposits in denom ina t ions of US$100,000 or more. In other developments, the U.S. In terna t ional Bank ing Act was signed into law on September 17, 1978. The new law, which repre- sents the first overall regulatory scheme on the par- ticipation of foreign banks in the U.S. domestic mar- ket, seeks to implement the principle of parity of trea tment of foreign and domestic bank s; it provides, in ter alia, that branches and agencies of foreign banks may have federal charters (previously, they were limited to state ch a r t e r s ); that the Federal Reserve Board is legally authorized tb set reserve ratios for both federal and state branches and agencies of for- eign banks having more than US$1 billion in world- wide consolidated assets; that foreign banks may be a majority owner in corporations organized to engage in international financial transactions (Edge Act Cor- porations) ; and that, with the exception of operations prior to July 27, 1978, a foreign bank may accept deposits f rom domestic sources in only one U.S. state. During the period under review, measures to control capital movements were taken in the Federal Republic of Germany, Italy, Japan, and Switzerland, essentially to counter upward pressures on their respective currencies. With effect f rom Janua ry 1, 1978, the Federal Republic of Germany increased the mini- mum reserve requirement on banks' foreign liabilities from 12.75 per cent to 20 per cent for sight deposits, f rom 8.95 per cent to 15 per cent for time deposits, and from 5.65 per cent to 10 per cent for savings deposits. Simultaneously, increases in the banks' for- eign liabilities over their average levels for the quarter ended December 1977 were made subject to a new reserve requirement of 80 per cent. However, the marginal reserve requirement was abolished with effect f rom June 1, 1978, at which time the reserve requ iremen ts on foreign liabilities were lowered to the levels applicable to the corresponding domestic liabilities, and the unified requirements were reduced by 7 per cent. Effective November 1, 1978, in order to offset renewed capital inflows, the minimum reserve rates on banks' domestic and foreign liabilities were raised by 9 per cent. In a liberalization of exist- ing controls, Italy on Janua ry 1, 1978 introduced changes in its foreign exchange regulations which, inter alia, permitted foreign exchange receipts to be converted under specified circumstances during a period of up to 120 days af ter collection, instead of 30 days, as was required previously. In Japan, measures announced in the context of the Ushiba-Strauss Joint Statement of Janua ry 13, 1978, and introduced on April 1, 1978, included a liberalization of regulations concerning foreign cur- rency deposits by residents, a relaxation of restrictions on forward foreign exchange transactions, and a lib- eralization of bank guarantees. At the same time, an increase in the marginal reserve requ irement for non- res ident free-yen deposits over the daily average level of February 1978, f rom 50 per cent to 100 per cent, came into effect on March 18, 1978. However, in J a n u a ry 1979, the Bank of Japan restored the 50 per cent reserve requirement and eliminated it altogether in February 1979. In Spain, a new decree issued in June 1978 allowed fore ign banks to open branches, and required them to subscribe capital of Ptas 750 million for a branch and Ptas 1,500 million for a subsidiary. Each foreign bank was restricted to three branches, and only 40 per cent of the lending operations in Spain could be financed with pesetas obtained in the local market.
