Not for Redistribution IRAQ (Position on December 31, 1978) Exchange Rate System The currency of Iraq is the Iraqi Dinar, which is pegged to the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, at ID 1 = US$3.3778. The official buy ing and selling rates on December 29, 1978 were US$3.394678 and US$3.377778, respectively, per ID 1. Buy ing and selling rates for certain other currencies1 are also officially quoted, with daily quotations based on the buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in marke ts abroad. The Central Bank of Iraq under takes transactions in the listed currencies only with authorized dealers. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of fore ign exchange. Administration of Control Exchange control authority is vested in the Board of Administration of the Central Bank; this au tho r i ty is executed through the Foreign Exchange Committee, which has delegated certain approval au tho r i ty to the Department of Foreign Exchange of the Central Bank and to licensed dealers. Foreign exchange transactions must take place through a licensed dealer unless other- wise authorized by the Board of Adm in is tra t ion. All branches of the Raf ida in Bank, the sole commercial bank, are licensed dealers. Import policy is de term ined by the Council for the Regulation of Trade. A foreign exchange budget, inc lud ing an import pro- gram, is established annually, and foreign exchange allocations under the import program are supervised by the Import Program Committee. Prescription of Currency Settlements with foreign countries normally must be made in any of the listed currencies. Transactions permitted in the listed currencies may alternatively be settled in Iraqi dinars through nonresident accounts. There are no bilateral paymen ts arrangements. Pay- ments to and receipts f rom Israel, Rhodes ia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The opening of a nonres ident account requ i res the approval of the exchange control authorities. Nonresi- dent accounts are divided into o rd ina ry non res ident accounts, which arise f rom transactions in respect of current payments, and special nonresident accounts, which arise from transactions in respect of capital transfers. Iraqi nationals who have been working abroad for at least a year or who become residents a f ter having been nonresidents may open accounts in fore ign currencies with banks in Iraq and credit these with up 4 Au s t r ian schillings, Belgian f ranc s, Canad ian dollars, Danish k rone r, deutsche m a r k, French f ranc s, Italian l i re, Japanese yen, Ne ther lands gu i lders, No rweg ian kroner, pounds s ter l ing, Swedish kroner, and Swiss francs. to 50 per cent of their fore ign savings. Balances in such accounts may be used for a variety of purposes, inc lud ing impor ts for the holder's personal use, impor ts of certain capital goods, or mee t ing expend i tu res abroad for travel, medical t rea tmen t, and s tudy purposes; pay- ments f rom these accounts up to the equ iva lent of ID 500 a year do not require the Central Bank's approval. Imports and Import Payments Imports of many commodities, inc lud ing ju t e, sugar, tea, edible oil, certain medical supplies, mach ine tools, and automobiles, are a government monopo ly. All private imports are subject to licenses except those for development projects benef i t ing f rom Law No. 157 of 1973; in principle, licenses are issued in accordance with an annual import program, but some impor ts take place outside the program. Imports of all goods f rom Israel, Rhodes ia, and South A f r ica are prohibited. All impo r ts f rom Hong Kong are regulated. Imports of some com- modities on a protection list are, in principle, prohibited f rom all sources. A tax is levied on the amount of any supp lemen tary import licenses above a private importer's annual quota. Regu la t ions de te rm in ing the incidence of this tax are issued annua l ly. To f inance the Export Subsidy Fund, a tax of 0.5 per cent is levied on imports of capital goods and a tax of 0.75 per cent on imports of consumer goods. All imports subject to import du ty are also subject to a customs surcharge of 15 per cent of the applicable customs du ty. The Ra f ida in Bank makes exchange available upon presentation of the exchange control copy of the import license, except in some instances where reference has to be made to the Central Bank. Payments for Invisibles With the exception of certain payments f rom fore ign currency accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above), all payments for invisibles require permission. Exchange is usually granted for educational and medical expenses abroad, freight on exports effected on a c. & f. basis, insurance premiums, royalties, etc. Exchange is not granted to merchants for the insurance abroad of their imports or exports. The Rafidain Bank is per- mitted to transfer up to 50 per cent of annual income accrued to Arab and foreign nationals resident in Iraq, unless the particular contract extends this limit to 75 per cent, subject to the approval of the Central Bank. There is a basic exchange allowance for tourist and business travel of ID 300 a trip for each person 12 years of age or over (ID 150 for children under 12), for trips of a month or less to Arab countries, socialist countries, Iran, and Turkey; for trips of over a month the allow- ance is increased to ID 400 (ID 200 for children under 12), and for subsequent trips in the same calendar year 217 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRAQ these allowances are reduced to 50 per cent or more of the basic allowance. For travel to other countries, the basic allowance is ID 500 a trip for each person 12 years of age or over for trips not exceeding one month, ID 600 for longer trips, and 50 per cent of the basic allocation for subsequent trips in the same calendar year. Travelers may take out ID 5 in Iraqi currency notes, which is considered part of the basic travel allowance, and the balance of that allowance in travelers checks. Residents on a pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia are pe rm i t ted to take out the equivalent of ID 300 in listed currencies or in Saudi Arabian riyals (ID 150 for persons over 5 and under 12). On leaving the country, Iraqi nationals must pay an exit tax of ID 10, except when traveling to Gulf coun- tries or the Syrian Arab Republic or on official business. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r ica and exports of certain goods to all other countries are prohibited. The Council for the Regulation of Trade has authority to prohibit the export of any commodity when supply falls short of domestic demand. The export of certain items is reserved for the General Organization for Exports. All other exports are licensed freely. Exporters generally must undertake to repatriate their foreign exchange proceeds through the Rafidain Bank and to surrender them within six months after shipment. Proceeds from exports of dates taken by sailing boats to countries of the Gulf area (excluding I r a n ), India, and Pakistan are exempt from these requirements when the amount does not exceed ID 600 in value or 25 tons in weight. Exports of certain goods are subsidized through an Export Subsidy Fund. The extent of finan- cial support may not exceed 25 per cent of the value of the goods, and commodities whose import content exceeds 40 per cent are ineligible. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts in excess of ID 50 from invisibles must be surrendered within three months to a licensed dealer. Travelers may bring in foreign exchange, including currency notes (other than Israel currency), in unlimited amounts, provided that the funds are declared on an exchange control form; amounts not intended to be taken out of the country are exempt from declaration. Travelers may bring in ID 25 in Iraqi notes. Capital Nonresidents may import capital freely, except from Israel, Rhodesia, or South Africa, but they must deposit it with the Rafidain Bank; such deposits may be con- 218 verted into local currency at the official rate, and repatriation to the country of origin is permitted. With minor exceptions, foreign companies starting operations in Iraq must use Iraqi capital to the extent of at least 51 per cent of their total capital. The transfer of profits (net of income tax) f rom foreign investments is limited to 10 per cent per annum of the paid-up capital for trad ing companies, to 20 per cent of the paid-up capital for industrial companies, and to 50 per cent of total profit for service companies. These percentages are applicable for each year separately. They also apply to profits on capital resulting from the mandatory reinvest- ment of profits in excess of the transferable percentage. Arab capital invested in Iraq is exempt from these percentage limitations and interest payments are not subject to ceilings. All transfers of capital abroad by residents, whether Iraqis or foreigners, require exchange control approval; such transfers are severely restricted. Special facilities allow Arab investors to bring in con- vertible currency freely through the Rafidain Bank for specified investment purposes; such capital and any net profits may be transferred abroad in convertible cur- rency. Similar facilities permit Iraqi nationals to bring in convertible currency through the Rafidain Bank and deposit the funds in foreign currency accounts, balances in which are freely transferable abroad. Under the Industrial Promotion Law (No. 22 of 1973), certain incentives and guarantees may be granted to approved investments of domestic or foreign capital in Iraq. Under the Iraqization Law of June 1961, all branches of foreign firms and all foreign- owned firms must have a majority of equity capital held by Iraqi nationals; this law does not cover export agencies and operations requiring special skills. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in Iraq in any form other than gold bars. Imports and exports of gold in any form require the approval of the Central Bank. The Rafidain Bank has a monopoly over the import and domestic distribution of gold needed for industrial purposes; it sells gold to registered goldsmiths only, under a quota system based on their past turnover of gold. Travelers may freely bring gold into Iraq, provided that it is declared at the point of entry on a foreign exchange form. Changes during 1978 November 9. It was announced that foreign enter- prises wishing to engage in business in Iraq must be registered with the Ministry of Planning. After Janu- ary 1, 1979 all activities by unregistered enterprises would be prohibited. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRELAND (Position on December 31, 1978) Exchange Rate System The currency of Ireland is the Irish Pound, which is pegged at par to the pound sterling and transactions in sterling are free of commissions.1 Daily quotations in the Irish foreign exchange market are based on the equivalent buying and selling rates for the pound sterling in London. On December 29, 1978 the Central Bank's buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were US$2.0420 and US$2.0400, respectively, per <£Ir. 1. Forward transactions between authorized banks and their customers must have an underlying commercial transaction. There are no taxes or subsidies on pur- chases or sales of foreign exchange. On February 15, 1961, Ireland formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control Exchange control is operated by the Central Bank. Much of the authority for approv ing normal payments is delegated to commercial banks authorized for this purpose. Import licenses, where necessary, are issued by the Department of Industry and Commerce if the goods are of an industrial nature, or by the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries if they are agr icu l tural in character. Import licensing is not used for exchange control purposes. Import and export controls are administered by the Revenue Commissioners. Prescription of Currency The adm in is tra t ion of Irish exchange control is based on the d is t inc t ion between entities that are permanen t ly resident in Ireland and nonresidents, i.e., residents of other countries. The latter comprises four categories: ( 1) residents of the United Kingdom, (2) residents of EEC member countries, ( 3) residents of Rhodesia,2 and (4) residents of all other countries. Authorized payments may be made in Irish pounds or in any foreign currency. The proceeds of exports must be received in foreign currency or in Irish pounds f rom an External Account. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Irish pounds of nonresidents are desig- nated External Accounts. All such trans- actions and other transactions (e.g., for t ravel or em ig r a t ion) involving Rhodesia or Rhodesian residents mu st be re fe r red to the Cen tral Bank. <£Ir 50,000 to nonbank external accounts require specific approval by the Central Bank, except where the credit is in respect of imports into Ireland, and there are limits on max imum balances in External Accounts of nonresident banks which may be maintained without prior approval of the Central Bank. There are two types of External Accounts: External Accounts in the names of residents of countries other than the United Kingdom (External Accounts —non-U.K.) and External Accounts in the names of U.K. residents (External Accounts —U.K.). External Accounts—non-U.K. may be credited with payments that are eligible for transfer to countries other than the United Kingdom, transfers from other External Accounts —non-U.K., transfers from External Accounts —U .K. under U.K. exchange control approval, pay- ments for any foreign currencies purchased from account holders, the proceeds of Irish currency notes in denomi- nations not exceeding £ I r20, and interest payable on the accounts; they may be debited for transfers to residents, transfers to other External Accounts, both U.K. and non-U.K., the cost of any foreign currency sold to account holders, the t rans fer of any part of account balances to account holders, and bank charges, if applicable. Authorized banks may operate foreign currency accounts in the names of nonresidents in any foreign currency provided that, in the case of U.K. residents, approval has been granted by the U.K. exchange control authorities; they may also operate fore ign currency accounts in the names of residents under specific Central Bank approval. Accounts held by or on behalf of residents of Rhode- sia are designated Rhodesian Accounts. The opening 219 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRELAND of such accounts, and all debits and credits thereto, require the prior approval of the Central Bank. Imports and Import Payments All imports of commodities originating in Rhodesia require a special license. The import from other sources of certain goods into Ireland is subject to three types of administrative control, as follows: Quantitative Restriction. —Special quota restrictions apply to (1) cycle tires from countries other than member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and Japan; (2) certain textile products originating in the state-trading countries; (3) automobile tires from the German Democratic Republic; (4) footwear from the Republic of China and Czechoslovakia, and (5) certain sacks and bags other than of wool, cotton, and man-made fibers (mainly jute bags originating in the Republic of China, Hong Kong, India, Japan, Macao, Malaysia, Pakistan, and Yugoslavia. Voluntary Restraint.—The EEC has negotiated bilat- eral restraint agreements with various supplying coun- tries on trade and textiles under which import quotas are set each year for different products. (Autono- mous import restrictions have been imposed by the EEC on the Republic of Ch ina .) Ireland also has a vo lun tary restraint agreement with Poland in regard to certain footwear. Surveillance. —Ireland operates a system of import surveillance over certain footwear f rom all sources and for imports of certain clothing and textiles and binder- twine f rom non-EEC sources. Under the third type of control, prior permission of the Central Bank is required before orders may be placed for goods if they are not to be used in Ireland or are to be delivered more than nine months after the date of the order. Special import restrictions apply in regard to motor vehicles. Imports f rom non-EEC countries of most products covered by the Common Agr icu l tural Policy of the EEC are subject to variable import levies which have replaced all previous barriers to imports; common EEC regula- tions are also applied to imports f rom non-EEC coun- tries of most other agr icu l tural and livestock products. For permitted imports, appropriate exchange or permis- sion to credit Irish pounds to an External Account is granted automatically. Exchange control forms are requ ired for import paymen ts exceeding <£ Ir 10,000. Payments for Invisibles Payments to nonresidents require approval. Approval to make paymen ts for most invisibles is delegated to the authorized banks; for other invisibles, it is given by the Central Bank. For tourist travel there is a basic allowance for resi- dents of Ireland of <£Ir 500 a person for each trip, or 220 where the trip exceeds two months, <£Ir 1,000. For business travel, up to <£Ir 3,000 at a rate of <£Ir 100 a day is allowed for each journey. Limits are also estab- lished for allowances for education and other purposes. Applications for larger amounts are approved, provided that no unauthorized export of capital is involved. Not more than <£Ir 500 of an allowance of foreign currency may be issued in the form of currency notes. Residents may also take with them up to <£Ir 100 in Irish cur- rency notes. Nonresidents may take with them any foreign currency notes that they brought into Ireland. Exports and Export Proceeds A system of export licensing is applied to a limited range of goods. Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited at present except under license. The export to South Africa of arms, ammunition, military equipment, and vehicles is also prohibited. Exporters of goods must obtain payment for the goods within six months of shipment, if their value exceeds <£Ir 100. When payment is received in foreign currencies, the exchange must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. Exchange control forms are required for exports exceeding <£Ir 10,000. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no specific requirements governing exchange receipts from invisibles, but if foreign currencies are received they must be offered for sale to an authorized bank or permission for their retention must be obtained. Any foreign currency held by a person after his return f rom a trip abroad may be retained for three months f rom the date he received the exchange. There are no limitations on the import of Irish or foreign banknotes. Capital Exchange control approval is required for all trans- fers of capital to nonresidents. The normal allowance available to Irish residents on emigration is <£Ir 40,000 for each fam i ly. Where the total value of an emigrant's assets exceeds <£ Ir 40,000, the transfer of the excess amount is restricted for a period of four years from the emigrant's redesignation as a nonresident, i.e., f rom the date of departure f rom Ireland. After the four-year period, the balance of restricted assets may be freely exported without limit. For Irish residents taking up pe rmanent residence in an EEC country, including people tak ing up employment, applications are con- sidered to transfer Irish assets to the new country of residence in excess of the normal allowances. There are no restrictions on the inflow of capital, but inward direct investment requires exchange control approval and net inflows into the banks may be subject to guidelines set from time to time by the Central Bank. At the end of 1978 the following guidelines were in force. Banks are required to deposit with the Central ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Bank 50 per cent of any net capital inflows occurring after May 1977. However, subject to prior consultation with the Central Bank, inflows of capital in connection with the financing of major industrial projects, whether public or private, may be exempted from the 50 per cent requirement. Moreover, temporary inflows arising f rom acceptances already arranged, may also be exempted from the requirement. Purchases of unquoted Irish securities by nonresidents require exchange control approval, and the purchase of nonurban land by fore ign nationals in most cases requires approval by the Land Commission. Incoming capital received in foreign cur- rencies must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. The Central Bank will consider applications by Irish residents for permission to purchase property for per- sonal use in a member coun try of the EEC with foreign currency purchased at the official rate of exchange. The acquisition of personal property outside the EEC may be financed only by foreign currency borrowing, which will be approved by the Central Bank on appli- cation, subject to a l im it of <£ Ir 20,000 a property and one property for each f am i ly un i t. Borrowings may be repaid with official foreign exchange in equal annual installments over a period of not less than five years. The entire fore ign currency proceeds f rom the sale of property outside Ireland purchased for personal use of a resident must be offered for sale to an authorized dealer. Transactions in foreign currency securities are con- trolled to ensure that capital is not transferred outside Ireland. All such transactions must be routed through an approved agent (an Irish bank, stockbroker, or solicitor). Resident holdings of all foreign currency securities ( inc lud ing U.K. securities) may be sold only to nonresidents. Where such securities, whether acquired with sterling investment currency or not, are sold, the proceeds must be either reinvested or offered for sale to an authorized dealer w i th in three months. Dur ing that three-month period, in the absence of the specific approval of the Central Bank, the proceeds must be held under the control of an approved agent. Purchases of for- eign currency securities (including U.K. securities), apart f rom switches referred to above, are prohibited. The Central Bank may, however, approve foreign currency borrowing by institutional investors for portfolio invest- ment abroad. Borrowing for investment in securities issued by the EEC, the European Investment Bank, the European Coal and Steel Commun i ty, and the European Atomic Energy Community are normally approved for any Irish resident and are subject to less stringent requirements.3 Direct investment abroad requires prior approval and may normally be financed by borrowing foreign cur- rency; in certain cases the use of official exchange may 8 Such borrow ings may be repaid in equal installments over five years w i th official fo re ign exchange; interest charges may also be paid with official fore ign exchange. Dealings by nonresidents in Irish registered securities are permitted subject to notification to the Central Bank; purchases by nonresidents must be funded with fore ign currency or Irish pounds from an External Account. Remittances of casli g if ts or personal loans are nor- mally permitted up to <£ Ir 1,500 a donor a calendar year. For dependents, an additional amount of up to <£ I r2 ,000 a donor a year in cash g if ts or personal loans may be remitted. Applications by Irish residents to make cash gifts or personal loans to EEC residents, in excess of the normal allowance, will be considered. Application must be made to the Central Bank for nonbank pr iva te sector borrowing from nonresidents; such applications are considered on their merits and, except as regards borrowing for the acquisition of prop- erty for personal use, on the benefit likely to accrue to the economy. Public sector borrowing f rom nonresidents is unde r taken following consultation with the Central Bank. Lend ing of Irish currency to nonresidents is not no rma l ly permitted, except to the extent that overdraft fac i l i t ies may be provided by the banks to members of d ip loma t ic and consular missions in Ireland. Provided that the company is not a channel for portfolio invest- ment, a subsidiary or branch of a company controlled by interests in EEC countries may obtain f rom Irish banks, subject to exchange control approval, all the finance it requires for its operation in Ireland. Gold Residents may freely hold, buy, borrow, sell, or lend gold coin in Ireland. Dealings in gold bullion are restricted, and no dealings take place in Ireland. Although there are no import restrictions, residents require specific exchange control permission to purchase gold coin or bullion outside Ireland. Specific exchange control permission also is required for the export of gold coin and bullion outside Ireland. Specific permis- sion to buy or export gold coin or bullion normally is given only for bona fide numismatic or industrial pur- poses, respectively. Residents of Ireland are not per- mitted to hold gold abroad. Changes during 1978 January 1. Ireland completed the phasing out of its duties on imports of all industrial and agricultural products from other member states of the EEC, and fu l ly aligned its customs duties with those of the EEC's common customs tariff for imports from third countries. Ireland acceded to all existing preferential trade agree- ments negotiated between the EEC and third countries. January 1. New quota levels came into effect for certain imports, including textiles, yarns, and footwear, from countries in the state trading area. 221 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRELAND December 18. In consequence of Ireland's decision to participate in the European Monetary System, Ireland introduced exchange control measures to be applied to all financial transactions with Great Britain, Nor thern Ireland, the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man, and Gibraltar. These areas are, for convenience, referred to as the "United Kingdom" in the description given below. The general effect was to align the United Kingdom with other EEC countries. All persons, companies, and other legal entities resident in the Un i ted Kingdom were designated as nonresident for Irish exchange control purposes. In consequence, all payments to, or on behalf of, or for the credit of such persons would require permission f rom an authorized dealer or, in certain cases, f rom the Central Bank. The exchange control measures adopted were as follows: 1. Designation of accounts, (a) The accounts of banks and other f inanc ial ins t i tu t ions in Ireland of residents of the United Kingdom were designated Exter- nal Accounts; (b) all credits in excess of <£Ir 50,000 to nonbank External Accounts, irrespective of the coun- try of residence of the account holder, required the specific approval of the Central Bank; and (c) without the specific approval of the Central Bank, the max imum permitted balance on accounts of nonresident banks, irrespective of the country of residence of the bank, was an amount <£Ir 100,000 in excess of the balance on each such account at the close of business on December 17, 1978. 2. Accounts in the United Kingdom of Irish residents. Irish residents holding accounts with banks or other financial institutions in the United Kingdom were required to close such accounts within three months. The balance on such account must be offered for sale to an authorized dealer, unless the account holder had applied for, and had been granted, approval by the Central Bank to continue to operate the account. Within the period of three months referred to above, such accounts might not be used to acquire securities or properties outside Ireland or to make other capital trans- fers to nonresidents of Ireland. 3. Foreign borrowing. Apart from borrowings asso- ciated with normal trade credit terms, the prior approval of the Central Bank would be required for all borrowing from residents of the United Kingdom. 4. Portfolio investment, (a) Purchases of Irish- quoted securities by nonresidents (including U.K. residents) should be notified to the Central Bank, (b) Resident holdings of all foreign currency securities (including U.K. securities) might be sold only to non- residents; where such securities were sold, the proceeds must either be reinvested or offered for sale to an authorized dealer within two months (later extended to three mon th s ), (c) Purchases of foreign currency securities (including U.K. securities), apart from switches referred to in (b) above, were not allowed. The Central Bank, however, was prepared to consider applications f rom institutional investors to borrow for- eign currency for portfolio investment. 5. Direct investment. Existing rules for the super- vision of direct investment in the EEC now applied to the United Kingdom. 6. Personal capital movements. Existing rules for the supervision of personal capital movements to the EEC now applied to the United Kingdom. 7. Purchases of personal property abroad. Existing rules for the supervision of the purchase of personal property in the EEC now applied to the United King- dom. Applications for permission to borrow foreign currency for the purchase of personal property outside the EEC would be approved by the Central Bank, subject to a limit of <£ Ir 20,000 for each property and one property for each fam i ly unit. Borrowings might be repaid in equal annual installments over a period of not less than five years with official foreign exchange. 8. Imports and exports. Imports from and exports to the United Kingdom were subject to the same rules as were applied to trade with other countries. These rules were designed not to hinder trade but only to monitor payments and avoid evasion of restrictions on capital movements. 9. Travel. The existing foreign travel arrangements applied to the United Kingdom. 10. Exempted transactions. Transactions not exceed- ing <£Ir 100 in value were exempted from exchange control. 11. Provision of forward cover. With effect from December 18: (a) authorized dealers might provide forward cover to nonbank residents for trade-related transactions only; (b) authorized dealers might provide forward cover to nonresident banks on evidence that the transaction was related to trade; (c) prior Central Bank approval was required for cover in excess of <£Ir 50,000; and (d) authorized dealers might not pro- vide forward cover direct to nonbank nonresidents. 12. Rhodesia. Existing arrangements regarding Rho- desia remained unchanged. 222 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ISRAEL (Position on December 31, 1978) Exchange Rate System The cu r rency of Israel is the Israel Pound. The authorities do not ma in ta in ma rg ins in respect of exchange transactions, and exchange rates are deter- mined largely on the basis of demand and supply condi- tions in the exchange markets. However, the au thor i t ies intervene when necessary in order to smooth out fluc- tua t ions in rates in order to ma in ta in orderly conditions in the ma rke t. Au tho r ized banks are permitted to deal in foreign exchange w i th residents and w i th their cor- respondents in foreign marke ts. At the end of the trad ing day the Bank of Israel publishes an average of the quota- tions of the day as a representative rate. On Decem- ber 31, 1978 the representative rate for the U.S. dollar was I £19.01 per US$1. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of fore ign exchange. Administration of Control Exchange control is the respons ib i l i ty of the Con- troller of Foreign Exchange and is adm in is te red by the Bank of Israel, in cooperation with other government agencies and is carr ied out th rough au tho r ized banks. Prescription of Currency Paymen ts and receipts must be effec ted in the cur- rency and manner prescribed by the exchange control au thor i t ies. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents' f u n ds are held either in fore ign currency accounts or in local currency accounts. The open ing of non res ident fore ign currency accounts does not requ i re prior approval. The holder may f ree ly e f fect t ran s fe rs f r om his fore ign cu r rency account. He may also convert f u n ds held on the account in to local cu r rency at the ma rket rate of exchange. There are no restrictions on the open ing by a non- resident of a local cu r rency account and on the local use of such f u n d s, inc lud ing t ran s fe rs between nonres iden ts. Nonres ident holders of a local cu r rency account may convert at the ma rket rate of exchange up to US$3,000 for each visit to Israel, wh ich may be t r an s f e r r ed abroad, together w i th an amount of local cu r rency not exceeding I £5,000. The sales proceeds of real es ta te and other inves tmen ts may be t r an s f e r r ed in the ir en t i re ty if the o r ig in al inves tment had been made w i th fo r e ign cu r rency or State of Israel Deve lopment Loan bonds. Resident Accounts in Foreign Currency Residents may m a i n t a in fo re ign cu r rency deposits with au tho r ized banks in Israel on e i ther ( 1) PATAM accounts, wh ich may be held by all recipients of fo re ign exchange or fo re ign cu r rency acqu i red f rom a bank or (2) PAZAK or TAMAM accounts, which may be held by recipients of res t i tu t ion payments and certain disability pensions. PATAM accounts are demand or time deposit accounts in fo re ign currency placed w i th authorized banks, which must redeposit, respectively, 90 per cent or 80 per cent of the fore ign currency funds with the Bank of Israel. Balances in these accounts are transferab le between residents and may be used to pay for any bona fide in te rna t ional current transaction. PAZAK or TAMAM accounts also are demand or time deposit accounts in convertible currencies with author- ized banks, which must redeposit all of these foreign currency f u n ds w i th the Bank of Israel. Two thirds of convertible exchange receipts derived f rom personal restitution payments and from pensions of disabled soldiers who served during World War II may be credited to PAZAK accounts; the remaining one third may be credited to TAMAM accounts. Funds deposited in both types of account are free of taxation. TAMAM accounts are permitted to be used for ( 1) payment of p rem iums on existing life insurance policies denom ina ted in foreign currency and (2) pay- ment of expenses in connection w i th travel and subsis- tence abroad in excess of the basic travel exchange a l loca t ion. Holders of TAMAM accounts may resell securities bought w i th TAMAM account funds for foreign cu r rency, and deposit the proceeds in a TAMAM account. Residents who are not holders of TAMAM accounts may deposit the foreign exchange proceeds f rom the sale of fore ign securities in PATAM accounts. Imports and Import Payments A few impor ts are prohibited f rom all sources and all impo r ts f rom Rhodesia are prohibited. Almost all impo r ts are f ree of licensing and administrative or qu an t i t a t ive restrictions. A few imports on a Restricted List are subject to approval; this list includes some meat and da i ry produc ts, sugar, tobacco, chemicals, and pha rmaceu t ical products. Oilseeds and edible fa ts are impo r ted exclusively by or for account of the Govern- men t. Exchange to pay for authorized imports is g ran ted au toma t ica l ly by the banks upon presentation of proof of the impo rt transac t ion. A value-added tax is levied on a lmost all imported and domestically produced goods, o ther t h an cap i tal goods and travel tickets. Payments for Invisibles Exchange for paymen ts abroad on account of invisi- bles is provided au toma t ica l ly upon proof of the na ture of the t ran sac t ion. The exchange allowance for tourist travel is the equ iva lent of US$3,000 a traveler for each j o u r n e y. No l im i ts app ly w i th respect to credit cards. Res ident t rave le rs may take out part or all of the travel a l lowance in Israel bankno tes. Nonresident travelers 223 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ISRAEL leaving Israel are permitted to repurchase through authorized dealers foreign currency up to US$3,000 and may, in addition, take out up to I .£5,000 in Israel banknotes. Commercial banks are authorized to sell abroad unlimited amounts of Israel currency. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Most exports do not require licenses, although for some commodities export licensing is retained for quality control. Export proceeds in foreign currencies must be surrendered or held in a PAT AM account. Exporters may retain in a deposit account abroad an amount equivalent to 10 per cent of their turnover in the preceding year. For inputs directly imported by an exporter there is a system of rebates of customs duties, wharf charges, etc. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange proceeds from invisibles must, in general, be surrendered. Alternatively, they may be kept in foreign exchange on PATAM accounts. Any resident is free to accept specified convertible currencies from tourists in payment for services and commodities other than commercial exports, securities, and real estate. For 20 years af ter entering Israel, new immigrants are exempt f rom the requirement to surrender their foreign exchange to the Treasury, and they may hold these foreign currencies freely with authorized banks in Israel or with banks abroad. There are no limits to the amoun ts of Israel banknotes or foreign currency that may be brought in by travelers. Capital Foreign exchange representing incoming capital and belonging to a resident may be held in a PATAM account. Capital brought into Israel for the purpose of investment may, subject to approval, be granted preferential treat- ment in accordance with the Law for the Encouragement of Capital Investments of May 23, 1976, which, inter a l ia, permits a nonresident who has made an investment in foreign currency to transfer all his profits abroad in the same currency at the official rate. Current policy is to grant "approved" status only to enterprises in selected fields of production that ( 1) are established either in "priority areas" or in less developed areas; (2) are export oriented, i.e., either at least 50 per cent of the ou tput is exported or the existing productive capacity is increased by at least 50 per cent while at least 50 per cent of the additional output is exported; ( 3) have geared production to impor t-subs t i tu t ion, even though for economic reasons, the enterprise cannot be estab- lished in a priority area or in a less developed area; or (4) will fac i l i ta te the absorption of immigrants. There is no d ifference between an "approved invest- ment" and any other investment made by a nonresident in fore ign currency, inso far as his rights to t r an s f er abroad the principal, the interest, or the profits are concerned, 224 and repayments and amortization of capital may also be transferred.1 However, there are differences as regards other benefits, such as income tax concessions and grants. Investments made by nonresidents prior to Janua ry 1, 1958 and investments made by nonresidents in foreign exchange a f ter that date can be transferred abroad. Proceeds accruing from the repatriation or liquidation of foreign assets held by residents are treated in the same way as proceeds from invisibles. Any resident may retain real estate abroad, but not money, securities, or the income from such assets; in addition, new immigrants may retain their liquid assets for 20 years. Transfers abroad of a capital na ture by residents other than new immigrants are generally not permitted. A general license allows nonresidents to purchase in Israel real estate, shares, and debentures. In order to repatriate the principal or profits of these investments, proof is required to be presented to an authorized dealer that they were made in foreign currency. Direct loans in any fo rm to nonresidents are subject to licensing, but loans to a resident by a nonresident may be made freely if the f u n ds are credited to a PATAM account. Gold Residents, including private persons, may hold gold in the form of bars or certificates entitling them to gold held in bars on deposit with an authorized dealer. Gold can be bought or sold only from or to an author- ized dealer. Other residents are forbidden to trade in gold or to take it out of Israel. Imports of gold are permitted only if an import license is obtained. Changes during 1978 During the year, numerous amendments were made to the schedule of import tariff rates, to the list of imports subject to licensing or other restrictions, and to the list of imports subject to ta r i ff surcharges. April 1. Two amendments were made to the income tax provisions of the Law for the Encouragement of Indus try. The income tax on retained earnings was reduced f rom 35 to 20 per cent and firms were author- ized to revalue their inventories by 25 per cent and 50 per cent of domestic inflation in 1978 and 1979. November 1. The Additional Protocol to the Agree- ment between the EEC and Israel and the Protocol on Financial Cooperation between the EEC and Israel entered into force. December 10. A 20 per cent surrender requirement was imposed on receipts f rom short-term foreign loans and capital inflows. The requirement took the form of interest-free deposits at the Bank of Israel. Administration of Control The exchange control system is opera ted by the Italian Exchange Office (Uff ic io Italiano dei Cambi or U IC) on the basis of instructions issued by the Ministry of Foreign Trade. All sales and purchases of exchange must be effected through banks authorized for this purpose. Import and export licenses, when required, are issued by the Ministry of Finance at the request of the M in is try of Foreign Trade. Certain imports and exports require the prior visa of the National Foreign Trade Institute. Issues of securities by nonresidents require the prior approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade and are subject in addition to the rules governing the issuing in Italy of Italian securities. Imports and Import Payments Imports are governed by a M in is te r ial Decree of May 6, 1976. The import regu la t ions vary with the coun try of origin. Countries are grouped in three ma jor areas: Zone A, which is subdivided into subzones A /1 (EEC coun tr ies, Guade loupe, French Gu i an a, Mar t i- nique, and Reun ion ), A /2 (overseas countries and ter- ritories, member countries of the European Free Trade Association, and other countries associated w i th the EEC), and A /3 (third countries); Zone B (member countries of the Council for Mu tu al Economic Assist- ance (CMEA), A lban ia, the People's Republic of Ch ina, and Nor th Korea); and Zone C (Japan). The import control procedures distinguish between goods that may be freely imported w i thout quan t i ta t ive restriction and goods that require a special license. Import liberaliza- tion is v i r tua l ly complete for subzones A /1 and A/2, while very few quan t i ta t ive restrictions remain for sub- zone A /3. Many types of goods f rom Zones B and C are heavily restricted. For imports f rom countries in Zone B, as well as Egypt and Yugoslavia, the country of origin must also be the coun try of shipment. All imports of Rhodesian origin are proh ib i ted. Imports from non-EEC countries of most products covered by the Common Agr icu l tural Policy of the EEC are subject to variable import levies that have replaced all previous barriers to imports. Common EEC regulations are also applied to imports from non- EEC countries of most other agricultural and livestock products. For imports not exceeding Lit 1 million in value, no exchange control form is required; for imports f rom Lit 1 million to Lit 2 million in value, a form completed by the importer is required; for imports over Lit 2 million in value, an import document completed by an author- ized bank is required. Where settlement takes place more than 360 days after importation, the importer must choose an authorized bank as his bank of domicile, 226 through which he must carry out all payments operations. Deferred payments for imports are permitted freely if settlement is to take place, to the extent of at least 90 per cent, within 360 days after importation, and the balance w i th in 24 months af ter importation; such payments require the prior approval of the UIC if the settlement is to take place between 12 months and 24 months a f ter importation. In all other cases, the prior approval of the M in is t ry of Foreign Trade is required; where, according to the contract, settlement is to take place more than 360 days a f ter the date of importation, the approval of the UIC (in some cases the M in is try of Foreign Trade) is required to make the payment prior to the due date set in the contract. Advance paymen ts for imports require special approval when they are to take place more than 120 days before importation. Advance paymen ts in excess of Lit 2 million must be made with foreign cur- rency borrowed f rom authorized banks. When prepay- ments for imports exceed Lit 10 million, an advance deposit of 5 per cent is required. For all authorized imports, the authorized banks provide exchange or permit payment in Italian lire to a Foreign Account, provided that appropriate payment terms are observed (see section on Capital, below). In te rna t ional postal money orders may be used for import payments, subject, in the case of payments to Switzer- land, to a l im it of Lit 30,000 for each remitter and fore ign beneficiary. Payments for Invisibles In principle, payments abroad for invisibles require authorization by the exchange control authorities. How- ever, the authorized banks may sell foreign exchange for paymen ts for invisibles provided that the necessary documents are submitted, except for tourist travel and travel for business, study, or health reasons; their au tho r i ty to sell exchange for fam i ly remittances is limited to Lit 35,000 a transfer. Exchange is granted freely for remittances of earnings or investments. Residents may use international postal money orders for payments, sub- ject, in the case of payments to Switzerland, to a limit of Lit 30,000 for each remitter and foreign beneficiary. Certain transactions (but not the related payments) in respect of services are subject to approval by the Min- istry of Foreign Trade or the Ministry of Industry. These transactions can be divided into two groups: (1) contracts which require a permit if they involve residents of specified countries 7 and (2) contracts which require a permit regardless of the nationality of the nonresidents involved. The first group includes trans- actions giving rise to expenditures for chartering ships (excluding charters for a single trip); repairs to ships which are not urgent and not necessary for safety of operation; news agencies and newspaper correspondents 7 Albania, Bhu tan, Bu lgar ia, People's Republic of China (including Mongo l ia), Cuba, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, Hun- gary, Democratic Kampuchea, North Korea, Poland, Romania, U.S.S.R., Viet Nam, and ( for chartering ships only) Yugoslavia. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution (for amounts exceeding Lit 5 million a month for the same payee); purchases of publication rights; informa- tion agencies, etc. (for amounts exceeding Lit 5 million for each contract); copyrights (for amounts exceeding Lit 5 million a year for each contract); services of pro- fessional workers and company managers (for amounts exceeding Lit 5 million); and services of en ter ta iners and athletes (for amounts exceeding Lit 5 million). The second group includes transactions giving rise to ex- penditures for production abroad of films, u t i l iza t ion of films, scripts, synchronization, etc.; collaboration in cinematography; insurance of ships and a ircraft against risks of operation; 8 and other transac t ions when the amounts involved exceed Lit 1 million. Residents traveling to foreign countries may obtain from the banks exchange equivalent to Lit 750,000 a person a year for tourism, business, medical t rea tmen t, and education (the corresponding amount for group travel also is Lit 750,000); the UIC grants foreign exchange above these allowances (except for tourism), provided that it is satisfied that th is is jus t i f ied in the l ight of the du ra t ion and purpose of the t r ip. The amount that may be taken out in the fo rm of fore ign bankno tes is Lit 100,000, wh i le up to Lit 650,000 may be taken out in letters of credit, fore ign payment orders, t rave le rs checks, or non t ran s fe rab le checks d rawn on fo re ign banks. However, the export of Italian bankno tes in denom ina t ions larger than Lit 50,000 is prohibited. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to any coun t ry of a few commodities in a special list (Tabella Esport) requ i re export licenses. For exports not exceeding Lit 1 million in va lue, no exchange control form is required; for exports f rom Lit 1 mil- lion to Lit 2 million in value, a fo rm completed by the exporter is required; for exports exceeding Lit 2 mil- lion in va lue, an export document completed by an authorized bank is required. If settlement takes place more than 360 days before expo r ta t ion or more than 120 days a f ter expor ta t ion, the expor ter must effect the paymen ts operations related to his export t ransac t ions th rough an au tho r ized bank as his b ank of dom ic i le. Advance paymen ts for expo r ts may be received f ree ly if expor ta t ion is to take place w i th in 360 days; in all other cases, such receipts requ i re the p r ior app roval of the UIC. Deferred paymen ts for exports are pe rm i t ted if settlement is to take place to the ex tent of at least ITALY 90 per cent within 120 days after exportation, and the balance within 24 months after exportation. For settle- ments between 120 and 360 days after exportation, the approval of the UIC is required. In all other cases such receipts require the prior approval either of the Ministry of Foreign Trade, or of the Autonomous Section for Export Credits ( SACE ), depending on whether the max- imum delay granted to the foreign importer is longer or shorter than five years, and on whether the trans- action will be covered by state insurance. Unless special approval is obtained for different terms of payment, 90 per cent of exchange receipts must be collected w i th in 120 days of shipment and offered for sale to an authorized bank within 7 days of receipt, while 10 per cent must be collected w i th in 24 months of shipment. Proceeds in U.S. dollars, Canadian dollars, Japanese yen, and externally convertible European cur- rencies may be retained by authorized banks on behalf of the recipients in Ordinary Foreign Currency Accounts (Conti Valutari Ordinari) for 15 days, dur ing which period such balances may be used for permitted trans- actions or be sold to authorized banks; the banks are allowed to sell these currencies to residents for author- ized transac t ions or to negotiate them freely w i th the UIC or among themselves.10 A f t er expiration of the re ten t ion period, unused balances must be sold to the UIC at the lowest exchange rate quoted dur ing the retention period (these rates are determined daily on the basis of the average closing rates in Milan and Rom e ). Export proceeds may also be received by in te rna t ional postal money order, up to Lit 600,000 for each paymen t, and in certain circumstances, in foreign bankno tes that are accepted in the coun t ry of issue for credit to bank accounts, balances in which are con- ver t ib le at official market rates. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from current inv is ib les are subject to the same collection, re ten t ion, and surrender requ iremen ts as receipts from exports. Shipping and insurance com- pan ies and travel and fo rwa rd ing agencies may keep Ope ra t ing Accounts (Conti Autorizzati) in U.S. dollars, Canad ian dollars, Japanese yen, and ex te rna l ly con- ver t ib le European currencies; unu t i l ized balances must be surrendered periodically. Residents may not retain fore ign bankno tes l e ft over f rom trips abroad but must sell them to an authorized bank. Persons may bring in any amount in fore ign bankno tes and Lit 100,000 in I t a l i an bankno tes, in denom ina t ions not larger than Lit 50,000. Repayment of such loans may be made freely. A deposit requirement applies to outward transfers of resident-owned capital for direct investments, port- folio investments, financial loans, purchases of real estate, and personal capital movements. The transferor must lodge a lira deposit equivalent to 50 per cent of the amount transferred (25 per cent for investment fund securities, but mu tual funds investing entirely in Italian securities are exempt) in a noninterest-bearing account with the bank effecting the transfer. In addition, when foreign investments are transferred between residents against lire, the transferee is subject to the deposit requirement, regardless of the date when the investment was made. The deposits are released only when, and to the extent that, disinvestment operations occur, and their release requires the prior approval of the Bank of Italy. Reinvestments of funds in new issues or on the secondary market are exempt if the original investment was made prior to July 27, 1973. Purchases by residents of certain bonds issued by specified EEC ins t i tu t ions are also exempt. Outward direct investment transactions have f rom time to time been given an ad hoc exemption. Foreign investment in Italy is, in principle, governed by Law No. 43 and subsequent implementing regulations. Foreign investments of any kind, including both direct and portfolio inves tment and the purchase of real estate, are permitted freely, and no restrictions are applied to their repatriation. Direct investment in OECD countries by physical or juridical persons (other than participation by a financial institution that has its main office in Italy in a foreign company not hav ing the same corporate purpose) is permitted in any form and w i thout any limit.11 Direct investment in other countries may be made only by jur id ical persons in firms that are in the same line of business as that of the I ta l ian firm mak ing the invest- ment and under the supervision of the UIC; other types of direct investment in such countries require special authorization f rom the M in is t ry of Foreign Trade. The general license to make these inves tmen ts also covers 11 F inanc ial inve s tmen t, i.e., inve s tment not intended to establish pe rmanent relations, is not considered direct inves tmen t. The regu la t ions gove rn ing d irect inves tment are also not applicable to participations in "holdings" abroad of any k ind. 228 the reinvestment of earnings and the use for this purpose of the liquidation proceeds of previous investments (after crediting the proceeds of the disinvestment to bank accounts similar to those established for proceeds from exports and invisibles; see section on Proceeds from Invisibles, above). Residents are free to buy and sell, through the Bank of Italy or the authorized banks, any foreign securities issued or payable abroad and quoted on foreign stock exchanges, and to deal in such securities among them- selves against payment in lire. Such foreign securities, except securities of Lit 100,000 or less, have to be deposited with an Italian bank or with a bank abroad for account of an Italian bank. The purchase by resi- dents of shares of foreign financial institutions of any kind (including mu tual funds), as well as convertible bonds issued by such institutions, requires prior approval by the UIC. In practice, however, a resident is able to purchase freely shares of foreign funds that have received authorization from the Ministry of Foreign Trade to sell their shares in Italy, since that authorization is valid also for the individual resident subscriber. Such authorization is given only to funds meeting certain requirements, including the investment of at least 50 per cent of their portfolio in Italian securities and the estab- lishment of a branch office in Italy. Residents do not require authorization to purchase real estate in EEC countries. All issues of securities by nonresidents on the Italian capital market require the prior approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade, and are subject to the rules governing the issue of domestic securities. These rules include the prior approval of the Bank of Italy, and, for issues above Lit 500 million, that of the Ministry of the Treasury, the Ministry of Industry, and the Interministerial Credit Committee. Issues are normally restricted to inter- national institutions. Transfers in connection with donations, inheritances, and dowries may be made freely. The transfer of property of residents leaving Italy permanently is allowed in two stages: the equivalent of Lit 5 million a person is allowed upon presentation of specified documents to an authorized bank at the time of leaving Italy, and .the remainder is subject to examination of the documents by the UIC, when residence has been established abroad. In relations with EEC countries, the reciprocal grant- ing of credits for commercial transactions or the per- formance of services, with a maturity longer than the time limits that banks are authorized to approve and up to five years, may be effected a f ter examination of the documents by the UIC. This applies also in relations with Austria, Finland, Norway, Sweden, and Switzerland. Loans and credits (the la t ter only beyond a certain dura t ion, generally 180-360 days) not connected with commercial transactions or w i th the performance of services require the approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade and are severely restricted. However, financial ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution loans may be granted to or by residents of EEC coun- tries as indicated above. The export of Italian and foreign securities is per- mitted only when they are owned by nonresidents and have been purchased against U.S. dollars, Canadian dollars, Japanese yen, or externally convertible European currencies, or against funds on a Foreign Account or a Capital Account. Gold Residents may freely hold and negotiate gold in any form in Italy, with the exception of unref ined gold imported under ministerial license for indus tr ial pur- poses. The mone tary authorities may free ly acqu ire un re f ined gold abroad. Agent banks may acquire unre- fined gold abroad upon submission of licenses issued by the M in is try of Foreign Trade to I ta l ian firms for industrial use. Exports of wrought and sem imanufac- tured gold, other than jewe lry, are subject to licensing. Imports of unrefined gold are in principle subject to value-added tax but at the end of 1978 the rate of tax was zero per cent. Importation and exportation of gold coins which are legal tender in a fo re ign coun try are prohibited in the absence of a special au thor iza t ion. Imports of other gold coins for num isma t ic purposes are subject to value-added tax at 18 per cent. Changes during 1978 January 10.
