Not for Redistribution investments in Morocco are transferable to the investor's country of residence. The transfer of dividends on nonresident-owned shares of Moroccan companies hav- ing their main office in Morocco requires the approval of the Exchange Office. Undistributed profits relating to the financial year 1968 or later remain transferable indefinitely. Some payments are subject to limitations. A foreign employee may transfer to his country of origin, subject to the initial approval of the Exchange Office, 50 per cent of his monthly wages or salary if his f am i ly does not reside in Morocco, or 30 per cent if he is single or his fam i ly lives in Morocco,9 except for the medical and paramedical professions, such transfers are subject to a limit of DH 1,000 a month. Subject to a monthly limit of DH 300, the same percentages of earnings may also be transferred by foreign nationals engaged in agricultural, industrial, or commercial activities, or in skilled crafts. Foreign nationals employed in the hotel sector or the mining sector are authorized to transfer between 60 and 80 per cent of their monthly salaries or wages. An allocation of foreign exchange equivalent to DH 100 a person a year is granted to residents of any nationality for travel abroad, provided that they do not make periodic transfers abroad. There is a special allocation for pilgrimages. Residents of foreign na- tionality may acquire exchange for tourist travel up to the equivalent of DH 2,500 a year for each passport by selling to an authorized bank a corresponding amount in foreign exchange (other than banknotes) from their own foreign assets not subject to surrender requirements. For business travel by persons other than exporters a standard allowance of DH 250 a day is granted, up to DH 5,000 a person a trip and within an annual ceiling fixed individually by the Exchange Office; exporters may obtain up to DH 300 a day, up to DH 7,500 a person a trip, within a ceiling of 3 per cent of the foreign ex- change repatriated dur ing the preceding calendar year. The allocation issued for business travel may be added to the allocation issued for tourist travel. Moroccan students pursuing higher studies abroad may obtain monthly allocations of foreign exchange up to DH 1,000 for students in higher education who do not hold scholarships, and of DH 1,500 for doctoral students who do not hold scholarships. There is also a quarterly allocation of DH 1,000 as a supplement for scholarship students. Students are granted an annual installation allowance, fixed at DH 2,000. For family mainte- nance, the Exchange Office grants a monthly allocation of DH 300. MOROCCO Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports may be made freely, although export licenses are required for a few items, and exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. All fruits, fresh vegetables, canned goods, raw cotton, and cotton by-products may be exported only by a state trading agency, the Office of Marke t ing and Export (Office de Commercialisa- tion et d'Exportation —OCE) which is also in charge of w ine exports. All exporters must sign an unde r tak ing to repatriate and surrender fore ign exchange proceeds. The sur- render to the exporter's bank must take place w i th in one mon th from the date the payment is due. The da te on which the payment is due is the maturity date fixed in the commercial contract; in principle, this date must not be set more than 90 days a f ter the date of arrival of the merchandise at the place of destination. When the exporter's bank receives the advice of credit in fo re ign currency f rom abroad, it must surrender the foreign exchange immediately to the Bank of Morocco. Proceeds from Invisibles Residents of Moroccan nationality and Moroccan companies must repatriate exchange receipts accruing f rom all their noncommercial claims and surrender them to an authorized bank. Other residents must sur- render noncommercial receipts only if the receipts result f rom current transactions, and only when they accrue in foreign currencies other than those of the former French Franc Area. Moroccans working abroad must surrender such currencies within one month of re-entry, but are permitted, when leaving again, to repur- chase 15 per cent of the amount surrendered (the cur- rencies so purchased may include French f rancs ). Moroccan workers abroad are entitled to a bonus of 5 per cent on the dirham equivalent of any foreign exchange repatriated in the form of transfers to a bank or a postal account. A supplementary premium is paid on such remittances by Moroccans working in France. The additional premium, called the "fidelity premium," is computed to assure beneficiaries a conversion rate of F 1 = DH 1. The importation of Moroccan bank- notes is prohibited. Nonresident travelers may freely bring in foreign banknotes; foreign currency imported in excess of the equivalent of DH 5,000 must, however, be declared to the customs authorities. Resident tra- velers also may bring in any amount in foreign bank- notes, but these must be surrendered within 30 days of re-entry. Capital Residents of Moroccan nationality, as well as com- panies established in Morocco, are obliged to declare to the Exchange Office all foreign-held assets exceeding DH 250, and to repatriate and surrender certain of these assets. The disposal of other foreign-held assets requires permission. The transfer of capital abroad by residents must be approved. Remittance of the assets 283 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO of emigrants and t rans fe rs in the fo rm of g i f ts are not normally approved, nor is investment by private ind i- viduals in foreign securities or real estate. Exchange allocations for the t ran s fer of inheritances are limited to DH 35,000 a beneficiary. Transfers of assets by persons returning to their own country vary with the length of their stay in Morocco, f rom DH 35,000 a fam i ly w i th fam i ly residence of 3 to 5 years to DH 250,000 a fam i ly where the period of residence has been 15 years or more. New foreign investments in specified sectors of the economy may benefit f rom the provisions of the Invest- ment Code of August 15, 1973. The Code provides various tax concessions and other incentives. It gua ran- tees the t ran s fer of dividends distributed to nonresidents and of proceeds from the liquidation of the capital brought in by the foreign investor. Investments financed with funds held in Capital Accounts (see below) also are eligible for the benefits of the Code; proceeds f rom the l iqu ida t ion of investments f inanced in this m a n n er become transferab le a f ter a m in imum inves tment period of 5 years. Foreign investments approved under the previous Inves tment Code (of February 10, 1961) continue to benefit f rom the re transfer guarantee for the liquidation proceeds. Proceeds f rom the liquidation of other invest- ments are credited to Capital Accounts. Operations through Capital Accounts that may be effected with approval include purchases on the Casa- blanca Stock Exchange of Moroccan and non-Moroccan securities; purchases of Moroccan securities not quoted on the Casablanca Stock Exchange or of participation in a Moroccan firm; subscriptions to either; investments of any k ind, including purchases of businesses or office buildings; l end ing to residents; payment of local ex- penses in excess of DH 5,000 dur ing the account holder's stay in Morocco; any such payments to bene- ficiaries other than the holder of the account or a close relative; any such payments f rom an account held by a fore ign jur id ical person; gifts to social, cultural, or religious institutions; subscriptions to capital increases of Moroccan companies whose shares are quoted on the Casablanca Stock Exchange; subscriptions at the time of issue to long-term or short-term fixed yield securities issued by a Moroccan public entity; custody charges and commissions on securities; and payment of the cost of maintenance, repairs, real estate taxes, and insurance on real estate located in Morocco. Subject to approval, Capital Accounts may also be debited for investments in Morocco, within the f ramewo rk of the 1973 Investment Code, provided that the amoun ts debited do not exceed 50 per cent of the investment unde r taken by the nonresident and 25 per cent of the company's total capital. Certain government bonds acquired with funds f rom Capital Accounts are freely negotiable between non- residents. These are 5.5 per cent, seven-year bonds on 284 which interest and redemption proceeds are transfer- able. All other transactions in securities involving non- resident interests, as well as the import and export of securities, require approval. Banks are permitted to engage in short-term borrow ing abroad; they may accept convertible currency funds f rom nonresidents for credit to Special Deposit Accounts, provided that these f u n ds are reinvested abroad in the same currency and for the same ma tur i ty period. The rate of interest paid by banks on these deposits may not exceed the rate received by them on their corresponding placements. Gold A commemo ra t ive gold coin w i th a face va lue of DH 250 has been issued, which is legal tender. Resi- dents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Morocco for num i sma t ic or investment purposes. Ten d i f fe rent types of foreign gold coins are traded on the Casablanca Stock Exchange, which does not, however, deal in gold bars. Not for Redistribution NEPAL (Position on December 31,1978) Exchange Rate System The currency of Nepal is the Nepalese Rupee, which is pegged to the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, at the rate of NRs 12.00 = US$1. On December 31, 1978 the official buying and selling rates were NRs 11.90 and NRs 12.10, respectively, per US$1. Nepal also quotes fixed rates for the Indian rupee, at NRs 145.00 buying and .NRs 145.15 selling, per 100 Indian rupees. Buying and selling rates are quoted daily for other cur- rencies,1 with quotations based on the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in markets abroad. Buying rates only are quoted for Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Italian lire, and Swedish kroner, based on buying rates for the U.S. dollar in markets abroad. A second official exchange rate is applied only to merchandise transactions, with certain specified exceptions, with coun- tries other than India. This rate is fixed at NRs 15.90 buying and NRs 16.10 selling, per US$1. Residents may freely purchase Indian rupees from Nepalese banks and they may hold any amount of Indian notes and coin, but the Indian rupee is not legal tender. Administration of Control Permission is required from the Ministry of Finance for all payments in convertible currency except for import payments and certain specified payments. Import and export licensing is the responsibility of the Ministry of Industry and Commerce. A supervisory committee composed of representatives from the Nepal Rastra Bank (the central bank), the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Industry and Commerce, the M in is try of Agriculture, and the National Planning Commission oversees the operation of the dual exchange rate system. All exchange transactions with countries other than India must be settled through authorized dealers, i.e., the Nepal Bank Ltd. and the Rastriya Ban i jya Bank. Within Nepal there are 105 additional authorized dealers licensed to pur- chase foreign currencies; any sale of such currencies other than Indian rupees is subject to the prior approval of the Nepal Rastra Bank. All import and export trans- actions with payments agreement countries,2 as well as all barter trade, are conducted through a state t rad ing agency, the National Trading Ltd. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements apply to outgoing payments to countries w i th which no payments agreement is in force and these may be made in foreign currency supplied by the Nepal Ras tra Bank. Payments to, and receipts from, other member countries of the Asian Clearing Union except India (Bangladesh, Burma, 1 Australian dollars, Canadian dollars, deutsche m a rk, French f rancs, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, and Swiss francs. 2 Nepal has bilateral payments agreements w i th Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, Poland, and U.S.S.R.; paymen ts between Nepal and these countries must be made th rough special accounts. An agreement with Pakistan is inoperative. 286 Iran, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka) in respect of current transactions (other than those relating to petroleum, natural gas, and their products) may, but need not, be effected in Asian monetary units through the Asian Clearing Union. Payments for imports from India nor- mally are settled in Indian rupees, but the Nepal Rastra Bank sometimes makes convertible currencies available for such imports at the recommendation of the Ministry of Finance. The proceeds of exports to India are obtained in Indian or Nepalese rupees; the proceeds of exports to other countries must be received in any of the convertible currencies quoted by the Nepal Rastra Bank. Nonresident Accounts The Nepal Rastra Bank permits nonresidents to open "convertible rupee accounts" with Nepalese banks; bal- ances on these accounts may be freely transferred abroad. Indian nationals are allowed to open current accounts in Indian rupees with Nepalese banks. Foreign currencies brought into or received in Nepal by nonresidents, which are converted into Nepalese rupees and deposited with a Nepalese bank, may be reconverted for transfer out of the country, subject to prior permission of the Nepal Rastra Bank. Imports and Import Payments Imports from India and imports of certain commodi- ties (cement, corrugated sheeting, hardware, industrial machinery and spare parts, and fertilizer) from countries other than India do not require import licenses. All other imports of goods require import licenses. Imports of vegetable oil, margarine, animal fa t, woolen carpets, arms and ammunition, explosives, chemicals to be used for explosives, and wireless transmitters require special permission of the Government. Imports of beef are banned. Under the Trade and Transit Treaties, Nepal and India agreed to freedom of trade between them- selves in Nepalese and Indian goods; Indian goods may in principle be imported freely (although some are subject to a permit system in order to prevent their re-exportation, and certain others are subject to export ceilings in India); reimbursement of tax is made by the Government of India to the Government of Nepal on direct imports from Indian manufac turers of commodi- ties subject to excise duty in India. Imports of certain commodities from countries other than India (e.g., stainless steel, wrist watches, synthetic yarn, radios, and pocket calculators) are restricted. Foreign tourists may bring in, without permission, goods, not exceeding NRs 10,000 in value, which are not otherwise restricted. Nepalese citizens returning af ter less than three months abroad, except to India, are allowed to import without permission goods valued up to NRs 5000. Nepalese citizens returning af ter an absence of between three months and one year may ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution import goods valued up to NRs 10,000 without permis- sion; the limit for citizens returning after more than one year abroad is NRs 15,000. Under the dual exchange rate system for merchandise transactions, a fixed depreciated selling rate of NRs 16.10 per US$1 is applied to all imports from countries other than India, except for exempted items (e.g., petroleum products, coal, fertilizer, raw cotton, cotton yarn, indus- trial chemicals, construction materials, and machinery). Exchange to pay for the exempted import items is pur- chased at the official selling rate of NRs 12.10 per US$1.3 Most government imports are effected through state trading agencies, mainly the National Trading Ltd. and the Agricultural Input Corporation. All imports settled through the banking system must be made on a letter of credit basis; only imports from India may be settled outside the banking system. Certain imports from all sources are subject to import surcharges. Payments for Invisibles Payments to India may be made freely in Indian rupees, but for amounts of Rs 500 or over the purpose of the payment must be indicated. All payments for freight and insurance are made at the official exchange rate. For travel to countries other than India for medical treatment, foreign exchange is allowed as recommended by a panel of doctors; students studying at their own expense in these countries are allowed up to US$2,160 a year for board and lodging, while payments for tuition fees are allowed as required. Payments for other invisi- bles depend on the essentiality of the transaction and the availability of foreign exchange. Nepalese and Indian currencies may be taken out freely to India but only by Nepalese and Indian nationals; the export of these cur- rencies to countries other than India is prohibited. Foreign banknotes, other than Indian banknotes, may not be taken out by residents without permission. Non- residents may take out the unchanged amount of any foreign banknotes they brought in; however, nonresi- dents, other than Indian nationals, may not take out Nepalese or Indian banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of old coins, gold and silver, and coin and jewelry made of these metals, wild buffaloes, monkeys, pandas, musk deer, and rhinoceros are prohibited. The re-export to India of non-N£palese goods is not per- mitted, and re-export to any destination of goods im- ported from India is prohibited. All other goods, except rice, may be exported freely to India. All exports to other destinations except handicrafts, woolen goods other than carpets, and jute bags, require export licenses. Eight regional paddy and rice export companies and the Nepal Food Corporation have a monopoly over exports of paddy and rice, and the latter has a monopoly over exports of lentil seeds. 8 Debt service payments on foreign credits associated with imports are transacted at the rate applicable to the merchandise. NEPAL The exchange proceeds from exports, except Indian rupees, must be surrendered to the Nepal Rastra Bank or to an authorized bank within six months of the date when the goods crossed the customs frontier. As part of the dual exchange rate system, exports to countries other than India are transacted at the depreciated official buying rate of NRs 15.90 per US$1. An export valuation committee determines for each commodity the maximum unit value that can appear on an application for the depreciated exchange rate. Un it values are defined on an f.o.b. Nepal basis. Foreign exchange surrendered in excess of earnings calculated on this basis is not eligible for the depreciated exchange rate. Nepalese citizens going abroad may take out unre- stricted goods worth up to NRs 10,000 without authori- zation; otherwise an export license is required. Proceeds from invisibles With the exception of Indian rupees, foreign exchange proceeds derived from transactions in invisibles must be surrendered to the Nepal Rastra Bank or an authorized bank at the official rate of exchange. Nepalese and Indian currency may be brought in from India only, and by Nepalese and Indian nationals only; the import of these currencies from countries other than India is prohibited. When extending their visas, tourists are required to produce evidence that they have converted a m in imum of US$5 at the official rate of exchange for each day's stay. Nonresidents other than Indian nationals are not allowed to bring in Nepalese or Indian bank- notes. Other foreign banknotes may be brought in freely by residents and nonresidents, but residents and Indian nationals must declare any foreign banknotes they bring in. Capital No conditions are specified concerning receipts and remittances in respect of capital transactions, but official exchange is not normally provided for capital remit- tances by Nepalese nationals. Nepalese citizens, whether resident in Nepal or not, are prohibited from making any type of investment in foreign countries, except investment specifically exempted by government notice; the exemptions include the purchase and sale of insur- ance policies abroad, investments abroad by any banking or financial institution incorporated in Nepal, and the purchase of shares of foreign companies under a rights issue. The Industrial Enterprise Act, 1974 provides certain incentives for foreign investment in Nepal. Foreign investors who obtain an investment guarantee may remit yearly profits of up to 25 per cent on the foreign capital invested and, in any one year, up to 10 per cent of the principal; if the exchange situation permits, profits in excess of 25 per cent are remittable. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Nepal. Imports of gold from any country 287 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NEPAL other than India require a license and are subject to an import duty of NRs 6.65 a troy ounce; such imports are not normally allowed. Exports of gold may be made only by the monetary authorities and require prior approval by the Ministry of Finance. Domestic dealings in gold do not require a license but are subject to a sales tax of 12 per cent. Changes during 1978 February 2. Excise duties levied by India on diesel, kerosene, and other petroleum products exported to Nepal under the special petroleum products exchange arrangement were waived. The Nepalese Government imposed customs duties on petroleum products equiva- lent to those waived by India. February 28. The Nepal Food Corporation was granted a monopoly over the export of lentil seeds. March 17. Nepal and India signed separate treaties on trade and transit, and an agreement to control unauthorized trade. The trade treaty prohibited the re-export to India of non-Nepalese goods and the re- export to any destination of goods imported from India. Tariff concessions were granted by India for manufac- tured goods. Manufactured goods containing at least 80 per cent Nepalese and Indian value-added were exempted from duty; where value-added was less than 80 per cent but more than 50 per cent, the maximum tariff rate would be 50 per cent of the most-favored- nation rate; the most-favored-nation rate would be applied to manufactured goods with a combined Nepalese and Indian value-added of less than 50 per cent. The transit treaty stipulated the points of entry and exit for goods in transit through India and the proce- dures for transshipment, storage, and inspection. The Agreement to Control Unauthorized Trade committed both Governments to prevent the infringement of the laws, rules, and regulations of the other country relating to customs, foreign exchange, and foreign trade. The trade treaty and the agreements to control unauthorized trade would be effective for five years. The transit treaty would be operative for seven years. March 22. The official rates for the U.S. dollar were adjusted from NRs 12.45 buying and NRs 12.55 selling, per US$1 to NRs 11.90 buying and NRs 12.10 selling, per US$1. Also, the official rates for the Indian rupee were adjusted from NRs 139.00 buying and NRs 139.15 selling, per 100 Indian rupees to NRs 145.00 buying and NRs 145.15 selling, per 100 Indian rupees. March 30. With effect from March 31, both the Exporters' Exchange Entitlement Scheme and the pro- portionality requirement on imports were abolished and were replaced by a dual exchange rate system. All transactions with India and all transfers, capital trans- actions, and transactions in invisibles with countries other than India, except certain debt service payments on foreign credits associated with merchandise trade, would be transacted at the existing exchange rates. A fixed 288 depreciated second rate of NRs 15.90 buying and NRs 16.10 selling, per US$1, would be applied to all merchandise trade with countries other than India, except for exempted import items (e.g., petroleum prod- ucts, coal, fertilizer, raw cotton, cotton yarn, industrial chemicals, construction materials, and machinery); the depreciated rate would also be applied to the debt service payments mentioned above. Markups used in the assessments of sales taxes were raised and the valua- tion base was changed from c.i.f. Calcutta, to c.i.f. Nepal border, for all imports f rom countries other than India. Licensing for all permitted exports to, and im- ports from, third countries was made automatic, and un i fo rm treatment in gran t ing licenses would be accorded to the public and private sectors except that (1) export licenses for rice and pulses would be issued only to public corporations and (2) imports of specified commodi- ties (e.g., stainless steel, synthetic yarn, wrist watches, radios, and pocket calculators) would be restricted. April 6. An additional duty of 6 per cent was imposed on the export of raw ju te and ju te cuttings with effect from March 30, 1978. April 8. Customs duties and sales taxes on imports of cement were waived for the fiscal year 1978/79. April 21. Restrictions were imposed on the import of biris, cigarettes, matches, opium, morphia, and l iquor containing 60 per cent alcohol. April 29. The Government restricted the export of articles of archeological importance, unprocessed leather, raw wool, and scrap of brass, copper, and bronze, and utensils made of those materials. The export of wild buffaloes, monkeys, pandas, musk deer, rhinoceros and other wild animals was prohibited. May 24. The Export Valuation Study Committee changed the valuation base for imports from c.i.f. Calcutta to f.o.b. Nepal. The 15 per cent margin above the max imum unit price set by the Committee was abol- ished, but it was announced that maximum prices set by the Committee would be adequate to permit price varia- tion in individual contracts. August 19. Nepalese citizens traveling abroad might take out, without permission, unrestricted goods worth up to NRs 10,000. Foreign tourists might bring in, without permission, goods not otherwise restricted up to a value of NRs 10,000. Nepalese citizens returning after less than three months abroad, except to India, would be allowed to import without permission, goods valued up to NRs 5,000. Nepalese citizens returning after an absence of between three months and one year might import goods valued up to NRs 10,000 without permis- sion, and for those returning after more than one year the limit would be NRs 15,000. September 4. India provided transit facilities through Radhikapur for Nepal's trade with Bangladesh and other countries. November 21. The import without license of turmeric powder from India was restricted. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS (Position on December 31,1978) Exchange Rate System The currency of the Netherlands is the Netherlands Guilder. The Netherlands participates with Belgium, Denmark, the Federal Republic of Germany, and Luxem- bourg in the European common margins arrangement (the snake), which is a multicurrency intervention sys- tem.1 In accordance with this arrangement, the Nether- lands maintains the spot exchange rates of the cur- rencies of the other participants within margins of 2.25 per cent above or below the cross rates based on the central rates applied in the arrangement. The arrangement implies that the Netherlands Bank (the central bank) stands ready to buy or sell the cur- rencies of the other participating states in unlimited amounts at specified intervention rates. On Decem- ber 29, 1978 these rates were: Specified Intervention 0 .* , T * .- Rates Per; Netherlands Guilders Upper limit Lower limit 100 Belgian francs or Luxembourg francs 100 Danish kroner 100 deutsche mark 7.0520 6.7420 39.270 37.5425 110.835 105.960 The participants in the snake are not maintaining exchange rates for other currencies within fixed limits. However, in order to ensure a proper functioning of the arrangement they intervene in concert to smooth out fluctuations in exchange rates, the principal intervention currencies being each other's and the U.S. dollar. The authorized banks quote buying and selling rates for 13 foreign currencies.2 On December 29, 1978, the authorized banks' buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were f. 1.96775 and f. 1.97025, respectively, per US$1. There are no taxes or subsidies on pur- chases or sales of foreign exchange. Authorized banks are freely permitted to buy and sell convertible and inconvertible currencies, both spot and forward, against convertible currencies, including depos- its in nonresident guilder accounts, and inconvertible currencies; they are free to deal with residents and nonresidents, whether banks or nonbanks. Forward exchange contracts are not limited as to delivery period nor is an underlying transaction required. Residents are free to conclude spot transactions with other residents, including authorized banks, and they may conclude forward transactions with authorized banks for any period. The intermediation of authorized banks is not obligatory in those forward currency transactions in iW i th effect from March 13, 1979 the Netherlands participates in the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System. 2 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. (With effect from March 13, 1979 rates for the Irish pound are also quoted.) which the guilder is not involved. Nonbank residents are free to hold foreign currency accounts at home and are permitted to hold accounts in their own names with banks abroad; overdrafts on the latter accounts nor- mally are not allowed in excess of f. 300,000 a year. The Kingdom of the Netherlands formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Exchange Control Territory Transactions with the Netherlands Antilles are subject to the same exchange controls as transactions with other countries. Vis-a-vis any third countries with which pay- ments agreements might be in force, the Netherlands and the Netherlands Antilles will, if so stipulated, con- stitute the Netherlands Monetary Area. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Netherlands Bank on behalf of the Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Finance, Economic Affairs, and Agriculture. Import and export licensing are handled by the Central Import- Export Agency (CDIU) and the delegated offices, under directives from the Directorate-General for Foreign Economic Relations. Capital transactions are licensed by the Netherlands Bank; transit trade transactions in strategic goods and scrap are licensed by the CDIU.3 Commercial banks are authorized to handle exchange transactions within the scope of general and special licenses granted by the licensing authorities. For all current payments to, or receipts f rom, nonresidents exceeding f. 3,000, and for all capital payments or receipts, nonbank residents as well as nonauthorized banks are required to indicate, on an exchange control form, the nature of the underlying transaction as well as the currency and amount paid or received. Separate regulations govern the reporting of settlements where no transfer of money is involved. Prescription of Currency In effecting payments to nonresidents or collecting receipts from them, residents may make use of guilders or any foreign currency. If such payments are made from, or are received in, the Netherlands they must use the intermediation of authorized banks or of other domestic institutions or persons designated by the Nether- lands Bank. Residents are free, however, to open and maintain bank accounts abroad, to which receipts may be credited and payments debited; in that case, they must notify the Netherlands Bank, and receipts and payments are to be reported to the Bank in accordance with the relative regulations. 3 The only transit trade transactions still subject to specific license are purchases and sales of strategic goods and, within the EEC, of scrap. Transit trade (merchanting) involving Rhodesia is prohibited. 289 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS There are specific regulations for payments in respect of certain direct imports from Egypt.4 All payments and credits, whether direct or indirect, f rom the Nether- lands to Rhodesia are prohibited unless a license is granted by the Netherlands Bank. Payments in any foreign currency between residents may be made freely. There are no bilateral payments agreements in force. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents are free to open and ma in ta in nonresi- dent accounts with authorized banks in the Netherlands in guilders or any foreign currency, and to e f fect pay- ments to, or collect receipts f rom, residents. All cu r rent payments or receipts are freely perm i t ted, as well as transfers of balances to and from other nonres ident accounts. A number of capital payments or receipts, however, are subject to license f rom the Netherlands Bank (see section on Capital below). Nonresident accounts held by residents of Rhodesia are of two kinds: R Accounts for payments w i th in the Netherlands, some of which are permitted under general license, and Special Accounts through which external payments must be made, subject to special licenses (which are granted only for the exceptional cases referred to in the relevant UN Resolution). Imports and Import Payments Imports from the Belgian-Luxembourg Economic Union are free from import licenses. All imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Import licenses are required for imports originating in Hong Kong, Japan, and state trading countries, and for the import of goods of unknown origin. In addition, import licenses are required for a limited number of products, ma in ly in the agricultural, steel, and textile sectors, when not of EEC origin. Except for imports of textiles o r ig ina t ing in the Far East and in state trad ing countries, practically all imports that require an import license are free from quantitative restriction. Most impo r ts from Eastern European countries are formally liberalized. Imports from non-EEC countries of most products covered by the Common Agricultural Policy of the EEC are subject to import levies that have replaced all previ- ous barriers to imports; common EEC regu la t ions are also applied to imports f rom non-EEC countries of most other agricultural and livestock products. Payments for imports may be made freely, provided that the method of payment conforms to the relative exchange control regulations. Residents may freely grant credit in respect of imports of commodities, but they require prior approval f rom the Netherlands Bank to accept credit for periods in excess of those that are customary in the trade concerned. * Fifty per cent of these payments are used to settle Netherlands claims outstanding under the indemnity agreement with Egypt. 290 Payments for Invisibles Payments abroad for invisibles are permitted freely. Residents may take out any amount in foreign and domestic banknotes and coin or documents of value for travel purposes; these may be used for traveling expenses abroad as well as for purchases for which payment in cash is customary in the trade concerned. Payments for interest, dividends, and contractual amortization due to nonresidents are permitted freely by crediting the appro- priate nonresident account. Nonresidents may export all unutilized documents of value for travel purposes as well as foreign and Nether- lands banknotes and coin which they have imported or have obtained in the Netherlands by drawing on their accounts or by exchanging other currencies. Exports and Export Proceeds Virtually all exports to Rhodesia are prohibited; those which are permitted require an export license. For exports to other countries, export licenses are requ ired for only a few commodities, mostly of a strategic char- acter, and for some agricultural products, iron and steel scrap, and certain nonferrous metals. Residents may freely grant credit in respect of exports of commodities, but they require prior permission from the Netherlands Bank to accept payment in advance of delivery in excess of the customary practice in the trade concerned. The surrender of export proceeds is not obligatory. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no requirements attached to receipts by residents from current invisibles. Nonresidents may bring into the Netherlands for travel purposes any amounts in Netherlands or foreign banknotes and docu- ments of value; these may be used for traveling expenses in the Netherlands as well as for purchases for which payment in cash is customary in the trade concerned. Capital Most external capital transactions are free. The main capital transactions of nonbank residents still subject to case-by-case review are (1) financial borrowing from nonresidents exceeding f. 300,000 a year; (2) the issue of interest-bearing domestic securities, and the sale of such unlisted securities, to nonresidents; (3) lending to nonresidents exceeding f. 10 million a year to the same nonresident; and (4) the acquisition of unlisted foreign securities bearing interest in guilders. The inward transfer of capital originating from short- term and medium-term borrowing abroad by nonbank residents continues to be restricted for reasons of mone- tary policy. Long-term borrowing abroad for domestic use by resident enterprises is generally permitted upon application if the loans meet the following conditions: (1) the period between the conclusion of the contract and the maturity date of the last repayment shall be at least ten years; (2) repayment shall be effected by ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution means of at least five equal annual or at least ten equal semiannual installments, whether or not preceded by a repayment-free period; (3) repayment before the dates provided for in the contract is precluded; (4) the rate of interest shall be fixed on conclusion of the contract for the full period to maturity, no periodic adjustment to prevailing market conditions being allowed; and (5) to the extent that the long-term private loan is denominated in guilders, the issue of bearer debt certi- ficates shall not be allowed. Once permission has been granted for such loans, permission to give guarantees and other security to nonresident lenders will also be granted. Apart from this, the inward transfer of foreign capital (other than for portfolio investment in listed securities or the purchase of real estate, see below) is in general permitted only if the capital constitutes a direct invest- ment. In addition to foreign participation in the capital of companies, direct investment is considered to include intercompany financial loans with a fixed term of at least five years from the foreign parent company. Under certain conditions loans from other affiliated foreign companies are also being licensed. The regulations on long-term foreign financial borrowing provide that the proceeds of loans that meet certain conditions, mainly regarding maturities, may be employed in the Nether- lands as well as abroad. If employed abroad, such proceeds may be used either for investment abroad (which is considered to include purchases of ships and aircraft) or for repayment of foreign credits raised earlier under an exchange control permission. How- ever, companies working on the Netherlands sector of the continental shelf, whether foreign owned or resident owned, are allowed to take up foreign credits (with a fixed term of at least five years) to the full extent of their financing requirements. Resident un i ts of international companies are free to maintain current accounts with their head offices or subsidiaries abroad for the purpose of intercompany settlements; changes in the accounts are to be reported to the Netherlands Bank in accordance with the relative regulations. Short- term foreign bank credit for the financing of imports is licensed if it is directly connected with a specific import transaction; for long-term financing, importers are referred to the domestic credit market. Sales to nonresidents, including central banks, of Netherlands treasury paper and bank acceptances denominated in guilders are prohibited. Lending by nonbank residents to nonresidents (whether affiliated companies or others) is free up to f. 10 million a year to the same nonresident; larger amounts are normally permitted on application. Public issues on the domestic capital market on behalf of nonresidents are scheduled, and if necessary limited, by the Netherlands Bank in accordance with the market's capacity to absorb issues. In the private placement sector of the capital market (the market for debt certificates or onderhandse NETHERLANDS leningen), institutional investors are liberally permitted to extend loans to nonresidents. The maximum size of each loan is set at f. 75 million and the minimum maturity at ten years, with repayment to take place in at least five equal installments. The lenders are to deliver in foreign currency. A queue system with an issue calendar for nonresident borrowers is used to ensure an orderly market. Participation by residents in the capital of companies abroad is free. The inward or outward transfer of proceeds from the sale or liqui- dation of direct investments is free. Repayment of licensed loans may be made or received freely, provided that any relevant stipulations in the license are complied with. Transactions between residents and nonresidents in all stocks and bonds listed on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange take place at official market exchange rates and are unrestricted. Residents may freely purchase officially listed securities abroad. Transactions between residents and nonresidents in unlisted stocks are free. However, residents are not allowed to purchase unlisted fixed-interest securities (such as notes) on the Euromarket denominated in guilders and issued by nonresidents. Nonbank residents are licensed to issue bonds and notes abroad only if the proceeds are not brought into the Netherlands, unless they comply with the conditions regarding long-term foreign borrowing for domestic use by resident enterprises (see above). The proceeds of securities sold in the Netherlands by nonresidents (except Rhodesian nationals) are transferable in any cur- rency, irrespective of the seller's country of domicile or residence. Nonresidents may have their securities, domes- tic or foreign, exported to them; securities held in the Netherlands are not subject to deposit. Nonresidents may freely purchase real estate in the Netherlands for personal use or investment, and resi- dents may freely purchase real estate abroad. Exten- sion of payments within the framework of such trans- actions is also freely permitted. Residents, when purchasing real estate abroad, may borrow on mortgage from a nonresident an amount not exceeding the purchase amount. Previously acquired foreign real estate may be mortgaged for a loan (provided the amount of the mortgage does not exceed the value of the real estate). Subject to certain conditions, residents may also incur a debt toward a nonresident, on the security of a mortgage, for the purchase amount of real estate situated in the Netherlands. Gifts and donations to nonresidents are free.5 Emi- grants may export any amount in foreign and domestic currency. They acquire nonresident status upon leaving the Netherlands and may upon departure have remitted to them their total assets in the Netherlands. Non- residents inheriting from estates in the Netherlands may have the proceeds transferred to them freely. 5 Charitable gifts and donations for religious purposes are included in the Netherlands definition of current payments. 291 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS The curtailment of external borrowing is also applied to the authorized banks. Any net foreign indebtedness on their part is restricted by the "five million regulation," which prescribes that the total of each bank's spot fore ign liabilities (regardless of denomination or maturity) must not at any time exceed its total spot foreign assets by more than f. 5 million. Banks are required to report to the Netherlands Bank twice a month the totals of their spot assets and liabilities, broken down into guilders and all foreign currencies combined. In addition, banks are encouraged to maintain a balanced total position (i.e., spot plus forward position) in each fore ign currency. They are required to report their spot position, as well as their forward position with residents and nonresidents, respectively, in each foreign currency at the end of each month; for deutsche mark, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars, the same da ta must also be reported at mid-month. Moreover, copies of all fo rwa rd exchange contracts with nonresidents are fo rwa rded to the Nether- lands Bank. Banks are free to lend to fore ign banks and, for maturities up to one year, to fore ign nonbanks; longer-term lending is permitted under general license. Banks are free to pay customary rates of interest on nonresident-held guilder demand deposits, and to estab- lish guilder time or savings deposits on their books in the names of nonresidents. Thus, their freedom to accept deposits from nonresidents (including foreign cur- rency demand or time deposits) and to borrow abroad is unrestricted, provided the limit set by the "five million regulation" is observed. All capital transfers by nonbank residents, whe ther free or permitted under license, must be notified to the Balance of Payments Department of the Netherlands Bank. This includes suppliers' credits granted or received for periods in excess of one year; prepayments exceed- ing f. 250,000 received for exports must be reported as such. Totals of security transactions must be reported periodically by securities brokers and authorized banks or, if transactions take place through a foreign bank account, by the resident parties concerned. Gold The Netherlands Bank engages in gold transactions only with monetary authorities and international finan- cial institutions. Neither the Bank nor any government agency imports or markets gold for industrial use. Authorized banks and nonbank residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold (fine gold, gold coin, and gold alloys) in the Netherlands or abroad. Imports and exports of gold do not require exchange licenses or import and export licenses. There is a free gold market in Amsterdam. Domestic sales of gold coin, if legal tender in the coun try of issue, are free of value-added tax; those that are not legal tender are subject to value- added tax at 4 per cent. The value-added tax on medallions and commemorative coins is 18 per cent.6 Commercial imports of gold jewelry and of articles containing minor quantities of gold, such as watches, require import licenses only when originating in Hong Kong, Japan, or state trading countries. Changes during 1978 August 1. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS ANTILLES1 (Position on December 31,1978) Exchange Rate System The currency of the Netherlands Antilles is the Neth- erlands Antilles Guilder which is pegged to the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, at Ant. f. 1.7900 = US$1. The official buying rates for the U.S. dollar on December 29, 1978 were Ant. f. 1.77 per US$1 for banknotes and Ant. f. 1.79 per US$1 for drafts, checks, and transfers. The official selling rate was Ant. f. 1.81 per US$1. The Bank of Netherlands Antilles (the cen- tral bank) deals with commercial banks at interbank rates; it does not normally deal with the public. Official buying and selling rates for certain other currencies2 are set daily on the basis of rates for the U.S. dollar abroad. There is an exchange tax of 0.80 per cent on sales of foreign exchange.3 Commercial banks require the approval of the central bank to invest or hold foreign currency balances,4 but authorized banks have been granted general permissions for these purposes. Administration of Control Exchange licenses, where required, are issued by the central bank. Import licenses are issued by the Depart- ment of Economic Affairs. The commercial banks are permitted by the central bank to provide foreign exchange for most current transactions without prior approval. The central bank may grant exemption f rom the obligation of surrendering foreign exchange, insofar as the assets or moneys concerned were acquired from nonresidents as principals; the foreign exchange may then be held or used freely until further notice. Prescription of Currency Payments may be made in any currency except Netherlands Antilles guilders. Receipts may be accepted in any convertible currency except Netherlands Antilles guilders. For statistical purposes, all payments made by residents through the authorized banks in foreign exchange, as well as all receipts through the authorized banks, must be reported to the central bank. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents may freely open nonresident accounts in any foreign currency. Nonresidents (including foreign investment funds, etc., with nonresident status) are per- iThe Netherlands Antilles is a nonmetropolitan territory in respect of which the Kingdom of the Netherlands has accepted the Fund's Articles of Agreement. 2 Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Suriname guilders, Swiss francs, and Venezuelan bolivares. 3 Purchases of foreign exchange by resident companies with nonresi- dent status for exchange control purposes are exempt from the exchange tax. 4 All currencies other than the Netherlands Antilles guilder are con- sidered foreign currencies. mitted to hold nonresident accounts in Netherlands Antilles guilders only if the authorized bank concerned considers that they have certain interests in the Nether- lands Antilles which render such an account desirable; balances in such accounts may not exceed Ant. f. 10,000 without central bank approval. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain items, such as narcotics and explo- sives, are subject to license for reasons of public policy. Imports of a number of commodities, including edible oils and certain domestic appliances into Aruba, Bonaire, and Curasao are subject to licensing by the Department of Economic Affa irs, while commercial imports of pas- senger automobiles built prior to the production year November 1, 1975-October 31, 1976 are prohibited. Payments for permitted imports may be made freely. Companies with nonresident status normally finance their imports with their own foreign exchange. Certain commodities are subject to import surcharges in Aruba, Bonaire, and Curasao. Payments for Invisibles Payments for current invisibles are not restricted. For most types of current invisibles remittances may be made freely through the authorized banks. Licenses are required mainly for the purchase of travel exchange in excess of Ant. f. 180 a person for each day to be spent abroad and for certain personal remittances in excess of Ant. f. 5,000 for each transaction or in excess of Ant. f. 25,000 a person a year. Such licenses are freely granted when no capital transfer seems to be involved. Nonresidents may take with them on departure any fore ign currency which they brought in on arrival. The export of Netherlands Antilles banknotes is limited to Ant. f. 200 a person. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports require licenses, which usually are granted. Exchange proceeds must be surrendered to an authorized bank within six months of shipment, with the exception of export proceeds received by companies with nonresi- dent status. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts f rom invisibles (except those of firms with nonresident status) must in principle be surrendered to an authorized bank within eight days of receipt, but in practice the public is allowed to hold foreign banknotes and coin, since the domestic currency and the U.S. dollar circulate concurrently. Travelers may bring in with them any amount of checks, travelers 293 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS ANTILLES checks, or banknotes denominated in foreign currency. Each traveler may also bring in Ant. f. 200 in Nether- lands Antilles banknotes. Capital Foreign investment in the Netherlands Antilles requires a license, which is, in general, granted if the investment is in the economic and social interest of the islands; the Investment Incentives Program, as amended, provides for duty-free entry of many commodities as well as tax facilities. New industrial companies pri- marily engaged in exporting may be granted nonresident status by the central bank, which confers on the company concerned exemption from exchange control (except in its transactions with residents), including exemption f rom the requirement of surrendering their foreign cur- rency receipts. Such exemption may also be granted to companies concerned with investment, patent holding, shipping, and insurance. Outward flows of resident-owned capital are subject to control, and certain capital transactions by or on behalf of residents are restricted. Life insurance con- tracts in foreign currency between residents and foreign insurance companies for a m in imum term of ten years are licensed up to an amount which is fixed annually, depending on the foreign exchange position, but outward transfers of capital by l ife insurance companies are not restricted; contracts expressed in domestic currency are freely permitted in any amount by v ir tue of general per- missions granted to individual foreign insurers. Invest- ment by residents in real estate situated abroad requires a license but this is normally given freely. Investment in officially listed foreign securities (i.e., securities issued outside the Netherlands Antilles or payable or optionally payable in the currency of a country other than the Netherlands Antilles) is freely allowed by a general permission provided the securities are registered abroad in the name of an authorized bank and provided foreign payments are channeled through authorized banks; purchases of mutual fund shares are prohibited. Authorized banks may freely borrow foreign currency abroad f rom nonresidents (including residents with non- resident s ta tus), or accept foreign currency deposits from nonresidents, for relending to nonresidents or redeposit abroad; their borrowing from nonresidents for relending to residents is restricted for monetary policy reasons and banks require central bank approval to incur a net foreign liability position. Nonresidents are not normally permitted to acquire balances in Netherlands Antilles guilders. Local borrowing in domestic currency by non- residents ( inc lud ing resident companies regarded as nonresidents for exchange control purposes) is restricted. Gold There are three commemorative gold coins each o f, which is legal tender, the Ant. f. 200 (1976) Bicenten- n ia l, the Ant. f. 200 (1977) Peter Stuyvesant, and the An t. f. 100 ( 1 9 7 9 ), commemorating the 150th anniver- sary of the central bank. Residents may hold and acqu ire gold coins in the Netherlands Antilles for num isma t ic and investment purposes; authorized banks may free ly negotiate gold coin among themselves and with other residents. Residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed without special permission to hold or acquire gold in any fo rm other than jewelry or coin, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the central bank; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports of coin by authorized banks, and for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Not for Redistribution NEW ZEALAND (Position on December 31, 1978) Exchange Rate System The currency of New Zealand is the New Zealand Dollar. Exchange rates are computed from the value of the New Zealand dollar, which is determined on the basis of the fixed relationship between the New Zealand dollar and a basket of currencies representing New Zealand's main trading partners. The currencies included in the basket and their weights are established in accord- ance with their proportionate share of New Zealand's total current overseas receipts and payments; the weights are adjusted quarterly. The exchange rate of the New Zealand dollar for the U.S. dollar, the intervention cur- rency, is fixed daily on the basis of the average weighted variations in quotations for the U.S. dollar in relation to the other currencies included in the basket. The outer limits for the telegraphic transfer buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar on December 29, 1978 were $NZ 0.9332 and $NZ 0.9420, respectively, per US$1. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. The trading banks are permitted to conclude with their customers forward exchange contracts for up to 12 months to cover both import and export transactions but can do so only within ten bank ing days of the exchange risk arising. Cover is not available for goods imported on consignment and nonresidents are not per- mitted to obtain forward exchange cover. Forward transactions in Canadian dollars and pounds sterling take place at rates of exchange determined daily by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand and are based on the closing forward quotations in overseas markets on the previous day. Forward exchange contracts in U.S. dollars are concluded at the relative spot rates adjusted by US$0.0050 a month on the selling side but unadjusted on the buying side. The Reserve Bank provides a facility whereby trading banks may obtain day-to-day cover for their net positions in Canadian dollars, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars, spot and forward. Contracts in other currencies may be covered through the London or New York foreign exchange markets, against sterling or U.S. dollars.1 Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Reserve Bank. The Reserve Bank has given discretionary author- ity to the trading banks to approve applications for certain remittances of funds overseas. The Overseas Investment Commission administers the regulations gov- 1 On February 1, 1979 the Reserve Bank facility under which trading banks might settle their net positions in spot and fo rwa rd sterling and Canadian dollars was w i thdrawn. At the same time the Reserve Bank ceased to determine the outer limit spot and fo rwa rd rates for all currencies except the U.S. dollar. erning foreign direct investment in New Zealand. Export and import licensing is the responsibility of the Customs Department and the Department of Trade and Industry, respectively. Prescription of Currency Payments to and from residents of countries other than New Zealand may be made or received in any foreign currency.2 Payment to and from accounts denominated in New Zealand currency held with banks in New Zealand by banks not domiciled in New Zealand or Rhodesia, also is an acceptable form of payment. Nonresident Accounts The Reserve Bank supervises certain specified accounts in New Zealand of residents of other countries ("con- trolled accounts"). The accounts in New Zealand dollars of overseas banks may be used for the settlement of transactions with other countries, but they may only be funded f rom overseas or by amounts which would otherwise be remittable f rom New Zealand. Imports and Import Payments Imports are controlled through an annual Import Licensing Schedule. The import categories included in the schedule are as follows: Category "E" (exempt) covers virtually all primary products (other than whea t), most raw materials and components of a type not pro- duced in New Zealand (e.g., base chemicals and fertil- izers), and a range of consumer goods and machinery. Goods in this category are exempt from licensing, as are, in addition, certain imports of Australian origin, irre- spective of the licensing category to which they belong.3 On a value basis, more than 70 per cent of all private imports are exempt f rom licensing. The "Basic" cate- gory comprises items for which licenses are granted by reference to either the amount of licenses issued or the actual value of imports in a previous licensing period. Goods covered by this category include tires, paper products, and a range of materials for use in manufac- ture. The "C" category covers a wide range of com- modities, including most manufac tures, e.g., machinery and appliances, aircraft, ships, and motor vehicles. Category "C" licenses are granted on an individual basis on such criteria as need, availability of domestic alterna- tives, and price; for some "C" items, however, there is an initial allocation until July of each year, based on a previous period, while applications for further licenses 2 Foreign currencies are defined as all currencies other than New Zealand cu r rency. 3 Under the terms of the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agree- ment that came into force on Janua ry 1, 1966. 295 ©International Monetary Fund. "Administrative basic licenses" are issued auto- matically to ensure con t inu i ty of importation for certain regularly required goods in the "C" category that correspond to only part of an item code, for example, spare parts. All licenses issued may be used for imports from any source except Rhodesia. Imports f rom Rhodesia require the consent of the Minister of Foreign Affa irs. A degree of flexibility in the application of the Licensing Schedule is achieved through the use of Group Schemes ( for Industry and Interchangeability Groups) that enable importers to transfer ind iv idual entitlements to a com- posite license instead of holding licenses for separate items, and to import, up to the total amount, any item or combination of items in the group. "No-remittance licenses" for imports outside the Import Licensing Schedule may be issued in special circumstances, viz., for advertising material supplied free of charge; gifts, passengers' baggage, replacement of fau l ty or damaged goods; t rade samples supplied free of charge; and temporary imports. The trading banks have authority to make foreign exchange available for payments in respect of all licensed imports and all imports that do not requ ire a license. Payments for Invisibles The trading banks are permitted to sell exchange for overseas payments up to established limits for many categories of invisibles, subject in appropriate cases, to the submission of supporting documents. Payments beyond the established limits, and for categories not included in the commercial banks' permitted list, require the specific approval of the Reserve Bank. Banks are authorized to sell foreign exchange for genuine foreign travel purposes without prior reference to the Reserve Bank up to $NZ 1,000 a person a month or part thereof, with a max imum of $NZ 4,000 a person in any 12-month period. Requests for amoun ts in excess of $NZ 1,000 a month or for a total of more than $NZ 4,000 in any 12-month period must be referred to the Reserve Bank. Larger amounts of exchange for any type of travel are authorized at the discretion of the Reserve Bank, which meets all reasonable requests for genuine travel purposes. In addition to the above alloca- tions, banks in New Zealand and their branches or agents in London and Australia may sell foreign curren- cies, without limit as to amoun t, to New Zealand trav- elers against privately held foreign funds. A 10 per cent travel tax is payable on all tickets supplied in New Zealand for overseas travel, except for travel to certain Pacific islands. This tax is administered by the Customs Department. The remittance abroad of dividends, interest, and profits due to nonresidents is approved, subject to formal 296 au then t ica t ion; for d iv idends and interest, the approval au tho r i ty up to $NZ 1,500 in any 12-month period to any one recipient has been delegated to the authorized banks. Exports of beef and veal to the United States and cheddar-type cheese to the United Kingdom are subject to annual quantitative restraint. Capital With the exception of capital issues outside New Zealand and overseas borrowings, consents are not required in respect of capital receipts. While overseas borrowing by financial institutions is controlled, consents are usually granted where the funds are required for industrial development purposes. To be eligible for repatriation, capital must have been transferred to New Zealand through normal banking channels or in some other way approved by the authorities, e.g., as imports of plant or machinery. Capital so transferred, including capital gains and capitalized profits, may be repatriated, after the formal approval of the Reserve Bank has been obtained. In the case of overseas borrowing, repayments are not normally permitted until the expiry of the term for which the funds were borrowed. Overseas companies seeking to establish themselves in New Zealand must obtain the approval of the Overseas Investment Commission. Capital issues outside New Zealand by companies incorporated in New Zealand require the approval of the Overseas Investment Commission; overseas borrowing by such companies also requires prior approval. New Zealand subsidiaries and branches of overseas companies must obtain the consent of the Overseas Investment Commission if they wish to borrow in New Zealand, whether for long-term or short-term finance. Local borrowing by companies which are 50 per cent or more overseas owned is normally restricted to 10 per cent of the turnover in the previous financial year, with a special allowance in respect of any export turnover. Such companies may borrow locally, in addition, an amount in proportion to the level of their borrowings f rom overseas, based on the ratio of New Zealand and overseas equity holdings. Nonresident persons or com- panies wishing to make a direct investment in a New Zealand company through the purchase or exchange of shares are required to obtain the consent of the Overseas Investment Commission in respect of any proposed o f fer for such shares whenever the investment would confer on the offerer the beneficial entitlement to 25 per cent or more of any class of shares, or enable the offerer to exercise 25 per cent or more of the voting power at any general meeting. A New Zealand resident owning free ly held overseas securities may re ta in them abroad or he may sell them to a nonresident for any foreign currency, which may be reinvested in other overseas securities, may be remitted to New Zealand through the bank ing system, or may be retained at the disposal of the New Zealand resident. With lim- ited exceptions, sales of overseas securities by one New Zealand resident to another may be made only in exchange for other overseas securities or for any over- seas currency. The only overseas securities that may be traded between New Zealand residents in exchange for New Zealand currency are those that were registered in the names of New Zealand residents on June 16, 1966 and for which scrip or other documents of title were issued; the purchaser must lodge the share scrip with the Reserve Bank. These securities may also be sold for any overseas currency, in which case the proceeds must immediately be remitted to New Zealand through the banking system or be reinvested in other overseas securities within three months. 297 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NEW ZEALAND Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coin in New Zealand without restriction. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than gold coin and jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require licenses issued by the Customs Department; such licenses are not nor- mally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Commercial imports of gold jewelry are licensed restric- tively, but the importation of gold coin is exempt from license. Changes during 1978 February 3. The import deposit scheme applied since February 2, 1976 was terminated. April 1. The Exchange Control Regulations, 1978 and the Exchange Control Exemption Notice, 1978 came into force. The major amendments were as follows: ( 1) the Minister of Finance may determine, in doubtful cases, whether a person is deemed to be resident in New Zealand for the purposes of the regulations; (2) sterling area countries would henceforth be referred to as "for- eign countries"; (3) New Zealand residents were no longer required to obtain the prior approval of the Reserve Bank in order to borrow abroad for periods of less than one year for financing imports or exports; and (4) general exemptions relating to sterling area assets were continued and expanded to inc lude foreign assets wherever situated. April 6. The Import Licensing Schedule for 1978/79, to come into effect on July 1, provided for a basic alloca- tion in value terms of 107.5 per cent of 1977/78 qua l ify ing licenses for consumer goods, thus allowing the volume of such imports to remain unchanged. The allocation for other goods with a basic entitlement was 112.5 per cent of 1977/78 qua l i fy ing licenses. Other main features were ( 1) the m in imum value of "Basic" category license entitlements under an item code was raised to $NZ 500; (2) the major machinery item code was divided into 17 separate item codes for ease of identification; ( 3) in view of new or increased domestic production, certain items became entitled to a "C + 50 per cent" or "C + 75 per cent" allocation; these included tools for hand or machine use, screwdrivers, wood veneers, and grinding wheels; (4) nine product categories, including hearing aids, certain mineral fuels and oils, and tea in packages weighing 2 kilograms or more, were exempted from import licensing; (5) leather used in the manu fac tu re of footwear was shifted from the "Basic" category to category "C," and the allocation for made-up footwear was reduced to 90 per cent of the 1977/78 level; (6) to enable domestic producers to supply 70 per cent of the market for ceramic tableware, the 1978/79 allocation was set at the previous year's level; and (7) the exemption on private imports was raised to $NZ 50. The Government also announced that a new scheme would be introduced to correct anomalies arising in cases where the licensing criterion used in the past had been a major obstacle to the issue of a license to established firms, and that an in-depth review would be carried out for ten selected items to ensure that license holders were genuinely engaged in manu fac tu r ing or importing, that proper use was being made of licens- ing, and that there was an equitable spread of import licenses among firms. June 1. As part of the new budget, it was announced that ( 1) the scheme of tax incentives for exports to new markets was extended by one year un t il March 31, 1980; (2) the period for importing fishing vessels free of duty was extended to March 31, 1980; and (3) tariff policy would be reviewed to ensure it would not encourage the manu fac tu re of equipment that was less energy efficient than equipment available f rom overseas. July 1. Following a two-year review, a new customs tariff came into effect. Numerous adjustments were made to duty rates, but the overall level of tar iff protec- tion was reduced. Not for Redistribution NICARAGUA (Position on December 31, 1978) Exchange Rate System The currency of Nicaragua is the Nicaraguan Cordoba. Nicaragua maintains a dual exchange market system. Certain current and capital receipts must be surrendered to the Central Bank or its authorized agents at the official exchange rate, and the Central Bank or its authorized agents will sell foreign exchange at the official rate for specified current and capital pay- ments and transfers. All other permitted foreign exchange transactions take place at freely determined market rates. On December 29, 1978 the official buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were C$7.00 and C$7.0525, respectively, per US$1, and the average free market buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were C$7.80 and C$8.20, respectively, per US$1. The intervention currency in the official market is the U.S. dollar. There are no taxes or subsidies on pur- chases or sales of foreign exchange. Nicaragua accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from July 20, 1964. Administration of Control The exchange control system is administered by the Central Bank, which has sole authority to buy and sell foreign exchange. This authority has been delegated to the commercial banks, and the Central Bank deals with the public only to the extent that it accepts deposits in foreign currency, and for purposes of monetary control. Certain agencies are also authorized to buy and sell foreign exchange, but they may sell exchange only for payments for invisibles. The Central Bank is responsible for classifying imports, for issuing export authorizations, and for authorizing sales of exchange at the official rate for capital transactions and for payments for invisibles. Prescription of Currency There is no prescription of currency, but the customs authorities have the power to prohibit an export if the currency stipulated for payment is not readily convertible into U.S. dollars in international markets. Payments to Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras in respect of trade and invisibles may be settled in Nicara- guan cordobas through the Central American Clearing House. The Central Bank does not accept banknotes of El Salvador for compensation through the Clearing House in excess of 400,000 Salvadoran colones a month. Imports and Import Payments All commercial and industrial importers are required to be registered. There are two broad categories of registered importers: those who are permitted to import any kind of merchandise and those who may import only for their own industrial needs. Unregistered indi- viduals may not import for their own personal con- sumption except for the unaccompanied baggage of those persons who have resided outside Nicaragua for more than one year. Commercial and industrial imports f rom all countries, except the other Central American countries, must be consigned to persons or firms holding an importer's license from the Ministry of Economy. Import licenses are not required, but import transactions must be registered with and authorized by the Central Bank by means of import declarations. In view of the current shortage of foreign exchange, authorization is being given according to a priority list for purchases of foreign exchange only for the import of essentials, including medicines, foods tuffs, and industrial raw mate- rials. Other imports may be settled through the parallel market. Payments for imports from the Central American region must be effected in cordobas by bank check or certified check authorized for conversion through the Central American Clearing House. Payments for imports from outside the Central American region must be made with exchange purchased from the banking system, such payments being eligible for purchases at the official exchange rate.1 Letters of credit are used for imports f rom the rest of the world. Central Bank approval is not required to open a sight letter of credit but is required for a term letter of credit. The banks are not permitted to sell exchange for import payments in advance of the arrival of the documents. The Central Bank may authorize deferred payment or payment with funds derived from properly authenticated credits obtained abroad, provided that the imports are capital goods intended for development or production or for basic works complementary to production; such permis- sion is at present limited mainly to industrial and agri- cultural machinery and certain raw materials. Imports are not released from customs unless evidence is submitted that either payment or acceptance has been made through a bank. In the latter case, the Central Bank must also approve the importation on credit terms; this require- ment does not apply to duty-free imports from member countries of the Central American Common Market. Under the provisions of the Central American Agree- ment on Fiscal Incentives, Nicaragua grants duty exon- erations on imports of raw materials and capital goods to approved industrial firms. Most imports originating outside the Central American Common Market are subject to an import surcharge of 30 per cent of the applicable import duty. Certain commodities are subject to a compensatory (selective) 1 However, by virtue of Decree No. 1-L (effective March 1, 1963) the exchange proceeds f rom bananas, coconuts, copra, and coconut by- products exported through the ports of the region of El Cabo and the department of Zelaya may be used by the exporters to pay for com- modities not produced in Nicaragua which they themselves import for the exclusive use of or consumption by the inhabitants of those areas. 299 ©International Monetary Fund.
