Paymen ts with Portugal are channeled th rough a special account, but Turkey does not consider Portugal to be a bilateral par tner country. 8 Austria, Be lg ium, Denmark, France, Federal Republic of Germany, Italy, Ne ther lands, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, and United Kingdom. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution establishing their qualification is issued by the respective public authority, i.e., the Chambers of Commerce and Industry, the Exporters Union, or the Ministry of Tour- ism and Information. Most goods are imported in accordance with the pro- visions of import programs which are planned for one year. The import programs classify imports in two categories: (1) An annual list of liberalized goods, consisting of two parts (lists I and I I ). There are no limits as to either value or quan t i ty of goods brought in under these lists. Import licenses are issued freely and applications for import licenses for goods on the liberal- ized lists may be submitted at any time to authorized banks, which transfer them to the Central Bank for issuance of the import licenses. However, before an import license may be issued for goods to be imported under list II, approval of the appropriate government department is required. (2) A list of goods subject to global quotas published annua l ly. Imports of goods that do not appear on any of these lists are prohibited; certain of these commodities, however, may be imported when specifically authorized by the Ministry of Com- merce. The list of liberalized goods and the list of global quotas apply, in principle, only to imports from countries other than those with which Turkey has bilateral payments agreements;4 goods not included in either of these two import lists may not be imported under the bilateral quotas. Certain imports from mem- ber countries of the EEC are included in a list of liberalized items consolidated to the EEC and these are free of quantitative restriction; most of the items on this list are included in liberalized lists I and II. The list of import quotas contains quotas for regis- tered importers and for indus tr ia l is ts, which are allo- cated twice a year. Imports on the quota list are sub- divided into two broad categories, depend ing on whether they do or do not require a perm it from a specified pub- lic body. Foreign exchange allocations for all quota imports within the quantitative l im it established for each quota item are made by the Ministry of Commerce. Some of the quota imports also require a certificate confirming that the articles are not manu fac tu red domestically or that local supplies are inadequate as to either quantity or qua l i ty; this certificate is issued by the Ministry of Indus try and Technology. Registered importers have to submit their applications for goods not requiring a perm it through an authorized bank and the Central Bank to the Ministry of Commerce during the first two months of each semester. The Ministry of Commerce issues a foreign exchange allocation letter valid for four months, and an import license must be secured from the Central Bank w i th in this period. Appli- 4 When p e rm i t t ing impo r ts of goods on the liberalized or quo ta lists f rom coun t r ies o ther th an the paymen ts ag reement coun t r ies or member coun t r ies of the O rgan iza t ion for Economic Cooperation and Develop- men t, the M in is try of Commerce takes into account the balance of t rade and paymen ts w i th these countries. TURKEY cations for imports against industrialists' quotas where no permit is required have to be submitted through the Chambers of Commerce and Industry to the Ministry of Commerce in April and September of each year. Applications for quota imports requiring a permit from a specified public authority must be submitted to the responsible body by importers and by industrialists. An import license must then be secured from the Central Bank within the period of validity of the exchange allocation. The import license, in principle, permits the necessary foreign exchange payment to be made. Pay- ments for imports may be made against letters of credit, documents, or goods (i.e., upon customs clearance). For payment against letters of credit or documents, all importers (with the exception of government depart- men ts) are required to prepay in local currency the equivalent of the foreign exchange for which they have applied. The prepayments are transferred to the Central Bank by the authorized bank within five days. If pre- payments are not made within five days, penalty pay- ments equivalent to a certain ratio of the total value of imports are required, as follows: 5 per cent, if prepay- ments are made within the following five days, and an additional 1 per cent a day up to a maximum period of 60 days, with a maximum rate of 50 per cent. For payment against goods, the local currency counterpart has to be deposited within two months from the date of customs clearance. Importers are formally required to make the foreign exchange transfer within five months from the date of the import license for payments against documents and w i th in two months from the date of customs clearance for payments against goods. Since March 1977, how- ever, the Central Bank has limited foreign exchange paymen ts for imports to raw materials and other essen- tial commodities. Beginning late in 1976, large arrears of payments for imports have emerged. There is also a large amount of outstanding applications with the Cen- tral Bank for authorization of letters of credit. The local currency counterparts both of these applications and of the arrears have been deposited with the Central Bank and are being held in a special account. Exchange rate adjustments for officially quoted currencies entail changes in required import deposits. Importers are required to increase their deposits in the special account or they may receive reimbursement f rom the special account in the following cases: ( 1) when foreign exchange has been sold to the importer but the goods have not yet been imported, (2) when no foreign exchange has been sold and the goods have not yet been cleared by customs, and ( 3) when no foreign exchange has been sold but the goods have been cleared by customs. Imports from bilateral agreement countries are sub- ject to separate quotas. These are established only for commodities that appear on the liberalized or global quota lists. The import licensing procedure for goods f rom these countries is the same as for imports under 411 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TURKEY global quotas, except that applications under the bilateral quotas specified in each agreement are submitted by the Central Bank or the responsible public authority to the Ministry of Commerce on a monthly basis. The financing through acceptance credits with a minimum maturity of 180 days is permitted for certain imports, including all import requirements of industrial- ists. Turkish banks have been requested to use half of their total acceptance credit financing for imports of petroleum and fertilizers. In principle, commercial banks have to meet all foreign exchange needs arising from acceptance credit financing from their own foreign exchange resources. Banks can apply at the Central Bank for the transfer of foreign exchange but, as a consequence, lose the right to carry out f u t u re accept- ance credit operations. Guarantee deposits for imports are payable in advance, generally as follows: for goods on liberalized list I, 30 per cent of the value of the merchandise and for items on list II, 15 per cent; for imports under global quotas, 10 per cent of the value of the import application is payable for goods on importers' quotas, and 2.5 per cent for industrialists' quotas.5 For imports under bilateral quotas the rate of guarantee deposit depends on the list on which the goods are included if imported from a nonpayments agreement country. Guarantee deposits are payable irrespective of the method of payment. The public sector is exempt, however, and in many cases industrialists make a symbolic deposit of 1 per cent (on imports under investment quotas set aside for their use and applicable to convertible currency countries only, or on imports under investment quotas in bilateral agreements). The deposit remains blocked until the goods have been cleared through customs and the foreign supplier paid; it is then refunded to the importer. The guarantee deposits collected are transferred weekly to an account held by the Central Bank in the name of the authorized bank. Should imports not be made in con- form i ty with the regulations, a part of the guarantee deposit corresponding to up to 10 per cent of the value of such imports is forfeited to the Treasury. Private compensation transactions are not permitted in any form, except that the Ministry of Commerce is authorized to conclude agreements to dispose of goods acquired through supporting purchases made by the State. There are special arrangements for the allocation of foreign exchange for exporters of manu fac tu res' and industrial and m in ing products who are entitled to foreign exchange allocations equivalent to 25 per cent of exports for their own import needs or the import needs of their subcontractors. Exporters are entitled to 5 For fe r t i l ize r s, ammon ia, breeding animals, and certain products on liberalized list II and the global quotas, the rate is 1 per cent. For materials used for sh ipbu i ld ing, repa ir, and modification carried out w i th in the coun t ry, and for the cons truc t ion of sh ipyards, the ra te is 0.1 per cent, provided the value of imports does not exceed LT 25,000; when ships are built abroad or are purchased abroad, the ra te is 0.2 per cent, provided the value of imports does not exceed LT 50,000. 412 use these foreign exchange earnings for payments for goods up to twice the amount of inputs imported under the "cash against goods" scheme. Furthermore, manu- facturers who have export orders in hand, or are willing to guarantee exports of a specific value, are allowed to arrange for credits abroad in order to finance their import needs, up to 50 per cent of the value of the export orders in hand or 50 per cent of their export commitment. They are subject to the condition that they will repay the external credits out of their export earnings within one year from the date of the import of their production inputs. The Government provides manufacturers with foreign exchange conversion authori- zations f rom the Export Promotion Foreign Exchange Fund established in 1970. Moreover, exporters are en- titled to priority in foreign exchange allocations equiva- lent to 1 per cent of their foreign exchange receipts in the previous year, subject to a limit of US$50,000. Imports without an allocation of foreign exchange may be permitted by the customs authorities, the Central Bank, or the Ministry of Finance, under certain condi- tions. Travelers domiciled in Turkey may bring in for personal or professional (but noncommercial) use goods and machinery up to a limit (in terms of total import duties applicable) of LT 6,000, Separate limits and conditions apply to imports of goods for personal use, and of professional instruments and machines, by per- sons who have resided abroad for employment or study; these vary with the length of stay abroad and with the transfer of foreign exchange to Turkey. Companies or cooperatives formed in Turkey by residents temporarily working abroad may import investment goods to the extent of the foreign exchange invested. In addition to personal effects, foreign tourists may import goods and machinery for their personal or family use. Foreign contractors may temporarily import machin- ery, vehicles, and scientific instruments without request- ing an allocation of foreign exchange, provided that the goods are proved to be necessary for their operations in Turkey. Foreign companies established in Turkey may import spare parts not intended for new investments without requesting an allocation of foreign exchange, provided that the goods are necessary for their opera- tions. All such imports require the permission of the exchange control authorities. Goods imported on these terms must not be sold to third parties in Turkey. Imports of automobiles,6 tractors, or professional machinery, etc., without payment of foreign exchange may be permitted by the Central Bank or the Ministry of Finance, provided that certain conditions are met relating to residence abroad and to remittance and sale of foreign exchange to authorized banks in Turkey. Automobiles imported without a foreign exchange allo- cation may be sold to residents by the Turkish nationals who had imported them. Foreign diplomats in Turkey 6 Automobiles are not included in the import program. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution may sell their automobiles to Turkish residents, provided that the necessary import duties are paid at the time of the sale, that Turkish diplomats in the seller's country are granted reciprocal privileges, and that the proceeds from such sales are not transferred abroad. Foreign officials, other than diplomats, may not sell to Turkish nationals any automobiles imported duty free under special agreements. Other foreign nationals resident in Turkey may import automobiles under certain condi- tions, but these must be exported af ter three years; how- ever, this three-year period may be extended, and the Ministry of Finance may also permit the sale of such cars to the State Supply Office or to nonprofit organi- zations. In addition to customs duty, imported goods are subject to the following charges: ( 1) a customs sur- charge (municipal tax) of 15 per cent of the applicable customs duty; (2) a stamp duty of 22.5 per cent or 25 per cent of the declared value, depending on the type of commodity;7 (3) a quay duty of 5 per cent on the sum of c.i.f. value, customs duty, customs surcharge, and customs clearance expenses; and (4) a production tax ranging generally from 10 per cent to 75 per cent on the sum of c.i.f. value, customs duty, customs sur- charge, customs clearing expenses, and quay duty. The quay du ty is not payable on goods imported by air. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles require exchange licenses which usually are issued by the Central Bank. These are granted liberally for the following purposes, pro- vided that applications are accompanied by specified documents: payments related to trade (including ship- ping costs and expenditures connected with other freight charges), subscriptions to newspapers and periodicals, purchases of books, payments for registration fees, advertising expenses, consulate income, payments by the Government, payments by the Post Office Administration and similar state institutions, banks' commissions and expenses, a proportion of insurance companies' pay- ments, specified technical assistance, repair and assembly expenses, and legal fees for commercial transactions. The transfer of income related to foreign investments approved under the Law for the Encouragement of Foreign Investment is permitted freely. Interest on long-term loans and credits extended by nonresidents to enterprises in Turkey (including those of an agricultural na ture) may be granted transferability between foreign nationals both in Turkey and abroad. Turkish citizens may not leave the country without obtaining an allocation of foreign exchange for travel, but this does not apply to foreign nationals residing in Turkey. Tourist travel is restricted, in effect, to one trip a person every three years, and one trip a person a 7 The stamp du ty is 100 per cent for imports made by special permis- sion but not conforming to the provisions of the Customs Law, the Foreign Trade Regime, and similar legislation and regulations. TURKEY year to Cyprus. A tax of 50 per cent is applied to the purchase of foreign exchange by Turkish nationals traveling abroad. The allowance for tourism is the equivalent of either a minimum of US$300 or a maxi- mum of US$500. Exchange for business travel is granted up to an annual maximum limit of US$2,500, individual limits being determined in accordance with the taxable income of the applicant firm; for businessmen in export- ing businesses the limit is related to the export proceeds of their firms. Exchange for travel abroad for other pur- poses (e.g., education, participation in international meetings, fairs, and athletic meets, and personal busi- ness) is sold up to specified limits. In addition, persons who can certify that it is necessary for them to travel abroad for medical treatment may purchase the neces- sary foreign exchange. Travelers are permitted to take out LT1,000 in Turkish banknotes and coin. Nonresidents may take out without any restriction the unspent portion of the foreign exchange which they brought in. Nonresident travelers who wish to reconvert liras into foreign cur- rency when leaving the country are required to present a document showing that foreign exchange had previ- ously been sold to an authorized dealer in Turkey. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. All exports destined to bilateral countries, exports of the commodi- ties listed in the appendix of the export program,8 re-exports irrespective of destination, and temporary exports require an export license in order to prevent re-exports and to assure adequate supplies for the domestic market. Most other exports need to be regis- tered. Commercial export prices must conform to the checklist of prices fixed at intervals by the Ministry of Commerce on the basis of prices in domestic and foreign markets. Exports of goods subject neither to registration nor to license may be effected freely. The prices of exports to free trade areas or to duty- f ree shops abroad are approved ex post at the time the goods are delivered or at the time of sale. Such exports require an export permit issued by the Ministry of Commerce. Transit trade items are not subject to price controls, although the purchase price and any commis- sion earned must be brought into Turkey. Exporters are required to sell to a bank in Turkey the foreign exchange proceeds of goods exported within three months from the date of export or within ten days from the date on which the foreign exchange is placed at their disposal. They are permitted to export on three-year credit terms, however, against payment in convertible currency and subject to a bank guarantee. While all export proceeds, in principle, are converted at current exchange rates, exporters receive from a special 8 Cereals, certain minerals such as molybdenum, wolfram, and iron ore, articles made of precious metals or stones, vegetable oils, oilseeds, skins, fer t i l izers, cattle, meat, timber, and paper. (However, this list may be changed whenever the export regime is renewed.) 413 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TURKEY account in the Central Bank the difference between the exchange rate at the time of export licensing, registra- tion, or customs declaration and the current exchange rate if the d ifference is in their favor. Forward sales may be made only when payment is to be received f rom the free currency area; price conformity for forward sales is required at the time the export contract is concluded. Under an export tax rebate scheme, direct and indi- rect taxes paid are refunded when manufactures or industrial products are exported. The rates of rebate range from 5 per cent to 35 per cent of export value. Other tax refunds apply for certain goods when exported to bilateral payments agreement countries. Other tax incentives include the exemption of export earnings from income and corporation taxes and the exemption of export goods from production tax. Exporters of specified goods also have access to credit at preferential interest rates from a Special Export Fund. Proceeds from Invisibles Firms or individuals not in the category of authorized institutions cannot accept more than the equivalent of US$100 from foreign tourists and are required to surrender any exchange earnings in the form of foreign banknotes and travelers checks to an authorized bank within ten days. Otherwise, foreign exchange accruing to residents for services rendered by them to nonresi- dents must be surrendered to an authorized exchange dealer within three months from the date on which the service was rendered or within ten days from the date of acquisition of the exchange. Foreign travelers wish- ing to take out articles with a value exceeding LT 2,000 must show proof that they have converted foreign exchange to cover the portion of the cost exceeding this limit. International transit through Turkey by road is sub- ject to a foreign exchange conversion requirement equivalent to US$300 for each transport unit without any claim to reconversion.9 The import of Turkish banknotes and coin by travelers (whether of Turkish or foreign nationality) is limited to LT 1,000. The import of foreign currency by travelers is unrestricted. Capital Foreign investments in Turkey require approval. Capital transfers abroad by residents and capital trans- actions between residents and nonresidents are subject to the approval of the exchange control authorities. Subject to specific permission issued by the Ministry of Finance residents may acquire foreign securities. Residents are not normally permitted to acquire foreign real estate. With the exception of certain investments made in accordance with the provisions of the Law for the Encouragement of Foreign Investments or the Petroleum 9 This requirement was abolished in March 1979. 414 Law, foreign companies and contractors who wish to do business in Turkey must import the required capital and operating funds in the form of foreign exchange, although under certain conditions blocked funds may be used for investment in the tourist industry. Borrowing in Turkish liras by such foreign companies and con- tractors is subject to quotas set by the Ministry of Finance in accordance with their equity capital in Turkey, but special facilities exist for borrowing from the "Blocked Currencies Fund" at the Central Bank. Blocked funds are those accrued or accruing to non- residents but not transferable under the existing exchange control regulations. These include the sale proceeds of real estate situated in Turkey and owned by nonresident physical or juridical persons. Except for approved investments, nonresidents may not convert into foreign currency any assets or balances owned by them, or earnings accruing to them; all earnings are blocked but if, at the end of the calendar year, such earnings are less than LT 10,000, the amount involved is deblocked. Subject to individual permission, blocked assets and balances may be utilized within Turkey, e.g., for the payment of taxes, insurance, and maintenance and repair of property, and for living expenses of up to LT 15,000 a month for each beneficiary for owners of such funds or their authorized representatives, and up to LT 10,000 for certain relatives. Normally, such blocked funds may not be transferred to others except by legal succession. The investment of blocked funds in the tourist industry is subject to the following condi- tions: (1) there must be a contribution in new foreign exchange or imported equipment equal to at least 50 per cent of the blocked funds to be used and (2) the investor must undertake not to request transfer for at least five years of that part of the capital financed by means of the blocked funds. Blocked funds used in this manner are considered as foreign capital imported under the Law for the Encouragement of Foreign Investments. A portion of 75 per cent of any holder's blocked funds can be transferred to the Blocked Currencies Fund at the Central Bank, from which nonresidents may receive credits for their partner companies' investment requirements in Turkey, provided the permission of the Ministry of Finance is obtained. Dividends and profits derived from these credits have to be blocked again and are nontransferable. Balances on nonresident accounts established at the Central Bank in accordance with the Paris Agreement on Commercial Debts Owed by Residents of Turkey (1959) may be used either partially or wholly by the creditors for investment or to pay expenses in Turkey at any time prior to the date, established under the Agreement, when the balances may be transferred. The use of these balances for investment purposes is subject to the provisions of the Law for the Encouragement of Foreign Investments. However, invested funds and income related thereto may not be transferred abroad ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution before the transfer date established under the Agree- ment, except for investment in the export industries or in other industries earning foreign exchange; in such instances the equivalent of up to 25 per cent of the investment may be transferred annually. Foreign capital invested in Turkey under the terms of the Law for the Encouragement of Foreign Invest- ments is accorded preferential treatment. All or part of the invested capital or foreign loans may be remitted abroad in the original currency of the capital. Upon application, the Ministry of Finance guarantees the transfer of dividends and of the proceeds f rom the sale or liquidation of shares or stock certificates registered on the books of the companies established under the law. Such registered shares or stock certificates are freely transferable between foreign nationals, both in Turkey and abroad, and between foreign nationals and residents. The transfer guarantees pass on to the new owner, provided that his name is notified to the Ministry of Finance; if the shares or stock certificates are sold to a resident, however, they must be presented to the Ministry of Finance for cancellation of the guarantees. The capital and interest on long-term loans and credits extended by nonresidents to enterprises in Turkey ( inc lud ing those of an agricultural na tu re) may be accorded the same transfer benefits. Foreign capital imported under the Petroleum Law is accorded addi- tional preferential treatment. Foreign investments out- side the petroleum sector may be made "under the monetary regulations," in which case the investor does not enjoy any transfer facilities for earnings or liquida- tion proceeds. Transactions in securities, including their export and import, require approval when nonresident interests are involved. There are special facilities for the acquisition by Turkish citizens working abroad of Turkish shares and bonds. Nonresidents and Turkish nationals working abroad may open demand and time accounts with commercial banks in convertible Turkish liras, carrying an exchange guarantee of the Central Bank. Interest rates on these funds must not exceed the six-month London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) by more than 2.25 per cent. However, the exchange rate guarantee is limited to the stock of deposits existing on March 1, 1978, including overdue deposits and rollovers, provided they are for a m in imum period of one year. In addition, authorized banks with deposits exceeding LT 2 billion are permitted to incur an overall fore ign exchange position (in cur- rencies purchased and sold by the Central B ank) of up to US$20 million. During 1978 arrears developed in respect of repayments of ma tu r ing convertible Turkish lira deposits. With the exception of borrowing by the Government from foreign governments or government agencies and f rom international institutions, all private sector and public sector borrowing abroad is regulated. The total TURKEY amount of private and public sector borrowing abroad from private sources, including suppliers' credits, is determined in an annual program by the Ministry of Finance, which also specifies the eligible sectors and projects. The Ministry of Finance, after consultation with other ministries if appropriate, is authorized to approve such credits and to issue a guarantee of the transferability of the foreign exchange. It is the respon- sibility of the intermediating bank to guarantee the repayment in liras. Turkish borrowers pay that bank the prevailing domestic interest rate. Regulations issued by the Ministry of Finance specify that, with certain exceptions, the maturity of such credits must not be less than two years, and the rate of interest must not exceed the LIBOR rate by more than 2.25 per cent. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Turkey for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized indus tr ial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any fo rm other than jewelry, at home or abroad; any unworked gold held in Turkey, however, may be pre- sented for m in t ing by the State Mint. Gold may be im- ported freely, provided it is sold to the Central Bank. Exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted except for exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Changes during 1978 January 24. The stamp duty on imports was raised f rom 9 or 9.5 per cent to 22.5 or 25 per cent of the declared value, depending on the type of commodity. February 16. The list of goods that could be imported w i th acceptance credit financing was reduced. February 18. Foreign exchange allowances for busi- ness travel were reduced by 50 per cent with the excep- tion of those available to exporters of goods and services. March 1. There were several changes in foreign exchange controls. The regulations for imports without foreign exchange allocation ("imports with waiver") were tightened; all exchange rate guaran tees were abol- ished w i th the exception of the stock of convertible lira deposits existing as of March 1, including overdue deposits and rollovers, provided they were for a m in imum period of one year; the foreign exchange allowance for travel abroad was reduced to US$500 a person for two calendar years; a tax of 50 per cent was introduced on the purchase of foreign exchange by Turkish nationals trave l ing abroad; the privilege of na tural persons and legal entities domiciled abroad to receive up to 50 per cent of their convertible Turkish lira deposits for imports of goods for their own production needs was abolished; and the "cash against goods" import scheme was limited to imports of industrialists. March 1. The official rates for the U.S. dollar were changed to LT 25.00 buying and LT 25.50 selling, per 415 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TURKEY US$1. The separate rate for workers' remittances became inoperative. Importers who had already received foreign exchange were requested to increase their deposits within 15 days. Importers who had yet to receive foreign exchange were given three months to augment their deposits or to withdraw their deposits and applications for foreign exchange transfers. March 2. Export tax rebates on manufactures and processed agricultural products were reduced by 20 per- centage points and export tax rebates for raw cotton, tobacco, and some other agricultural products were abolished. April 30. A special Export Encouragement Fund was established in the Central Bank to meet the preferential foreign exchange entitlements of exporters of manu- factures and mining products established in November 1977. For this purpose the fund would be allocated 25 per cent of receipts from industrial and mineral exports. (In November 1978, in order to simplify administrative procedures, banks were permitted to retain this portion of export receipts.) May 23. The time period during which importers who already received foreign exchange were required to increase their import deposits following the depreciation of the Turkish lira was lengthened three to ten months (see entry for March 1, above). The amounts due were to be paid in equal monthly installments. July 6. It was announced that exporters would be entitled to use their foreign exchange earnings for the payment of up to twice the amount of inputs imported under the "cash against goods" system to sustain their export and domestic production and the production needs of their subcontractors. July 6. Export tax rebates on manufactures and pro- cessed agricultural products were raised by 10 percentage points. July 6. It was announced that exporters would be entitled to priority in foreign exchange allocations equivalent to 1 per cent of their foreign exchange receipts in the previous year, subject to a limit of US$50,000. Hotels and restaurants were permitted smaller priority allocations. July 28. Turkish nationals working abroad were per- mitted, for a period of six months, to buy with foreign exchange, for which there was no repatriation obliga- tion, one domestically produced car, truck, or tractor without having to enter the waiting list for the purchase of these items. If they were to exercise this option they would, however, lose eligibility for imports without foreign exchange application ("imports with waiver") for a period of five years. The manufac turers of the cars, trucks, and tractors sold under this scheme would be entitled to preferential allocations in respect of the foreign exchange received. July. Manufacturers with export orders in hand, who were prepared to guarantee exports of their goods up to a specific value, were allowed to arrange for credits 416 abroad for up to 50 per cent of the value of the export orders in hand or 50 per cent of their guaranteed export commitment in order to finance their import require- ments. These arrangements were subject to the condition that they would repay out of their export earnings the export credits they might have arranged, within one year from the date of the import of their production inputs. September 20. The Central Bank announced that henceforth quoted rates for foreign currencies (other than the U.S. dollar) would be changed on a weekly basis, whenever any quoted rate deviated by more than 2.25 per cent from its cross rate vis-a-vis the U.S. dollar in international markets. (These adjustments were dis- continued on October 22, 1978.) September 30. A special fund of US$60 million was established for the importation of inputs for industrial production. October 4. Industrialists facing serious import bottle- necks were entitled to use acceptance credits for goods not on the list of items eligible for acceptance credit financing, provided that they could arrange a minimum maturity of one year. October 4. Banks were required to use half of their acceptance credit financing for imports of petroleum and fertilizers, and to meet all foreign exchange needs arising from acceptance credit financing from their own resources. In principle, banks could still apply to the Central Bank for the foreign exchange, but if they did so they would lose their entitlement to carry out accept- ance credit operations in the future. November 10. The regulations in respect of profits and losses arising from foreign exchange transactions, import deposits, and the conversion of export proceeds were revised. A special account established in the Cen- tral Bank would be used for the absorption of profits and reimbursement of losses of the commercial banks resulting from adjustments of the exchange rates for officially quoted currencies and in required import deposits. Importers would be required to increase their deposits or they would receive reimbursements in the following cases: (1) when foreign exchange had been sold to the importer but the goods had not yet been imported; (2) when no foreign exchange had been sold and the goods had not yet been cleared by customs; and ( 3) when no foreign exchange had been sold and the goods had been cleared by customs. While all export proceeds would be converted at current exchange rates, exporters would receive from the special account the difference between the exchange rate at the time of export licensing, registration, or customs declaration and the current exchange rate if the difference were in the exporter's favor. December 31. With effect from January 1, 1979, use of the foreign exchange allowance of US$500 a person for travel abroad would be reduced to once every three calendar years. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UGANDA (Position on December 31, 1978) Exchange Rate System The currency of Uganda is the Uganda Shilling, which is pegged to the SDR at U Sh 9.6600 = SDR 1. Uganda applies margins of not more than 1 per cent in terms of the fixed relationship between the Uganda shilling and the SDR. The Bank of Uganda does not deal in foreign currencies1 other than deutsche mark, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars. The mid-rate of the Uganda shilling for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, is determined by the Bank of Uganda on the basis of the daily calculation of the U.S. dollar-SDR rate. Buy- ing and selling rates for deutsche mark and pounds sterling are determined on the basis of the appropriate cross rates for the U.S. dollar in the New York market on the previous day. Authorized commercial banks in Uganda deal in all specified currencies2 and base their rates on the previous day's closing rates against the U.S. dollar in New York, except for Kenya shillings and Tanzania shillings, which are dealt in at par. Authorized banks may freely deal forward with customers in ster- ling, U.S. dollars, and other currencies, provided that there is an underlying approved import or export con- tract and that the term of the forward contract does not exceed three months; contracts for longer periods require exchange control approval. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. Administration of Control The Bank of Uganda administers exchange control on behalf of the Minister of Finance. Import and export control is administered by the Ministry of Commerce. The Minister of Commerce has powers to prohibit imports and exports. With Kenya and Tanzania, Uganda formed part of the East African Community, but after the Community was effectively dissolved, early in 1977, Uganda now treats residents of Kenya and Tanzania on the same basis as all other nonresidents for exchange control purposes. Prescription of Currency All payments to Kenya and Tanzania must be effected through U.S. dollar accounts held with banks abroad. Authorized payments, including payments for imports, by residents of Uganda to residents of foreign countries other than Israel, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica may be made in Uganda shillings to the credit of an External Account in Uganda, or in any other currency except 1 Foreign currencies are all currencies other than the Uganda shilling. 2 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish and Faroese kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, U.S. dollars, and all currencies of the former Sterling Area other than the Uganda shilling. Rhodesian currency that is appropriate to the country of residence of the payee. Receipts from such countries may be obtained in Uganda shillings from an External Account in Uganda or in any convertible currency. Payments to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Certain settlements with Zaire are channeled through special accounts. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Uganda shillings held by residents of foreign countries are designated External Accounts. They may be credited freely with authorized payments by residents of Uganda, with transfers f rom other External Accounts, and with the proceeds f rom sales of any foreign currency and gold by nonresidents of Uganda to authorized dealers. They may be debited free ly for payments to nonresidents, for transfers to other External Accounts in Uganda, and for purchases of foreign currencies from authorized dealers. Non transferab le funds of persons not resident in Uganda are credited to Blocked Accounts. Subject to prior approval, balances on Blocked Accounts may be used for the purchase in Uganda of specified bonds and shares issued in Uganda; the redemption proceeds of government bonds so acquired are transferable begin- ning five years from the date of purchase. Subject to individual permission, such balances may also be used for payments to residents not related to export trans- actions. All Blocked Accounts must be held with the Uganda Commercial Bank. Imports and Import Payments All imports from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Imports are controlled through foreign exchange allocations and import licensing. A Cabinet Committee, under the chairmanship of the Minister of Finance, meets fortnightly and makes block allocations of foreign exchange on a ministry-by-ministry basis. The Bank of Uganda informs the Committee of the availability of foreign exchange, while the Industrial Assessment Committee makes recommendations on import requirements for the industrial sector. On the basis of these recommendations a minimum guaranteed amount of foreign exchange is made available for the importation of industrial raw materials and spare parts. Import licenses, which are required for all imports, are issued to individual importers by the Uganda Advisory Board of Trade (UABT), operating under the super- vision of the Ministry of Commerce. For imports of industrial and commercial goods, the UABT also dis- tributes among individual importers allocations of for- eign exchange to the Ministry of Industry and the Ministry of Commerce. With regard to imports of the 417 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UGANDA goods that fall under the jurisdiction of other ministries, each ministry directly concerned apportions the foreign exchange allocated to it; in such cases, the UABT issues licenses automatically. Upon approval of the applica- tion, the importer must deposit with the UABT a commission of 1 per cent of the amount of the license. Imports normally must be purchased directly f rom the country of origin. Imports of some manufac tured goods from Kenya and Tanzania are subject to transfer taxes. Import payments normally are made under letters of credit opened in the name of the UABT for the account of the importer; the latter generally must make fu ll pay- ment to the authorized bank before the letter of credit is opened. Documentary evidence showing that the goods have been imported into Uganda must be forwarded to the exchange control authorities within six months from the date of payment. Since early 1977 a certain amount of foreign exchange has been set aside each month to liquidate payments arrears. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries are subject to approval by the Bank of Uganda and those to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. The basic allowance for travel outside Uganda is the equivalent of U Sh 3,000 a person every three years, which may be taken out in travelers checks. The allowance is available for travel to any country except Kenya and Tanzania, for which holiday facilities of up to U Sh 1,000 a person a year normally are available, and Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa, for which no allocation is granted. Expatriates working in Uganda may obtain allocations for travel outside East Africa at the time of their over- seas leave. Foreign exchange is not released for nursery, pri- mary, and secondary education abroad except for children of diplomats, technical assistance personnel, nonnationals working in Uganda on overseas terms, non- national missionaries, and other special cases. Facilities exist whereby salaried foreign nationals may remit to their country of origin up to 33^ per cent of their gross monthly earnings, to cover family maintenance, savings, etc., provided that they are on a contract of employment which includes a firm commitment to leave Uganda upon expiry of the contract. Transfers of dividends and profits are subject to special regulations; thus, foreign-owned companies must retain in Uganda at least 20 per cent of the profits made in any business year, and they are not allowed to remit interim divi- dends. The export of Uganda banknotes and coin by travelers is prohibited, except that travelers to Kenya and Tan- zania may take out U Sh 100 in Uganda currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. All exports require licenses and may be 418 restricted to ensure sufficient supplies for consumption in Uganda. The Uganda Tea Board has a monopoly over the export of tea, the Coffee Marketing Board over the export of coffee, and the Lint Marketing Board over the export of raw cotton. Export proceeds in specified currencies (see foot- note 2) must be collected within six months of exporta- tion and sold to an authorized bank against Uganda shillings. Coffee, cotton, copper, and hides and skins are subject to export duty. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in specified currencies (see footnote 2) must be sold to an authorized bank. The import of Uganda banknotes and coin by travelers is prohibited, except that returning residents may bring in U Sh 100 a person. Travelers may freely bring in bank- notes denominated in specified currencies and foreign currency travelers checks. Capital Capital transfers to all countries are restricted and those to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are pro- hibited. Foreign assets must be deposited with an author- ized depositary, except that residents of Uganda may be granted exemption in respect of specified Sterling Area assets held prior to June 11, 1965. Capital transfers require individual exchange control approval. Residents of Uganda leaving permanently may normally transfer their assets up to the equivalent of U Sh 50,000. The allowance is reduced by the amount of insurance premiums remitted after 1965 outside the facilities for remittance of savings. A further transfer of up to the equivalent of U Sh 20,000 upon each anni- versary of the emigrant's departure is allowed. All remaining funds must be credited to a Blocked Account and may either be invested in certain approved securities or be held on deposit with the Uganda Commercial Bank; such funds become transferable after five years. The income from such investments is transferable during the period when the funds are blocked. There is no restriction on the investment of foreign funds in Uganda; to secure guaranteed repatriation, however, it is necessary to obtain "approved status" for the investment in terms of the Foreign Investments (Pro- tection) Act, 1964, as amended by the Foreign Invest- ments Decree, 1977; in normal circumstances approved status is given freely. Foreign and domestic investment in specified types of production require approval under the Licensing Act of 1969. Dividends and profits due to nonresidents from normal trading operations and distrib- uted by companies operating in Uganda are, in principle, transferable. All imports and exports of securities require approval. Approval is freely granted for the purchase by non- residents of Ugandan securities, provided that payment is received in an appropriate manner. The income from ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UGANDA such securities is remittable, and the proceeds on resale are normally remittable also. Purchases of securities outside Uganda by residents are not normally permitted. A resident of Uganda may not send money abroad, for whatever purpose, without specific exchange control approval. With minor exceptions, prior exchange con- trol approval is required for loans or overdraft facilities granted to a nonresident or to a body corporate resident in Uganda which is controlled, directly or indirectly, by persons resident outside Uganda. Gold A commemorative gold coin with a face value of U Sh 500 is legal tender but does not circulate. Resi- dents may hold and acquire gold coins in Uganda for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in Uganda in any form other than jewelry. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a trav- eler require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance. Export licenses are not normally granted except for exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. The import of the following from all sources is subject to individual licensing: jewelry of gold, silver, or platinum; goldsmiths' or silversmiths' wares, including set gems; bullion in the ingot, bar, or sheet; and gold coin. Import licenses for gold bullion, gold jewelry, and gold coin are issued restrictively and only to goldsmiths. Changes during 1978 No significant changes took place. 419 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED ARAB EMIRATES1 (Position on December 31, 2978) Exchange Rate System Nonresident Accounts The currency of the United Arab Emirates is the U.A.E. Dirham, which is pegged to the SDR at the rate of Dh 4.76190 = SDR 1. The United Arab Emirates has established margins of 7.25 per cent around the official rate. The U.S. dollar is the intervention currency, and the Currency Board publishes daily buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar only. On December 31, 1978 the official buying and selling rates were Dh 3.8360 and Dh 3.8400, respectively, per US$1. The Currency Board sets no limits on the amount of U.S. dollars that it is prepared to buy from or sell to any commercial bank. Commercial banks are free to enter into foreign exchange transactions at rates of their own choosing; in practice, however, their quotations for the U.S. dollar are close to those announced by the Currency Board. Rates quoted by commercial banks for currencies other than the U.S. dollar are determined on the basis of the previous day's closing rates in New York as well as the international quotations elsewhere in the Gulf area and in the Far East. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchas.es or sales of foreign exchange. There is a swap facility at the Currency Board which the commercial banks may use to purchase or sell d i rhams forward for periods of one to three months. Max imum limits of US$20 million ou ts tand ing for each bank and, of US$5 million in purchases a day, are in effec t. The swap fac i l i ty is also used to in f luence the availability of dirhams to the bank ing system. There is an agreement between the United Arab Emirates, Bahra in, and Qatar whereby, for the con- venience of travelers, notes denominated in U.A.E. d irhams, Bahra in dinars, and Qatar riyals are inter- changeable at the fixed rates of Dh 1 = BD 0.1 = QR 1. The United A rab Emirates fo rma l ly accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement on February 13, 1974. Administration of Control There is neither exchange control legislation nor an exchange control authority in the United Arab Emirates, and there are no registration requ iremen ts for inward or outward transfers. Import and export licenses, where requ ired, are issued by the authorities of the Emirate concerned. Prescription of Currency All settlements with Israel and South Afr ica are pro- hibited. No other prescription of currency requirements are in force. There are no b i la teral paymen ts agreements. No distinction is made between accounts held by residents and those held by nonresidents. Imports and Import Payments Imports f rom Israel and South Afr ica are prohibited, as are imports of products manufac tured by foreign companies blacklisted by the Arab League. Imports of a few commodities are prohibited from all sources for health or security reasons. Virtually all other commodi- ties may be freely imported without an individual import permit, but only licensed parties can enter the import trade and an importer can import only the commodity or commodities specified in his license. There are no restrictions on the availability of foreign exchange for payments in respect of permitted imports. Payments for Invisibles All payments for current invisibles may be made free ly, except to Israel and South Africa. Travelers may take out any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports and re-exports to Israel and South Africa are prohibited. Virtually all commodities may be exported freely, without an export license, to any other destina- t ion. Each Emirate establishes its own export regula- tions. There are no requirements attached to receipts f rom exports or re-exports; the proceeds need not be repatriated or surrendered and may be disposed of freely, regardless of the currency involved. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no requirements governing receipts from current invisibles. Travelers may bring in any amount in foreign or domestic banknotes. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents. Transactions and settlements involving Israel, South A f r ica, and companies blacklisted by the Arab League, however, are prohibited. Profits on foreign capital invested in the United Arab Emirates may be remitted freely. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM (Position on December 31, 1978) Exchange Rate System The currency of the United Kingdom is the Pound Sterling. The authorities of the United Kingdom do not ma in ta in margins in respect of exchange transactions and exchange rates are determined largely on the basis of demand and supply conditions in the exchange markets, except for currencies ma in ta in ing a fixed rela- tionship with sterling. However, the authorities inter- vene when necessary in order to smooth out disruptive fluctuations in the exchange rates. The closing selling and buy ing rates in the foreign exchange market for the U.S. dollar on December 29, 1978 were US$2.0400 and US$2.0420, respectively, per £1. Authorized banks are allowed to engage in spot and forward exchange transactions in any currency, except Rhodesian currency, subject to the observance of limits on open positions and the accumulation of spot foreign exchange. Forward rates may fluctuate under the influ- ence of market forces; transactions with resident cus- tomers may be entered into only for approved purposes, where there is an underlying commercial contract (or where an exporter is tendering for an overseas export contract), and in the currency of the contract. There is also a market (referred to as the investment currency market) in which certain foreign currency proceeds,1 resulting mainly f rom the sale outside the Scheduled Territories (the United Kingdom, the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man, the Republic of Ireland,2 and Gibraltar) of foreign currency securities held for port- folio investment purposes,3 and of most personal resi- dential property situated outside the Scheduled Terri- tories may be negotiated at freely determined rates, usually attracting a prem ium over the official market; at the end of 1978, that premium was 42.7 per cent calculated at the ruling U.S. dollar rate in the official exchange market, the middle closing rate on December 29 being <£! = US$2.0410. These funds are normally available for reinvestment in marketable foreign currency securities, for approved purchases of personal residential property in countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia, and, although little used for this purpose, for approved direct investments in non- Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia. 1 Under the U.K. exchange control regulations, fore ign currency comprises all currencies other than the currencies of the United King- dom, the Republic of Ireland, and Gibraltar. 2 The U.K. regulations refer to Ireland as the Republic of Ireland, and for the purpose of this survey the U.K. usage is being followed. 3 The term "foreign currency securities" is generally to be read as meanins securities payable or optionally payable in a currency of a country other than the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, and G ibra l tar. Special regulations, however, are applicable to fore ign cur- rency securities payable in Rhodesian currency. Sterling securities are defined as securities payable solely in sterling, Irish pounds, or Gibraltar currency. The term "securities" includes certificates of deposit and treasury bills. 422 The authorized banks may deal among themselves and with residents and nonresidents in foreign notes and coin (other than Rhodesian currency) at free market rates of exchange. The United Kingdom formally accepted the obliga- tions of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Exchange Control Territory In general, the United Kingdom does not impose restrictions on exchange transactions or payments and receipts between residents of the United Kingdom and residents of the Scheduled Territories. Exchange control applies mainly to transactions with residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories. For administrative purposes, the non-Scheduled Territories are divided as follows: (1) the other member countries of the EEC, except the Republic of Ireland; (2) the Overseas Sterling Area (OSA), i.e., the countries other than the Republic of Ireland and Gibraltar which as at June 22, 1972 were treated as Scheduled Territories;4 (3) Rhodesia; and (4) all other countries, usually referred to as the Rest of the Non-Scheduled Territories (RNST). Administration of Control Exchange control in the United Kingdom is admin- istered by the Bank of England on behalf of the U.K. Treasury. However, practically all commercial banks are authorized to approve most current payments requiring exchange control permission. The licensing of imports and exports is handled mostly by the Depart- ment of Trade, but other departments also issue licenses in specialized fields. Prescription of Currency Receipts f rom Scheduled Territories may be obtained in sterling, Irish pounds, or Gibraltar currency; those from other countries, with the exception of Rhodesia, must be in sterling f rom an External Account or in any foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency), which must be offered for sale to an authorized bank unless permission has been given for the funds to be used for some other purpose. Settlements with Rhodesia are subject to special regu- lations generally prescribing the use of Rhodesian Accounts, Suspense Accounts, or, in certain circum- stances, the Rhodesian Special Account with the Stand- ard Bank, London. Nonresident Accounts The sterling accounts of residents of other Scheduled Territories are treated in the same way as those of residents of the United Kingdom. Rhodesian Accounts. These accounts are applicable to residents of Rhodesia only. Permitted credits include transfers f rom External Accounts, under the circum- stances described above; payments by residents of Scheduled Territories other than the United Kingdom to residents of Rhodesia, subject to the approval of the exchange control authority in the territory concerned; and payments by U.K. residents to residents of Rhodesia in respect of (1) the sale of foreign currencies other than Rhodesian currency, (2) the discount or maturity proceeds of U.K. Treasury bills, (3) permitted imports f rom Rhodesia which have entered customs in the United K ingdom, (4) insurance and freight charges resulting from permitted trade between Rhodesia and any Scheduled Territory, (5) insurance claims directly related to such permitted trade, (6) pensions and widows' annu i t ies where associated with the deceased husband's emp loymen t, (7) charges and fees relating to patents, designs, and trademarks registered in Malawi, Rhodesia, or Zambia, (8) ma tur i ty proceeds of certain endowment insurance policies, and (9) expenditure in gathering news material. Once import licensing requirements have been met, U.K. residents may purchase foreign currency, other than Rhodesian currency, or credit sterling to an Exter- nal Account to pay for the import, provided that evidence of customs entry is submitted or evidence is provided that the goods have been dispatched to the United Kingdom or are to be dispatched immediately on receipt of payment. Advance payments for imports are approved by the Bank of Eng land where the pay- ment is considered necessary or conforms to customary practice. Current adm in is tra t ive practice is not to allow advance payments for consumer goods. Exchange con- trol forms are not required for paymen ts to residents of the Scheduled Territories; neither are they requ ired for payments to residents of other countries, unless the payment represents part or final settlement for goods for which the total amount payable exceeds £5,000, and evidence of importation cannot be presented to the bank before mak ing the remittance. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to residents of other Sched- uled Territories may be made freely. Payments to residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories require exchange control authorization, which (except for payments to residents of Rhodesia)17 is granted freely for most purposes, subject to the presentation of supporting evidence. The completion of an exchange control fo rm is required for payments exceeding <£ 1,000 or its equivalent. Authorized banks are per- m i t ted to approve applications for transfers on account of m a ny categories of current invisibles without any l im i ta t ion, and for other categories up to established limits. Applications for payments in excess of these l im i ts or for purposes for which no delegation of au tho r i ty has been granted are approved by the Bank of England, provided that no unau thor ized capital out- flow is involved. Authorized banks may dispatch sterling banknotes to nonresidents except residents of Rhodesia against pay- ment in sterling from an External Account or in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. For any type of travel outside the Scheduled Terri- tories (except to Rhodesia), U.K. residents can obtain on demand from banks and authorized travel agents foreign exchange up to the equivalent of <£500 a person a trip; for travel for business or professional reasons, an allowance of £100 a day u p - to a max imum of 17 V i r tua l ly all current payments to Rhodesia are prohibited, except when these result f rom perm i t ted trade in goods.
