For approved official and essential business journeys the Bank of England will authorize the issue of foreign currency at a rate of up to £ 10 a day with a maximum of £300. Facilities for private travel are authorized only where there are compassionate grounds. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are subject to licensing control and licenses are normally issued only for the permitted exceptions, such as medical and educational supplies, foods tu f fs in special human i tar ian circumstances, and newsfilm, photographs, and printed matter (not more than 70 years old), and for equipment for the essential replacement needs of - the Rhodesian Railways, the Wankie Colliery, and the Central Afr ican Power Corpo- ration. Virtually all exports to other destinations are free of export control and no exchange control forms 425 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM are normally required. Exporters to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia must normally obtain appropriate payment within six months of shipment; special exchange control permission to collect at a later date is required only where the exporter extends credit for more than six months with- out cover from the Export Credits Guarantee Depart- ment (ECGD). Receipts in foreign currencies must be offered for sale to an authorized bank unless the recipient has obtained specific permission to credit them to a retained currency account (subject to supervision) or. permission has been given for them to be used for some other purpose. Permitted exports to Rhodesia must be paid for prior to shipment in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency or, if specific permission is granted by the Bank of England, in sterling f rom the Rhodesian Special Account. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts in foreign currencies on account of invisibles must be offered for sale to an authorized bank, unless recipients have permission to credit them to a retained currency account or to use them for some other purpose. British and other banknotes may be brought into the United Kingdom freely. Capital Residents of the United Kingdom who receive foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency from certain capital account sources (mainly the sale or redemption of foreign currency securities held for portfolio invest- ment purposes and the sale of personal residential prop- erty situated outside the Scheduled Territories) may, in certain circumstances and with permission, use the exchange (which is regarded as investment currency once permission has been given)18-19 for the purchase of marketable foreign currency securities, the purchase of personal residential property outside the Scheduled Ter- ritories, or the making of approved direct investments outside the Scheduled Territories; they may also sell the exchange for sterling to other residents to be used for the same purposes. If permission is not forthcoming, the foreign currency must be offered for sale at the rates ruling in the official market to an authorized bank in the United Kingdom. In certain circumstances, residents of the United Kingdom who possess the nationality or citizenship of a country outside the Sched- uled Territories or, in some cases, who are former residents of OSA countries but do not possess such nationality or citizenship may be granted exemption from certain of their obligations under the Exchange 18 Where currency is received f rom the sale of residential real estate by residents of other Scheduled Territories, permission may also be given for such f u n ds to be regarded as investment currency. 19 The full amount of the foreign currency proceeds is normally per- mitted to be sold as investment currency when the whole of a residential property that has been held for private use is sold; when it has been held as an investment, however, the proceeds are not normally eligible to be treated as investment currency. 426 Control Act in respect of assets denominated in a foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. There are no restrictions on capital transfers by residents of the United Kingdom into the beneficial ownership of residents of other Scheduled Territories. All capital transfers by residents to countries outside the Scheduled Territories require approval. Each indi- vidual resident of the United Kingdom may, from his own resources, make cash gifts or personal loans not exceeding a total of <£ 1,500, or the equivalent in foreign currency, during each calendar year to residents of any non-Scheduled Territory except Rhodesia. In addition, there is a fu r ther allowance of £1,500 a donor a calen- dar year to recipients in EEC countries. Further amounts may be allowed under appropriate circumstances, for example, by way of a dowry. Allowances for cash gifts are noncumulative and are not transferable from one resident to another. A resident of the United Kingdom with dependents who are established residents of coun- tries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rho- desia may make payments from his own resources not exceeding £2,000 a calendar year to support those dependents. Such payments, which may be gifts or loans, are outside the cash g ift scheme and do not prejudice the normal cash g i ft allowances. No capital transfers are allowed to Rhodesia, whether in the form of direct investment or of the purchase of Rhodesian securities, or by any other means, except to relatives, or other Rhodesian residents where humani- tarian reasons are given, to the extent of .£75 during any period of two years. For direct investments in non-Scheduled Territories, other than Rhodesia, official exchange is normally made available only for certain projects directly concerned with promoting exports of goods and services where the prospective benefit to the U.K. balance of payments is expected to equal or exceed the total cost of the invest- ment within 18 months (three years for direct investment in other EEC countries) and to continue thereafter; this benefit will normally occur by way of additional export receipts, but may also arise from profits and other foreign currency receipts that would not take place without the investment. For such projects ("super- criterion" projects), official exchange may be made available up to £250,000 (£500,000 for direct invest- ment in other EEC countries) or 50 per cent of the total investment, whichever is larger; any balance must be financed by foreign currency borrowing, the use of investment currency, the export without payment of capital equipment and stock-in-trade of U.K. manu- facture forming an integral part of the investment, by the issue or transfer of shares to nonresidents on appropriate terms, by the capitalization of an overseas subsidiary's current account indebtedness to the U.K. parent company on appropriate terms, by approved profit retention, or with foreign currency proceeds of disinvestment in the context of a group reorganization. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Direct investment other than for "super-criterion" projects is considered on the basis that its capital cost should not fa ll directly upon the U.K. official foreign exchange reserves until an equivalent amount has been received in the United Kingdom by way of benefits arising from the investments; such investments can normally be financed by foreign currency borrowing, the use of investment currency, the export without pay- ment of capital equipment and stock-in-trade of U.K. manu fac tu re forming an integral part of the investment, by the issue or transfer of shares to nonresidents on appropriate terms, by the capitalization of an overseas subsidiary's current account indebtedness to the U.K. parent company on appropriate terms, by approved profit retention, or with foreign currency proceeds of disinvestment in the context of a group reorganization. The permitted proportion of retained foreign currency earn ings normally is one third of net earn ings after taxes, applied, if desired, on a global basis where more than one subsidiary is involved. Applicants for per- mission to make an ou tward direct investment are requ ired to provide details of estimated benefits follow- ing the proposed investment. If the "super-criterion" is to be considered, details of benefits received du r ing the prev ious year are required, together w i th ha lf-year ly figures for the ensuing 18 months (annual figures for the ensiling three years in the case of investments in other EEC countries) and conf irma t ion that benefits are expected to con t inue thereaf ter. In add i t ion, investors seeking permission to repay foreign currency borrow ings taken to finance ou tward direct investments are expected to show, where possible, that the benefits received derive f rom the par t icu lar in jec t ion of capital financed by the foreign currency borrowing be ing repa id. The purchase outside the Scheduled Territories of marke tab le foreign currency securities for po r t fo l io inves tment must be financed either with inves tment currency or w i th fo re ign currency bo r row ing. Such bo r row ing is freely pe rm i t ted when unde r taken by or th rough U.K. professional security managers. Foreign currency loans taken up to purchase quo ted securities issued by the EEC, the European Inves tment Bank, the European Coal and Steel Commun i ty, and the European Atomic Energy Commun i ty may be repaid w i th official exchange over a five-year period. Purchases of marke t- able foreign currency securities w i th inves tment currency are f ree ly permitted by v i r tue of cer ta in general permis- sions gran ted to banks, stockbrokers, and other author- ized depositaries. Purchases f rom other res iden ts may also be effected with sterling on the Stock Exchange (sterling prices reflect the p reva i l ing inves tment currency premium). The purchase by U.K. residents of a house or an apartment for personal use in coun t r ies outside the Scheduled Territories requ ires specific approval and must be made either f rom another Scheduled Territory resident for sterling or another Scheduled Territory UNITED KINGDOM currency, or from a nonresident of the Scheduled Ter- ritories with investment currency; payment for attendant expenses and improvements, but not maintenance, must also be made with investment currency. (As an excep- tion to this rule, residents temporarily employed in member countries of the EEC may be authorized to purchase necessary accommodation at current official market rates of exchange.) Approval is normally limited to one property a family; purchases of investment currency are normally limited to reasonable amounts and may be made before exchange control approval is received, provided that the funds are held by an author- ized depositary and that a formal application is lodged to purchase the property within six months. The approval authority for amounts up to £30,000 for a residential property has been delegated to authorized banks. All proceeds from the realization, redemption, or m a tu r i ty of sterling capital assets (including direct invest- ments) owned by nonresidents of the Scheduled Terri- tories other than residents of Rhodesia are remittable at the official market rate of exchange. Payments to non- resident beneficiaries, other than Rhodesian residents, are au thor ized freely in respect of inheritances due f rom the estates of deceased residents; capital payments under l i fe and other insurance policies taken up by nonresidents with resident insurance companies are also authorized freely. Residents of the United Kingdom who leave with the in ten t ion of residing for at least three years in a country outside the Scheduled Territories and apply to transfer the ir assets are, on their departure f rom the United K ingdom, regarded for exchange control purposes as nonresidents, and, with the following exceptions, their assets are treated accordingly. Repatriates (non-Sched- uled Territory na t iona ls or citizens, other than Rhode- sians, who having been resident in the United Kingdom re tu rn to take up residence in any country outside the Scheduled Territories) may normally transfer all their sterling assets abroad at the official market rate of exchange. Other residents leaving to take up residence in countries outside the Scheduled Territories except Rhodesia are allowed on departure to t ran s fer for a fam i ly un it up to £40,000 (£80,000 for emigration to ano ther EEC country) through the official foreign exchange market, and may export any foreign currency securities they hold; the rema in ing declared assets in excess of £40,000 or £80,000, as appropriate, are restricted for a four-year period f rom the date of the depar t ing person's redesignation as a nonresident. U.K. residents tak ing up residence and employment in mem- ber countries of the EEC, however, may, with specific approval, t ran s fer sterling assets at the official market rate of exchange in excess of the £80,000 limit where this is necessary in order to ensure their freedom to take up the employment in question. 427 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM During the four-year period the restricted funds may be disposed of for foreign currencies other than Rhode- sian currency through the investment currency market, may be invested in sterling securities which are quoted on the Stock Exchange—the income therefrom being freely remittable through the official exchange market— or may be used, with general or specific permission, to meet certain expenses in the United Kingdom. Af ter the four-year period any remaining assets are transfer- able in accordance with the rules then applicable to the assets of a nonresident; at present, the transfer at the official market rate of exchange is normally allowed. The participation of foreign capital as a direct invest- ment in the United Kingdom is subject to individual authorization, which is normally granted, provided that adequate capital for the project is supplied in an approved manner of payment (see section on Prescrip- tion of Currency, above) or by the import of goods and services; the foreign currency received must be sur- rendered at rates ruling in the official market unless permission has been given for the funds to be used for some other purpose. Cases involving the takeover of existing companies that by their size or nature constitute a vital part of British industry are considered on their merits. Permissions given for direct investments in the United Kingdom by nonresidents are normally, unless otherwise agreed with the Bank of England, conditional on the consideration being paid in sterling from an External Account or in foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) and, where the company is a vehicle for portfolio investment in securities or property, on any subsequent finance being provided in foreign currency or External Account sterling at least in proportion to the nonresident interest in the equity of the company. The acquisition in any manner by any person not resident in the United Kingdom of 10 per cent or more of.the outstanding shares of a quoted company registered in the United Kingdom requires prior exchange control approval. Nonresident firms and individuals must obtain exchange control permission in order to raise capital in the United Kingdom, and all U.K. resident companies are required to obtain consent before issuing shares or other securities to nonresidents. U.K. residents also need permission to lend funds to U.K. companies controlled by nonresidents and U.K. companies controlled by nonresidents require permission to raise finance by way of bills of exchange, promissory notes, or certain other instruments. Such permission is normally given without restriction for sterling lending for the company's business in the United Kingdom, except where the borrower is a vehicle for portfolio investment in securities or property. U.K. banks are prohibited f rom prov id ing sterling loans or overdraf ts to persons resident outside the Scheduled Territories for the purpose of financing trade between non-Scheduled Territories. Similarly, U.K. merchants, except certain commodity traders, may not 428 finance such trade in sterling. They are, however, allowed to do so with foreign currency borrowed for the purpose. Borrowing by U.K. residents from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories to finance expenditure in the United Kingdom is subject to restrictions. Private sector U.K. residents other than authorized banks nor- mally are not permitted to borrow foreign currency from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories for conversion into sterling for use in the United Kingdom, or to finance current payments to nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories, unless the term of borrowing is at least two years; exporters, merchants, and certain com- modity traders are, however, permitted to borrow foreign currency for shorter periods from authorized banks or from nonresidents to finance their sales or, in some cases, stockholdings. Public sector entities nor- mally are not permitted to borrow foreign currency unless the term of the foreign borrowing is at least five years; for permitted foreign currency borrowing they may avail themselves of exchange cover provided by the Treasury. Authorized banks must not lend foreign cur- rency to U.K. residents (other than authorized banks) for any other purpose without prior reference to the Bank of England. U.K. companies normally are not permitted to borrow External Account sterling from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories unless the term of the borrowing is at least two years. Under certain permissions delegated to authorized depositaries, transactions in quoted securities of most types may generally be carried out freely between resi- dents of the United Kingdom, except that transactions which involve loss of U.K. voting control of a company, because the purchaser is itself nonresident-controlled, require Bank of England consent, and transactions in Rhodesian securities may only be effected on the Stock Exchange. Residents are normally permitted, subject to certain conditions, to sell foreign currency securities outside the Scheduled Territories, and, in respect of those held for portfolio investment purposes, to reinvest the proceeds (investment currency) in marketable foreign currency securities, or to sell the exchange to other residents for sucb investments or for certain approved direct investment or approved purchases of property for private use outside the Scheduled Territories. The pro- ceeds of sale of foreign currency securities held as direct investments must be sold at the official market rate of exchange or, where appropriate, may, with Bank of England permission, be retained in foreign currency for use for further outward direct investments in the context of a group reorganization. Investment currency may normally be retained as investment currency for a maxi- mum of 12 months, after which period any amount remaining must be offered for sale to an authorized ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution bank at the current market rate in the official foreign exchange market.20 Professional security managers acting on their own behalf and for clients are permitted, subject to certain conditions, to borrow foreign currency for the purpose of making portfolio investments in marketable foreign currency securities. U.K. jobbers and other security dealers may, with permission, arrange day-to-day bor- rowing of foreign currency, whether from U.K. banks or from nonresidents, to finance a "book" in foreign currency securities, but not to finance holdings of such securities as investments. Residents of other Scheduled Territories are not pre- vented by the U.K. regulations f rom buy ing and selling sterling securities in the United Kingdom; they may also buy and sell, subject to certain conditions, Rhodesian securities on the Stock Exchange, but they must obtain the permission of the U.K. authorities to buy and sell other foreign currency securities in the United Kingdom. Permission is required for all transfers of securities in the United Kingdom in which a nonresident of the Scheduled Territories is involved as either t rans fe ror or transferee, but most transfers are covered by a general authority. In most cases, U.K. companies may issue sterling securities (including bearer securities) under a general permission given by the U.K. authorities. Nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories except Rhodesian residents may buy sterling securities on the Stock Exchange against payment in foreign currency or in sterling from an External Account. Securities so purchased may be exported from the United Kingdom. Foreign currency securities may be bought and sold by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories on the Stock Exchange for settlement in foreign currency or, in cer- tain circumstances, for settlement in sterling excluding the investment currency premium. Nonresidents must obtain permission to buy and sell securities in the United Kingdom other than through the medium of a professional dealer in securities, whether or not the securities are quoted on a stock exchange. Nonresidents other than Rhodesian residents may sell sterling securi- ties on the Stock Exchange for sterling which may be held on External Account or, alternatively, may be transferred abroad at official market rates. Most trans- actions in securities by or on behalf of residents of Rhodesia require the specific approval of the Bank of England; subject to certain conditions, however, author- ized banks may approve applications by or on behalf of residents of Rhodesia to buy and sell sterling securities on the Stock Exchange. Except in respect of U.K. companies controlled by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories (where Bank of England consent is required), warrants issued by 20 Investment currency may be invested temporarily in short-term gov- e rnment bonds (w i th up to six mon ths to run before final m a tu r i ty) or in six-month treasury bills or other fo rms of recognized short-term money-market paper (including certificates of deposit). UNITED KINGDOM registrars, company secretaries, and paying agents in respect of interest, dividends, and capital payments on securities registered in the names of nonresidents other than Rhodesian residents may be dispatched freely to addresses outside the Scheduled Territories. These war- rants may be paid by crediting sterling to an External Account. Authorized banks may freely accept foreign currency deposits and employ them in their foreign currency busi- ness. They may also switch such deposits into sterling on a covered basis. Individual ceilings are set on each bank's overall open position in foreign currencies and on the amount of spot assets which may be held against forward liabilities in foreign currencies. Gold Gold bullion and gold coin are subject to control in the United Kingdom. Exemption under the Exchange Control Act, 1947 exists for (1) the buying, selling, lending, and borrowing of gold coin minted in or before 1937; (2) the buying and selling of any gold coin minted a f ter 1937 and held in the United Kingdom, if the seller is a person resident in the United Kingdom and is not selling on behalf of a person resident outside the United Kingdom; (3) the buying and selling of any gold coin minted af ter 1937 and held in the United Kingdom if the buyer and seller are both persons resident in the United Kingdom; and (4) the borrowing and lending of any gold coin minted after 1937 and held in the United Kingdom, if both the borrower and the lender are per- sons resident in the United Kingdom. Transactions both in gold coin not exempted above and in gold bullion may only be undertaken with permission. Permission is normally given for the use of gold bullion for genuine industrial and professional purposes. The sale of gold bullion for the manu fac tu re of gold coin, gold medals, etc., is prohibited unless specially authorized. Gold sovereigns are legal tender but do not circulate in the United Kingdom. Gold coins which are legal tender have also been issued in Jersey and the Isle of Man. Except under license granted by the Treasury, it is an offense to melt down or break up any metal coin which is for the time being current in the United King- dom or which, having been current there, has at any time after May 16, 1969 ceased to be so. Bulk imports of gold coins, certain gold coins of numismatic interest minted af ter 1937, and gold medals, medallions, tablets, or other pieces in pictorial relief or bearing inscriptions and manufac tured after 1937, other than those of limited weight and value, are subject to individual import licensing, and such licenses are nor- mally given only to authorized dealers in gold. The export of gold bullion and all gold coins requires prior exchange control approval. The export of gold bullion and of post-1937 gold coins to Gibraltar and the Republic of Ireland is not normally permitted except with the approval of the local control authorities. Authority has been given to authorized 429 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM dealers in gold to issue licenses in respect of exports of gold bullion and coin purchased by any non-Scheduled Territory resident in the London gold market against payment in External Account sterling or foreign cur- rency. A license is required f rom the Department of Trade for the export of gold (and other) jewelry, etc., containing diamonds. The export of gold in manu fac- tured fo rm over 100 years old and valued at £4,000 and over also requires a license from the Department of Trade. Manufac tures of gold other than medals, etc., manu- factured after 1937 may be imported without quantita- tive restriction under Open General Import License f rom all sources except Rhodesia. There is a free gold market in London in which gold bars are freely traded among (1) authorized dealers in gold, and (2) any nonresidents of the Scheduled Terri- tories. The U.K. authorities do not intervene in the market as either buyers or sellers. A commission of 0.25 per cent is charged on all purchases; there is no commission on sales. Authorized banks may enter into forward transactions in gold without prior permission from the Bank of England. Banks may also finance purchases of gold by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories by lending foreign exchange and may accept gold as collateral for advances in foreign currencies or External Account sterling to nonresidents of the Sched- uled Territories. Changes during 1978 In addition to the changes listed below, certain changes in quantitative import regulations were made in accordance with EEC decisions, directives, and regula- tions; most of these related to textiles. January 1. New quota levels for imports f rom coun- tries in the State Trading Area came into effect; subse- quently, there were several modifications. January 31. Quotas on imports of certain steel prod- ucts from Romania were established for the first half of 1978. The restrictions were removed on August 4. March 24. The ban on imports of certain iron and steel products from the U.S.S.R. was replaced by a quota of 7,500 tons to the end of June; subsequently, the quota was extended to the end of 1978 at an annual level of 15,000 tons. April 1. It was announced that British exporters would no longer have access to concessionary finance for goods sold to other EEC members on credit terms of two years or more. April 10. Surveillance licensing was introduced for certain cutlery products. June 29. The limits up to which banks might author- ize, without reference to the Bank of England, payments abroad were raised. The increases were for a variety of purposes ranging from advertising expenses to income tax. June 29. Institutional investors investing in foreign currency securities issued by investment trusts, unit trusts, mu tual funds, or other investment bodies whose principal purpose was portfolio investment in securities, land, or property were no longer restricted as to the amount of their assets which might be held in such foreign currency securities. The 20 per cent limit on the acquisition of foreign currency securities carrying voting rights remained. August 16. Authorized depositaries were authorized to effect sales of most foreign currency securities held in restricted deposit, without reference to the Bank of England. Also, dividends on U.K. residents' holdings of foreign currency securities received in stock would, in fu tu re, take on the character of the underlying hold- ing without the requirement to effect a compensatory transaction in the investment currency market. August 22. Import quotas on certain iron and steel products originating in Bulgaria and the German Demo- cratic Republic were established for 1978. September 12. A relaxation of controls on U.K. residents buying low fineness gold for industrial purposes was introduced. 430 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES (Position on December 31,1978) Exchange Rate System The currency of the United States is the U.S. Dollar. The U.S. authorities do not maintain margins in respect of exchange transactions, and spot and forward exchange rates are determined on the basis of demand and supply conditions in the exchange markets. However, the authorities intervene when necessary to counter dis- orderly conditions in the exchange markets; in recent years such intervention has been confined to the spot market. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. The United States formally notified the Fund on December 10, 1946 that it was prepared to accept the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control The Treasury Department deals w i th license applica- tions involving financial or commercial transactions directly or indirectly with Cuba, Democratic Kampuchea, Nor th Korea, Rhodesia, and Viet Nam or their nationals, as specified under the Foreign Assets Control Regula- tions, the Cuban Assets Control Regulations, and the Rhodesian Sanctions Regulations. It also has adminis- trative responsibility for blocked accounts of the above countries (except Rhodesia) as well as accounts of the People's Republic of China blocked under the Foreign Assets Control Regulations as of May 6, 1971 and accounts of Czechoslovakia, Estonia, the German Demo- cratic Republic, Latvia, and L i thuan ia, blocked since World War II under the Foreign Funds Control Regu- lations. It also adm in is ters the import restrictions imposed with respect to Uganda under Section 5(c) of Public Law 95-435. The Customs Service of the Treasury Department administers import quotas; such quotas, however, are generally established and allocated by other agencies. Import quotas on specified da i ry products are administered by the Department of Agriculture th rough the issuance of import licenses. A global import quota on sugar has been ma in ta ined since 1974 at a nonrestrictive level of 7 m i l l ion short tons annua l ly. Allocations and licenses for imports of crude petroleum and petroleum products are issued by the Depar tment of the Interior. For items sub ject to export control— other than crude petroleum and petroleum products— the Department of Commerce is, in general, the respon- sible authority. There are no restrictions on fore ign paymen ts, except those imposed for security reasons on transactions invo lv ing the authorities or na t iona ls of the People's Republic of Ch ina, Cuba, Democratic Kampuchea, No r th Korea, and Viet Nam, and those imposed pur- suant to UN Security Council Resolutions Nos. 232 and 253 with regard to Rhodesia. Most current trans- actions involving the People's Republic of China are authorized, except those involving strategic goods or assets of the People's Republic of China which were blocked as of May 6, 1971.1 Payments restrictions in respect of Cuba were eased to permit payments for support of relatives in Cuba, for purposes of cultural exchange, and for purposes of travel to and in the United States by Cuban nationals. Payments restrictions in respect of Viet Nam were eased for purposes of support remittances to close relatives. Imports and Import Payments Imports of Cuban, Kampuchean, North Korean, Rhodesian, Ugandan, and Vietnamese origin are pro- hibited under Treasury regulations, unless specifically licensed. Import quotas are in effect for (1) cotton, certain cotton waste and products, most dairy products, and peanuts; (2) certain fish and certain potatoes (tariff-rate quotas); (3) sugar; (4) certain types of meat; and (5) stain- less steel and alloy tool steel products. Among the quan t i ta t ive import quotas, all except those for peanuts, certain cotton and cotton products, butter oil, and sugar are on a country-of-production basis. In addition, imports of crude petroleum and petroleum products are subject to an import entitlement program, and import license fees. Certain dairy products which are subject to quotas are also subject to import licensing. The United States is a party to the GATT Arrange- ment Regarding International Trade in Textiles and to 18 bilateral textile agreements negotiated under the Arrangement's provisions. These agreements set the levels for the partners' exports of textiles and apparel to the United States. In 1978 the United States nego- tiated new bilateral textile and apparel agreements with five of these countries (Colombia, Mexico, the Philip- pines, Singapore, and Thailand). These agreements were negotiated in accordance with the terms of the Arrangement. The agreements provide for orderly expansion of trade while at the same time recognizing U.S. concerns in import-impacted categories. As of the end of 1978, no l im i ta t ions were applied to imports of crude petroleum and petroleum products, but these were generally subject to import licenses and import license fees. Imports of fresh, frozen, or chilled beef, veal, mu t ton, and goat's meat are restricted through voluntary res tra int agreements (12 bilateral agreements and one memo randum of unde r s tand ing ), as an alternative to the imposition of manda to ry quotas under the Meat Import 1 On Ma rch 2, 1979 the T reasu ry Department announced that a claims se t t lement agreement w i th the People's Republic of China had been initialed. The United States agreed to unblock the assets of the People's Repub l ic of China and of its nationals by October 1, 1979. 431 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES Act of 1964. Imports of a number of manufactured products are also effectively restricted by bilateral agree- ments designed to provide temporary relief to certain distressed industries (shoes, televisions, and specialty steels). Exports and Export Proceeds Munitions may be exported only under license issued by the Office of Munitions Control in the Department of State. Licenses are not granted for exports of arms and ammunition to the People's Republic of China, Cuba, Eastern Europe, Democratic Kampuchea, North Korea, South Africa, the U.S.S.R., and Viet Nam. Licenses are required for exports of crime control and detection equipment to all countries except other members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), Australia, Japan, and New Zealand. The Department of Com- merce administers controls on exports directly from the United States and on reexports of goods of U.S. origin from any area. (The Treasury Department administers controls on exports to certain areas of goods of foreign origin by foreign firms that are owned or controlled by U.S. nationals.) Most exports to Rhodesia require licenses, and generally no licenses are issued except for educa- tional, medical, or human i tar ian items. All exports to Cuba, Democratic Kampuchea, North Korea, and Viet Nam (except phonograph records, publications, and, to Cuba, limited gift parcels) are subject to individual validated licenses. Exports of designated strategic ma- terials and equipment to all other countries (except Canada) also require individual validated licenses. For many commodities, when exported to countries other than members of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CMEA), certain Arab states, Cuba, Demo- cratic Kampuchea, Nor th Korea, and Viet Nam, single distribution licenses may be obtained to cover a fu ll year's shipment. The licensing requirements applicable to Poland, Romania, and Yugoslavia are less restrictive than those applicable to other Eastern European coun- tries. From time to time, exports of certain commodities to all destinations have been subject to controls for reasons of short supply. Export arrangements for wheat, corn, sorghum, soybeans, and soybean oil are subject to reporting requirements in order to avoid the need for controls. The proceeds of exports are not subject to exchange control. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles The t rans fer of funds to Rhodesia is permitted only under licenses which are gran ted only for medical, educational, or human i ta r ian purposes. Other payments and transfers abroad may be made free ly, except for payments to or for the account of the authorities or nationals of Cuba, Democratic Kampuchea, Nor th Korea, and Viet Nam, which also are permitted only 432 under license. However, as of January 4, 1978, U.S. residents are allowed to remit up to US$500 a quarter to close relatives in Cuba and US$300 a quarter to close relatives in Viet Nam. In addition, remittances of up to US$500 to Cuba and US$750 to Viet Nam are allowed to aid in a relative's emigration from those countries, and specific licenses are available for certain transactions in connection with cultural exchanges be- tween the United States and Cuba. Receipts from Cuba, Democratic Kampuchea, North Korea, Rhodesia, and Viet Nam are prohibited, except for travel receipts from Cuban nationals visiting the United States. Individuals leaving or entering the country with more than US$5,000 in domestic or foreign currency, travelers checks, money orders, and /or bearer-form negotiable securities must declare these to the customs at the point of exit or entry. Capital Incoming or outgoing capital payments by residents or nonresidents are not subject to exchange control. In addition, inward and outward direct or portfolio invest- ment is generally free of any other form of approval requirements. Investments involving ownership interest in banks are subject to federal and state banking regula- tions. However, as noted above, there are restrictions on certain transactions with, or involving, Cuba, Demo- cratic Kampuchea, North Korea, Rhodesia, and Viet Nam, and there are certain reporting requirements for travelers entering or leaving the country when they are carrying in excess of US$5,000 in cash or negotiable instruments (as well as corresponding reporting require- ments for shipment of currency or bearer assets through the mails). In addition, as of October 25, 1978, owner- ship of U.S. farmland by foreign nationals must be registered with the Federal Government. On August 28, 1978, the reserve requirement on Federal Reserve member banks' net Eurodollar borrow- ings from their foreign branches and from foreign banks was reduced from 4 per cent to zero per cent. In addition, the reserve requirement that a head office of a member bank must hold against deposits that its foreign branches use for lending to U.S. nonbank resi- dents was reduced from 1 per cent to zero. Also, an earlier request of the Federal Reserve Board was with- drawn. Under this request nonmember banks that are majority-owned by foreign banks and U.S. agencies and branches of foreign banks would have voluntarily main- tained reserves against increases above May 1973 levels in certain net liabilities to (or reductions in net claims on) foreign banks. Member banks are discouraged by the Federal Reserve Board from soliciting or encourag- ing placement of deposits by U.S. residents at their foreign branches, unless such deposits are placed to serve a definite, necessary purpose outside the United States. The foreign currency positions of banks, whether overall or with respect to individual currencies, are not subject to regulations or regulatory limitation. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Gold U.S. citizens or residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad, except for certain gold transactions (e.g., imports or exports) involv- ing Cuba, Democratic Kampuchea, North Korea, Rho- desia, Uganda, and Viet Nam. Commercial banks may deal in gold bullion and gold coin, with the same ex- ceptions. Treasury licensing for importers, exporters, producers, refiners, and processors of gold is not re- quired, with the same country exceptions. Producers of gold may sell their output in the free market, with the same country exceptions. Gold may be freely imported except from the countries mentioned above and except counterfeit gold coins. U.S. gold coins are legal tender at their face value. Commercial imports of gold jewelry are free of quantitative restriction but are subject to import du ty at a rate of approximately 12 per cent. There is no duty on gold ore, bullion, or coin. All forms of gold must be declared at the point of entry into the United States. Changes during 1978 January 4. The Treasury Department announced it would allow residents to remit up to US$500 a quarter to close relatives in Cuba and US$300 a quarter to relatives in Viet Nam. Remittances to those countries had previously been banned. In addition, remittances of up to US$500 to Cuba and US$750 to Viet Nam would be allowed to aid in a relative's emigration f rom those countries. January 5. It was determined that exports of butter cookies from Denmark were being subsidized by 30 per cent and were subject to countervailing duties by the United States; however, countervailing duties were waived. (Under the Trade Act of 1974, Congress gave the Treasury Department authority under certain condi- tions to waive countervailing duties. This authority was scheduled to expire on January 3, 1979, at which point the Treasury Department would be required to impose all of the duties that had been waived during the previous four years.) January 12. The United States concluded a new three-year textile agreement with Poland covering the period January 1, 1978-December 31, 1980. January 18. The President decided to continue, with slight modification, the import quotas on specialty steel products in effect under Section 201 of the Trade Act of 1974. January 24. The Treasury Department imposed countervailing duties of 12.5 per cent on imports of iron and steel chains from Spain. January 30. The Treasury Department determined that exports of handbags, nonrubber footwear, and leather apparel from Uruguay were being subsidized by UNITED STATES 17.4 per cent, 23 per cent, and approximately 12 per cent, respectively. Handbags and nonrubber footwear were subject to countervailing duties. Initially these duties were waived but the waiver was revoked on November 13 and duties were imposed. The leather apparel case was sent to the International Trade Com- mission (ITC) for determination of in jury because imports were entering the United States duty free. The ITC found in ju ry. February 16. The Department of Commerce intro- duced new export regulations imposing an embargo on shipments of products and unpublished technical data for use by military or police organizations in South A f r ica and Namibia. February 17. The Treasury Department ruled that imports of railway track maintenance equipment from Austria were being dumped. February 21. The Treasury Department's ''trigger- price mechanism" for steel imports took effect. Under the program imports of steel mill products'were moni- tored at ports of entry and their prices were compared with "trigger prices" calculated from the cost of pro- ducing steel by the most efficient exporting country ( Japan ). Trigger prices subsequently were increased on July 1 and October 1. March 1. By an executive order issued on February 25 the list of products covered by the U.S. Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) was modified. A total of 320 products were designated as ineligible for duty-free treatment when imported f rom specified developing countries; at the same time 121 products from specified countries were redesignated as eligible for duty-free treatment. GSP treatment was extended to 11 items that had not previously been designated as eligible, while 1 product was deleted f rom the list of eligible imports. March 27. A Presidential proclamation temporarily raised tar iffs on citizens band transceivers f rom the previous rate of 6 per cent to 21 per cent in 1978, 18 per cent in 1979, and 15 per cent in 1980. The product was also removed from GSP eligibility. April 1. The Arrangement on Officially Supported Export Credits became effective. This agreement, among the United States and other members of the Organiza- tion for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), established guidelines designed to curb inter- national competition on extending government-supported export credits. The agreement replaced the unilateral declaration by the United States and six other countries (which subsequently was adopted by most other OECD countries) that had been in effect since July 1976. The Treasury Department determined that exports of handbags f rom Colombia were being sub- sidized and were subject to countervailing duties in the United States; however, countervailing duties were waived. 433 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES May 9. The Treasury Department issued regulations authorizing payment of travel expenses by Cuban nationals visiting the United States. It also published a statement of licensing policy announcing that specific licenses would be available for certain transactions in connection with cultural exchanges between the United States and Cuba. May 23. The Treasury Department instituted monthly gold auctions. From May through October, the Treasury sold 300,000 ounces of gold a month in exchange for U.S. dollars. The gold was available to U.S. citizens and foreigners (except foreign governments or central banks). In November, monthly gold sales were increased to 750,000 ounces and in December to 1,500,000 ounces. May 25. The Treasury Department ruled that imports of impression fabric f rom Japan were being dumped in the United States. May 30. The Treasury Department ruled that imports of carbon steel plate from Japan were being dumped in the United States. June 8. The United States concluded a new three-year textile agreement with Malaysia covering the period January 1, 1978-December 31, 1980. June 8. It was announced that the importation of an additional 200 million pounds of beef would be allowed in 1978 in an effort to slow the rise in beef prices. Under a voluntary restraint program, imports of beef in 1978 had previously been limited to 1,292 million pounds. June 15. The Treasury Department announced a new method of calculating countervailing duties on rebates of certain indirect taxes. As a result, the countervailing duties on imports of bottled green olives and nonrubber footwear from Spain were reduced. On August 29, however, the Treasury Department announced its inten- tions to review its new procedure. The original assess- ments had been made in 1974 and 1975, respectively. June 16. The Treasury Department determined that exports of certain fish f rom Canada were being sub- sidized. Countervailing duties were waived. Because some of these products were eligible for duty-free import, the imposition of countervailing duties would require an affirmative finding of in ju ry and that portion of the case was referred to the ITC. On September 19 the ITC ruled that imports of duty-free fish from Canada were not causing in ju ry to domestic industry and that portion of the case was closed. June 30. The Treasury Department ruled that imports of polyvinyl chloride from the Republic of China were being dumped in the United States. July 5. The Department of Commerce announced increased restrictions on exports of crime control and detection equipment, requiring licenses for all shipments except to other member countries of the NATO, Australia, Japan, and New Zealand. Previously, licenses were required only for exports to Eastern European 434 countries, the Republic of China, Namibia, South Africa, and the U.S.S.R. July 31. The Department of Commerce announced that the U.S.S.R. had been added to the list of countries (Cuba, Democratic Kampuchea, North Korea, Rhodesia, and Viet Nam) to which exports of oil and gas equip- ment and technology required a license. August 9. The Treasury Department amended its regulation for determinirig when sales in the United States have been made at less than fa ir value by nonmarket economies. The Treasury announced that, when pos- sible, it would use the prices of comparable products in market-oriented countries at similar levels of develop- ment. When such comparisons were not available, how- ever, the Treasury would estimate the cost of production by using the monetary value of the inputs in a market- oriented economy at a similar level of development. Finally, if the second approach were not feasible, the Treasury would use the price of such or similar mer- chandise produced and sold by a market-oriented country. August 24. The Treasury Department determined that exports of iron and steel chain from Japan were being subsidized and imposed countervailing duties of 2 per cent. August 28. The Federal Reserve Board announced changes in reserve requirements aimed at strengthening the U.S. dollar by encouraging member banks to sub- stitute Eurodollar borrowing for domestic borrowing. The changes involved a reduction from 4 per cent to zero in the reserve requirement on foreign borrowing of member banks from their foreign branches and other foreign banks, and a reduction from 1 per cent to zero in the reserve requirement on foreign branch loans to U.S. borrowers. September 8. The President made a determination under Section 101 (b) of Public Law 95-223 extending for one year the authority of Section 5(b) of the Trading with the Enemy Act with respect to countries affected by the Foreign Assets Control Regulations, the Cuban Assets Control Regulations, the Foreign Funds Control Regulations, and the Transactions Control Regulations. September 17. The International Banking Act of 1978 was signed into law. The new law, which represented the first overall regulatory scheme for the participation of foreign banks in the U.S. domestic market, sought to implement national treatment of foreign and domestic banks. The law provided, inter alia, that branches and agencies of foreign banks might have federal charters (previously they were limited to state charters); that the Federal Reserve Board was legally authorized to set reserve ratios and apply other monetary policy regula- tions for both federal and state branches and agencies ©International Monetary Fund. Several sections of the Act required the issuance of regulations, which would be published for public comment. October 10. Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA (Position on December 31,1978) Exchange Rate System The currency of Upper Volta is the CFA Franc,1 which is pegged to the French franc, the intervention currency, at the fixed rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02. The official buying and selling rates are CFAF 50 = F 1. Exchange rates for other currencies are derived from the rate for the currency concerned in the Paris exchange market and the fixed rate between the French f ranc and the CFA franc. These rates include a banking commission. The BCEAO levies a commission of 0.10 per mill for transfers f rom countries outside the West African Monetary Union and one of 2.50 per mill for transfers to such countries.2 Banks levy a commis- sion of 2.50 per mill on transfers to all countries out- side the West African Monetary Union, part of which must be surrendered to the Treasury. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. Administration of Control With the exception of measures relating to gold, Upper Volta's exchange controls do not apply to ( 1) France (and its Overseas Departments and Terri- tories) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account (Benin, Cameroon, the Central African Empire, Chad, the Comoros, the Congo, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Mali, Niger, Senegal, and Togo). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. All other countries, except Upper Volta itself, are considered foreign countries. Exchange control is administered by the External Finance Bureau in the Directorate of the Treasury and of Public Accounts in the Ministry of Finance. The approval authority in respect of exchange control (except for imports and exports of gold, forward exchange cover, and business travel allocations in excess of CFAF 400,000) has been delegated to the BCEAO and, within limits specified in the exchange control regula- tions, to authorized intermediaries. The BCEAO also is authorized to collect, either directly or through banks, financial institutions, the Postal Administration, and notaries public, any information necessary to compile balance of payments statistics. All exchange transac- tions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks, the Postal Administration, or the BCEAO. Import and export licenses are issued by the Directorate of Commerce in the Ministry of Com- merce, Industrial Development, and Mines. Import certificates for liberalized commodities and export 1 The CFA f ranc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and is the common cu r rency in Benin, Ivory Coast, N iger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. 2 Transfers between member countries of the Union are subject to a flat commission of CFAF 100 levied on settlements between agencies of the BCEAO. attestations are made out by the importer or exporter himself and, when settlement takes place with a country outside the former French Franc Area, are visaed by the customs. Prescription of Currency Since Upper Volta is an Operations Account country, settlements with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries are made in CFA francs, French francs, or the currency of any Operations Account country. Current payments to or f rom The Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Liberia, Nigeria, and Sierra Leone are normally made in West African accounting units through the West A f r ican Clearing House. Certain settlements with Ghana are made through special accounts. Certain settlements with the People's Republic of China and the Federal Republic of Germany also are channeled through special accounts. Settlements with all other countries are usu- ally effected either through correspondent banks in France, or the country concerned, in any of the cur- rencies of those countries, or in French francs (or in other currencies of the former French Franc Area) through Foreign Accounts. All settlements with Rhode- sia and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. BCEAO bank- notes may be credited to Foreign Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed to the BCEAO agency in Ouagadougou by an authorized bank's foreign corre- spondent. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresident accounts of BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury is prohibited. Foreign Accounts in Francs may be debited, without prior authorization, with the value of BCEAO banknotes mailed by authorized inter- mediaries to their fore ign correspondents. Imports and Import Payments Imports originating in or proceeding from Rhodesia and South Afr ica are prohibited. Imports from countries in the former French Franc Area may in principle be made freely, although exceptionally special regulations may be issued. Imports shipped from and originating in EEC countries, with minor exceptions, are liberalized and require only an import certificate. Most imports f rom other countries are subject to licensing. Imports f rom non-EEC countries outside the former French Franc Area are admitted in accordance with an annual import program, determined each year by the Direc- torate of Commerce. Under this program, global quotas are established for specified commodities and these 437 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA require import licenses. Imports from Ghana are sub- ject to special regulations. Most imports are subject to a customs stamp tax of 6 per cent and an import surcharge of 6 per cent. All import transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 500,000. Import licenses or import certificates entitle importers to purchase the necessary exchange, but at the earliest eight days before shipment if a documentary credit is opened, or eight days before payment is due if the commodities have already been imported, or at the time of the payment on account, if such a payment has to be made prior to the import. Payments for Invisibles All payments to Rhodesia and South Afr ica are pro- hibited. Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above ), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to exchange control approval, which for many invisibles has been delegated to the authorized banks. Authorized banks and the Postal Administration are empowered to make payments to foreign countries, on behalf of resi- dents, up to CFAF 50,000 a transfer. Payments for invisibles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted. Residents traveling for tourism to countries other than France (as defined above ), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries may purchase exchange equivalent to CFAF 175,000 a person a trip (CFAF 87,500 for chil- dren under ten) for any number of trips a year; any foreign exchange in excess of CFAF 5,000 remaining after re tu rn to Upper Volta must be surrendered. The basic allocation for travel abroad for business purposes is the equivalent of CFAF 20,000 a day, with a maxi- mum of CFAF 400,000 a trip. Resident travelers to foreign countries may take out up to a maximum of CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes of other Operations Account countries. Resident travelers to other countries of the former French Franc Area may take out any amount in BCEAO banknotes, but if proceeding to a country that is not a member of the West Afr ican Monetary Union, they must declare to the customs the amount taken out if it exceeds CFAF 150,000. Nonresident travelers may freely take out foreign banknotes up to the equivalent of CFAF 175,000 or any larger amount, if declared upon entry or acquired by drawing on a Foreign Account in Francs, or an Account in Foreign Currency, or by exchange of foreign travelers checks, etc. They may also take out any foreign means of payment other than banknotes acquired in Upper Volta, by debit to a Foreign Account in Francs, or an Account in Foreign Currency, subject to 438 submission of documentation. Finally, they may take out freely up to CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes of Operations Account countries. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to countries of the former French Franc Area may be made freely but for statistical purposes certain agr icu l tural products require a license from the Directorate of Commerce. Exports to Rhodesia and South A f r ica are prohibited. Exports to all other coun- tries are permitted freely but some require a license. Certain commodities can be exported in special circum- stances only. Exports to Ghana are subject to special regulations. Export proceeds received in currencies other than those of France or another Operations Account country must be surrendered within two months of the date on which the payment falls due (the due date stipulated in the commercial contract, which must not, in principle, be later than 180 days after arrival of the goods at their destination). All export transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 500,000, and the exporter must sign a foreign exchange commitment and submit a customs certification. Most exports are subject to a customs stamp tax of 6 per cent and a statistical duty of 3 per cent. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds f rom transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above), Monaco, and Operations Account countries may be retained. All amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services and all income earned in those countries from foreign assets must be collected and surrendered within two months of the due date. Such proceeds and earnings may not be received in or f rom Rhodesia or South Africa. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coin issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or any bank of issue maintaining an Operations Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coin (except gold coin) of countries outside the former French Franc Area. Resident travelers must declare to the customs any foreign means of payment in excess of CFAF 5,000 that they bring in and must surrender these to an author- ized bank within eight days after return. Capital All capital movements between Upper Volta and Rhodesia and South Africa are prohibited. Capital movements between Upper Volta and France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries are free of exchange control; capital transfers to all other countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over inward direct investment and all outward investment, and over the issuing, adver- tising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Upper Volta. Such operations require prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. Exempt from authorization, however, are operations in connection with ( 1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Upper Volta Govern- ment and (2) shares that are similar to or may be substituted for securities whose issue, offering for sale, or sale in Upper Volta has already been authorized. With the exception of controls over foreign securities, these measures do not apply to France (as defined above), Monaco, member countries of the West African Monetary Union, and the Operations Account countries. Special controls are maintained also over imports and exports of gold, over the soliciting of funds for deposit with foreign private persons and foreign firms and insti- tutions, and over publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate and building operations abroad; these special controls also apply to France, Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. All the special provisions described in this paragraph apply only to transactions and not to the associated payments or collections. All investments abroad by residents of Upper Volta require prior authorization by the Minister of Finance.3 Foreign direct investments in Upper Volta4 must be declared to the Minister of Finance before they are made. The Minister has a period of two months f rom receipt of the declaration dur ing which he may request postponement of the project. The fu ll or partial liquida- tion of either type of investment also requires prior declaration to the Minister. Both the making and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Upper Volta investments abroad or foreign investments in Upper Volta, must be reported to the Minister of Finance and the BCEAO within 20 days following each operation. Direct investments constitute investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, pro- vided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. Since October 30, 1975, fore ign firms operat- ing in Upper Volta are obliged to "Voltaize" their capital within two years, up to at least 51 per cent in vital or priority sectors and up to at least 35 per cent in all others. The sale to residents of Upper Volta of securities of foreign companies operating in Upper Volta 3 Inc lud ing those made th rough fo re ign companies that are directly or ind i rec t ly controlled by persons in Upper Volta and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of companies in Upper Volta. 4 Inc lud ing those made by companies in Upper Volta that are directly or ind i rec t ly under fo re ign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in Upper Volta of foreign companies. UPPER VOLTA requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance, who establishes the sale value. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. The following are, however, exempt from this authorization: (1) loans constituting a direct investment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indicated above; (2) loans taken up by industrial firms to finance trans- actions abroad, by any type of firm to finance imports into or exports from Upper Volta, or by international trading houses previously approved by the Minister of Finance to finance international merchanting trans- actions; (3) loans contracted by authorized banks; (4) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount outstanding of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed CFAF 100 million for any one borrower, provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed the normal market rate and that the proceeds are immediately surrendered by the sale of foreign currency on the exchange market or debited to a Foreign Account in Francs. The repayment of loans not constituting a direct investment requires the special authorization of the Minister if the loan itself was subject to such approval, but is exempt if the loan was exempt from special authorization. Lending abroad is subject only to exchange control authorization by the BCEAO, acting on behalf of the Minister of Finance. The Investment Code provides preferential treatment for foreign investment in Upper Volta. Two preferential categories (A and B) are established, in accordance with which preferential treatment with respect to stable rates of taxes, duties, and other fiscal charges may be accorded to specified enterprises for periods of up to 25 years. The benefits under Category B are more liberal than those under Category A; they are negotiable between the investor and the Government, and the enterprise accorded such benefits must be of exceptional importance to the development of the country. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Upper Volta. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authorization by the External Finance Bureau in the Ministry of Finance. Exempt f rom this requirement are ( 1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufac- tured articles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) imports and exports by travelers of gold objects up to a com- bined weight of 500 grams. Both licensed and exempt imports of gold are subject to customs declaration. Changes during 1978 No significant changes took place. 439 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY (Position on December 31,1978) Exchange Rate System The currency of Uruguay is the Uruguayan New Peso. From March 1972 to October 1978 Uruguay maintained a dual exchange market, consisting of a commercial market for trade and certain debt transactions that were effected at a rate set by the authorities, and a financial market for other transactions in which the rate fluctuated freely. The two exchange markets were unified de facto on Octpber 17, 1978 when the Central Bank announced that it stood ready to buy and sell any amount of exchange at rates to be adjusted in variable amounts at f requent intervals.1 With effect from December 28, 1978 a forward exchange market was established. Buy- ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, on December 29, 1978, were NUr$7.036 and NUr$7.054, respectively, per US$1. Rates for other currencies are based on U.S. dollar rates in exchange markets abroad. Additional effective exchange rates may arise f rom (1) the application of exchange taxes on proceeds of a few traditional exports; (2) a 40 per cent tax on profit remittances exceeding 20 per cent per annum of invested capital for enterprises registered under the Uruguayan Foreign Investment Law (at present this provision is inoperative because enterprises may make profit remittances f r e e l y ); and ( 3) export subsidization through the exchange system. The proceeds f rom exports must be surrendered to the Central Bank. There are no limits on the amount of foreign exchange that the Central Bank may sell to or buy from the Bank of the Republic, commercial banks,- and banking houses. Administration of Control Exchange transactions are carried out through author- ized banks, banking houses, and the Bank of the Republic. Any person or firm may conduct exchange transactions in the market. The Central Bank collects the m in imum import surcharge and export taxes, and the Bank of the Republic collects other import surcharges and consular charges and accepts export and import registrations. Exchange houses must be authorized by the Central Bank. Prescription of Currency Payments between Uruguay and the countries with which Uruguay has concluded reciprocal credit agree- ments may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the central banks, within the f ramewo rk of the multilateral clearing system of the Latin Ameri- can Free Trade Association (LAFTA); these countries 1 In la te October 1978, the Central Bank, for the first time, indi- ca ted the ra te of deprec ia t ion for the fo l low ing th ree mon ths; in December 1978 the Central Bank announced directly the daily exchange rates th rough March 1979. 440 are Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Mexico, Paraguay, Peru, and Venezuela. There are separate arrangements for trade in specified goods with Argentina and Brazil. Settlements with other countries are made in U.S. dollars or other convertible currencies. Most transactions in the manual market take place in U.S. dollars, Argentine pesos, or Brazilian cruzeiros. Imports and Import Payments All imports are subject to registration prior to the placing of orders abroad. The registrations are generally valid for 180 days, within which period goods must be cleared through customs. An import declaration must be submitted to the Bank of the Republic before the goods are shipped. Imports of fully assembled auto- mobiles are temporarily prohibited. Most imports are subject to import surcharges. Goods are classified into eight categories, and are subject to surcharges of 10, 30, 40, 55, 65, 90, 110, or 150 per cent, payable at the time of registration. Full or partial exemption from these surcharges is granted for imports f rom LAFTA countries, for imports made under the credit agreements signed by the Central Bank of Uruguay and the central banks of Argentina and Brazil, for imports of agricultural inputs, for imports by the public sector, and for imports under the temporary admission scheme. Most imports are subject to a customs tariff (impuesto aduanero unico—IMADUNI) and a service charge (tasa de movilizacion de bultos—TMB). Most goods are charged a tariff rate of 20 per cent; certain goods are charged tariff rates of 25 per cent or multiples of 25 per cent up to 150 per cent. The service charge is 2 per cent of the c.i.f. import price for most imports. There are exemptions to the IMADUNI and the TMB, and also differing (lower) tariff rates for certain prod- ucts. All imports are subject to consular charges payable in new pesos and calculated on the f.o.b. value. These charges are 7.5 per cent for private sector imports of petroleum and petroleum products, alcohol, and tetra- ethyl lead; 0.25 per cent for imports of the same com- modities by the state oil, alcohol, and cement enterprise (AN CA P ); 0.5 per cent for other imports by ANCAP; and 4 per cent for all other private sector imports. Import duties and surcharges are in most cases calcu- lated either on an officially assessed price (aforo), which usually is expressed in U.S. dollars a kilogram, or on the actual c.i.f. value. In a few cases, the calculation is based on an assumed c.i.f. price. Purchases with an exchange rate guarantee require a peso deposit at the time of application; the exchange is provided on the due date and the applicable exchange rate is that on the date of application for the guarantee. The facility is available for imports by the private sector, except imports of capital goods. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Payments for Invisibles Profit remittances exceeding 20 per cent of the invested capital for enterprises registered under the Uruguayan Foreign Investment Law are, in principle, subject to a tax of 40 per cent. There are no limitations on the export of foreign or domestic banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds The proceeds of a few traditional exports are subject to taxes, which are withheld by the Central Bank on the basis of either the f.o.b. value or in pesos per un it of export commodity, but legally, the tax may not be more than 50 per cent or less than 0.01 per cent of the peso proceeds of the export. However, in practice, the m in imum rate is applied only to the few remaining taxed products. The exchange proceeds of all exports must be surrendered in fu ll to the Central Bank upon receipt. At the end of 1978 the prescribed maximum surrender periods were 6 months for trad i t ional exports and 14 months for non trad i t ional exports. Surrender periods are counted f rom the date on which the ship- ment authorization lapses (normally 10 days) when no advance surrender is made or from the date of the advance surrender. There are two advance surrender schemes. Under the adelanto scheme, the exporter receives 60 per cent of the peso counterpart at the current exchange rate and the other 40 per cent on the date of receipt of the exchange. An adjustment is then made in respect of the earlier transaction to compensate the exporter for any exchange rate devaluation between the advance sur- render and final surrender dates. The exporter is required to pay a commission equal to 30 per cent of the rate of interest determined monthly by the Central Bank as representative of current deposit rates. Under the preventa de divisas scheme, the exporter receives the full peso counterpart at the current rate of exchange. This is a spot operation and there is no fu ture adjust- ment. Export subsidies are granted in the form of tax credit certificates of up to 29 per cent of the f.o.b. value for most products. Higher benefits are granted to certain textile exports. Exports of cattle on the hoof (except when specially authorized) and specified minerals (including iron, copper, zinc, aluminum, and nickel) are prohibited. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no surrender requirements on the proceeds from invisibles and there are no limitations on the import of foreign or domestic banknotes. Capital Inward and outward private capital transfers by either residents or nonresidents may be made freely, with the exception of certain inward and outward tranfers relat- ing to investments registered under the Foreign Invest- ment Law. The amortization or liquidation proceeds of foreign capital registered under this law cannot normally URUGUAY be transferred abroad until three years after the date on which the investment was approved. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Uruguay or abroad, provided that the trans- actions are registered. Gold may be exported only if accompanied by evidence of prior importation. Changes during 1978 Dur ing 1978 the buying and selling rates continued to be adjusted at frequent irregular intervals. Over the year the buy ing and selling rates were depreciated from NUr$5.40 and NUr$5 .41, respectively, per US$1 on Janua ry 1, 1978 to NUr$7.036 and NUr$7.054, respec- tively, per US$1 on December 31, 1978, resulting in a cumu la t ive depreciation of 30.3 per cent in terms of new pesos per U.S. dollar. The taxes (detracciones) on exports of sheepskins and cowhides, stated in terms of new pesos per kilogram of export, were increased periodically, rising roughly in line with the rate of devaluation.
