The same require- ment also applied to payments for invisibles, except for foreign travel or medical expenses (Letter No. 957). July 21. A simplified procedure was introduced for the processing of imports under the emergency assistance pledged at the June 1978 Brussels conference (Letter No. 1200 /- /BZ /KZ /MMA /- /006830). July 31. The exchange control regime was amended with the issuance of Circular No. 156, as follows: ( 1) The export regime.—With immediate effect, all exports, except those by GECAM INES, had to be effected against confirmed letters of credit. From August 15, 1978, the authorized banks had to surrender 30 per cent of their proceeds from exports of merchandise to the Bank of Zaire; the special surrender requirements of 11 per cent for coffee export proceeds and of 10 per cent for certain other export proceeds (see entry for April 21, above) ceased to apply. (2) The import and invisibles payment regime.—Each bank was required to employ the retained portion of its export proceeds (70 per cent) in the following manner: 33 per cent for essential imports, as listed in Circular No. 156; 35 per cent for raw materials, spare parts, chemicals, transportation vehicles, and intermediate goods for local industry; 2 per cent for energy-related imports; 5 per cent for nonpriority imports; and 25 per cent for essential pay- ments for invisibles, such as expatriate salaries, travel expenses, and other service payments with prior approval f rom the Bank of Zai're. Thus, all import letters of credit would henceforth be covered in foreign exchange with the authorized banks' correspondents through the banks' net foreign assets position and their current export proceeds. (3) Centralization of arrears.—All ou ts tand ing letters of credit which were not covered in foreign exchange at the time the new regulations were issued were to be transferred to the Bank of Zai're as and when they fell due. Also, all documentary commer- cial arrears accumulated between March 1, 1977 and August 15, 1978, and arrears on invisibles authorized under the applicable exchange control regulations, were to be covered in local currency and transferred to the Bank of Zaire by August 30, 1978. (4) Liquidation of centralized arrears.—The Bank of Zaire adopted a monthly program to liquidate the centralized arrears by 459 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAIRE according priority to particular sectors, and by chrono- logical order. (5) Decentralization.—The Bank of Zaire declared its intention to delegate the power of approval for export licenses to its branches. At the same time, authorized banks' branches could henceforth directly register import declarations (in lieu of applying for licenses) in the case of priority imports (as listed in Circular No. 156), raw materials, spare parts, and other intermediate goods for local industry, except where local production or financing through official credits was available. (6) Receipts from transactions in invisibles.—Banks could retain all such receipts and use them for nonpriority imports. (7) The New Guarantee of the Bank of Zaire was abolished. July 31. The Bank of Zaire requested the authorized banks to surrender the 2 per cent of their retained export proceeds that were earmarked for energy-related imports, thus raising the Bank of Zaire's share of export proceeds to 31.4 per cent. August 12. Letter No. 1185 introduced various modi- fications to Circular No. 156. The effective date for implementing the provisions of Circular No. 156 was postponed from August 15, 1978 to September 1, 1978 and the deadline for the centralization of arrears was extended from August 30, 1978 to September 30, 1978. As part of the new surrender arrangements, the author- ized banks would be required to deposit 20 per cent of their export proceeds with the National Bank of Belgium and 10 per cent with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The Bank of Zaire was prepared to allow author- ized banks to have recourse to suppliers' credits and lines of credit with foreign correspondents provided that such recourse was guaranteed by fu ture export earnings. The Bank of Zaire promised priority settlement of arrears on transactions covered by the New Guarantee of the Bank of Zaire. August 15. The special exchange rate for the export of diamonds purchased from small-scale producers was devalued again by 18.9 per cent from Z 2.92 per US$1 to Z3 .60 per US$1. September 21. Circular No. 158 tightened the pro- cedures for imports without foreign exchange purchase (sans achat de devises—SAD). Henceforth, applica- tions that implied the repayment of a loan and applica- tions for the import of priority items for resale and of luxury items would no longer qualify for the SAD pro- cedure. Raw materials, intermediate goods, and equip- ment for local industry, as well as foodstuffs for factory canteens and nonprohibited items for personal use, remained eligible for the SAD procedure provided that their external source of financing did not give rise to repayment obligations. In addition, items with an f.o.b. value up to Z 500 which were not destined for resale could be brought into the country by travelers as SAD imports. Importers availing themselves of the SAD facility were exempt from the tax payment certification requirement. 460 September 22. Further clarifications with respect to the new exchange regime introduced by Circular No. 156 were issued in the Bank of Zaire's Letter No. 9846, as follows: (1) The export regime.—It was reaffirmed that exports by SODIMIZ were also subject to the letter of credit requirement. Surrender of 30 per cent of all export proceeds had to be effected within 24 hours of receiving advice from correspondents. (2) The import regime.— The requirement of a 6 per cent rebate for imports pay- able at the time of shipment was not affected by Circular No. 156. The requirement that priority imports of spare parts and raw materials must be imported by end-users also remained in force. Imports financed by aid would only require advance approval from the Bank of Zaire if such items were also produced locally and if eventual pay- ment had to be made with official exchange. (3) The use of lines of credit and suppliers' credits would be limited to a bank's capacity to cover repayments without entailing new arrears. (4) Centralization of arrears. —Banks were given ten days to report the amounts of confirmed letters of credit outstanding on September 1,1978 as well as of for- eign exchange receipts expected after September 1, 1978 on the basis of export licenses validated before that date. September 25. Letter No. 1342 instructed the author- ized banks to transfer to the Bank of Zaire by Septem- ber 30, 1978 all letters of credit issued with the New Guarantee of the Bank of Zaire, as well as all arrears on salary, pension, and insurance transfers. October 25. Letter No. 9924 clarified the imple- mentation of Circular No. 156 by announcing that the maturity of letters of credit may not exceed the validity period of the export license, since repatriation must occur within the validity period. All spare parts were to be considered priority items; thus, commercial importers and end-users were eligible to import them. Irrespective of the mode of financing, imports of goods that were also produced domestically would require prior approval from the Bank of Zaire. This require- ment could be waived only for certain imports financed by official aid. Banks were not permitted to use for arrears payments the 5 per cent of their retained export earnings that were earmarked for nonpriority imports. November 1. The zaire was devalued by 10 per cent f rom Z 1 = SDR 1 to Z 1 = SDR 0.9. November 7. The zaire was devalued again by 10 per cent from Z 1 = SDR 0.9 to Z 1 = SDR 0.81. November 16. The Bank of Zaire announced that MIBA could retain 20 per cent of export proceeds in a foreign account. At the same time, MIBA was authorized to maintain in another foreign account the proceeds of loans obtained to import spare parts and equipment (Letter No. 1499). November 27. The zaire was devalued further by 6 per cent from Z 1 = SDR 0.81 to Z 1 = SDR 0.7614. December 1. The ban on the import of beer and mineral water was lifted (Order No. 34/0176 of Novem- ber 21, 1978). ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA (Position on December 31,1978) Exchange Rate System The currency of Zambia is the Zambian Kwacha. Since July 9, 1976 the middle rate for the kwacha has been maintained in terms of the SDR, and since March 17, 1978 the rate has been fixed at K 1 = SDR 0.976311. The U.S. dollar is the intervention currency, and the rates of the Bank of Zambia for the U.S. dollar are based on the daily calculation of the U.S. dollar-SDR rate. The Bank of Zambia deals with the Government and with authorized banks in U.S. dollars and sterling. Authorized banks are free to deal in other currencies at rates based on daily rates provided by the Bank of Zambia or on the basis of cross rates with the U.S. dollar prevailing in international foreign exchange markets. In its dealings with the commercial banks the Bank of Zambia applies a margin of 0.25 per cent for purchases of foreign exchange and 0.50 per cent for sales. Author- ized banks are permitted to charge an additional 1 per cent on either side for sales and purchases of U.S. dollars and 1.50 per cent for sales and purchases of other currencies when quoting their rates to customers. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Zambia under powers delegated to it by the Minister of Finance. Much of the authority for approving normal current payments is in tu rn delegated to commercial banks authorized to deal in foreign exchange. The con- trol of trade is the responsibility of the Ministry of Commerce, which also issues import and export licenses. Overall import policy is determined by a committee on which the Ministry of Commerce, the Ministry of Finance, and the Bank of Zambia are represented. Prescription of Currency Authorized payments, including payments for imports, by residents of Zambia to residents of countries other than Rhodesia may be made in Zambian currency to the credit of an External Account, or in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. Payments f rom residents of countries other than Rhodesia may be received in sterling or in Zambian currency from an External Account, or in any foreign currency freely exchangeable for U.S. dollars or sterling. Special regu- lations apply to settlements with Rhodesia. All per- mitted payments to residents of Rhodesia must be made in Rhodesian currency, in Zambian currency to an External Account earmarked Rhodesia, in sterling to a Rhodesian Account in the United Kingdom, in U.S. dollars, or in Canadian dollars. Proceeds f rom exports to Rhodesia must be received in U.S. or Canadian dollars. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Zambian currency held with authorized banks by residents of countries other than Rhodesia are designated External Accounts.1 These accounts may be credited with authorized payments from resi- dents of Zambia, with transfers f rom other External Accounts, and with the proceeds f rom sales of any foreign currency except Rhodesian currency by non- residents to authorized banks. They may be debited for payments for any purpose to residents of Zambia, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for purchases of any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency f rom authorized banks. Blocked Accounts in Zambian currency held with authorized banks by residents of any country other than Zambia are credited with nontransferable capital sums in Zambian currency. All debits and credits to such accounts require the prior approval of the exchange control authorities, except that the accounts of emigrants may be debited each year for the permitted anniversary allowance for remittances to the country of residence of the account holder. Normally, approval is given for the investment of balances on Blocked Accounts in Zambian securities, provided that these are held in Zambia to the order of an authorized dealer. The interest on Blocked Account balances is freely transferable to the account holder's country of residence, except interest due to a resident of Rhodesia, which also is blocked. Imports and Import Payments Virtually all imports from Rhodesia are prohibited, as is the import from all countries of certain specified commodities for reasons of health, safety, or public policy. Personal and household effects, samples, diplo- matic shipments, and means of transportation entering Zambia temporarily do not require individual import licenses, nor do any other goods for personal use and consumption, provided that the person importing them does not import more than K 50 worth of such goods in any period of 90 days. The two major mining companies and the Ministry of Health are granted priority for bona fide requirements. The Controller of Customs is authorized to admit emergency goods imported without prior reference to the Ministry of Commerce. All other imports require individual import licenses. Import licensing aims at containing imports within a half-yearly exchange allocation established by the Minis- try of Commerce in consultation with the Ministry of Finance and the Bank of Zambia. All imports under 1 Authorized banks are requ ired to obtain prior permission of the exchange control au thor i t ies before designating any new External Account except where the account is to be opened for a tem- porary visitor. 461 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA individual licensing are first divided into three-digit groups following the Standard International Trade Clas- sification system (SITC) and fu r ther subdivided into end-use groupings. Exchange allocations are specified for each of these categories. Normally, raw materials, intermediate goods for fur ther processing in Zambia, Pharmaceuticals, and fuel and electricity are licensed liberally; alcoholic beverages, tobacco, durable consumer goods, and other consumer goods are licensed restric- tively. No licenses are being issued for specified luxury consumer goods or for items that are produced locally. In principle, foreign exchange for import payments is automatically made available once an import license has been obtained, subject to presentation of the relevant documents to an authorized bank. Imports f rom South Africa are permissible provided that the importer has obtained a special endorsement on the import license from the Ministry of Commerce. Imports f rom Rhodesia are not normally permitted unless no alternative source of supply is available. Most imported goods are subject to a sales tax of 25 per cent, calculated at 120 per cent of the customs value plus the applicable import duty. Certain import payments are in arrears. The arrears have been cen- tralized and the Bank of Zambia is in the process of settling them in accordance with certain priorities. Payments for Invisibles Exchange to pay for invisibles related to imports, and also, up to certain limits, for other purposes, such as business travel, is provided by the commercial banks without prior reference to the exchange control authori- ties. Transfers to Rhodesia are prohibited except in respect of pensions due to residents in that country and school fees of children whose parents are resident in Zambia. Authorized dealers are not permitted to make foreign exchange available for travel to Rhodesia. For other countries, the basic exchange allowance for busi- ness travel is K 55 a day for up to 15 days a person a calendar year; exchange is provided, subject to certain limits, for other purposes such as education and medical treatment. Applications for amounts exceeding these limits may be granted by the exchange control authori- ties if they are satisfied that exceptional treatment is justified. There is a tourist travel allowance of K 300 an adult for each calendar year. Applications for remittance abroad of part or all of payments for advertising, management, accounting, administrative, engineering, and consulting services rendered to residents by nonresidents are subject to individual approval by the Bank of Zambia, which gen- erally grants the required permission, provided that the fees charged are reasonable, that they relate to existing contracts, and that these services cannot be provided domestically.2 Profits and dividends of subsidiaries and 2 Services rendered by a parent company abroad to its branch or wholly owned subsidiary in Zambia are not generally approved. 462 branches of companies whose head offices are situated outside Zambia may be transferred abroad up to 15 per cent of the nonresident share of the equity capital or 50 per cent of net profits accruing to the nonresident owners of incorporated companies, whichever is smaller.3 Expatriate farmers are permitted to remit 12.5 per cent of their after-tax profits. A further 10 per cent may be held to their credit every year for eventual remittance when they leave Zambia. Such remittances are allowed once a year after the end of the accounting year. The remittance of depreciation allowances is not permitted. Foreign nationals employed in Zambia on a contract made after December 4, 1971 are allowed to remit one third of their annual earnings to the country nominated when the contract was registered with the exchange control authorities. Foreign nationals recruited before December 4, 1971, and still employed on a contract entered into prior to that date, are allowed to remit to their country of domicile one half of their annual earn- ings. Foreign nationals availing themselves of these arrangements are not entitled to the regular allowances for travel, education, maintenance, etc.; their leave salary, gratuity, and other terminal benefits are trans- ferable only on completion of the contract period and are subject to a ceiling of K 8,000 on departure and K 5,000 as a subsequent annual allowance. Remittances of up to K 20 a year are normally approved by the exchange control authorities for family maintenance. Travelers leaving Zambia may take out a maximum of K 10 in Zambian currency. Certain current payments are in arrears. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports valued at over K 50 require a license, excepting those covered by an open general license; minerals are exported under general agreements with the mining companies. The export of certain metals is reserved, in principle, for an official agency, the Metal Marketing Corporation. Exports to Rhodesia are pro- hibited. Certain commodities are subject to licensing mainly to ensure domestic supplies of needed goods and of certain strategic materials, such as implements of war, lead in any form, certain minerals, petroleum products, certain rough and uncut precious stones, scrap and old metals, and ju te bags. For most goods, however, export licenses are issued freely. Export proceeds in foreign currency appropriate to the country of destination must be offered for sale to an authorized bank within six months of the date of shipment; the foreign exchange proceeds of copper exports, however, must be credited to a Bank of Zambia account in London upon receipt. 3 An auditor's certificate must be submitted to the effect that the amount to be t rans fe r red represents bona fide realized profits derived from the year's operations after full provision has been made for local taxation. The profit and loss account and balance sheet for the year in respect of which application is being made must also be submitted. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in any currency must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. There is no limitation on the amount of foreign currency notes that may be imported by travelers, except that travelers from Zaire are allowed to import only up to the equivalent of K 20. Travelers arriving in Zambia may bring in a maximum of K 10 in Zambian currency. Capital Inward transfers of capital are not restricted but, with the exception of overseas short-term financing of imports other than certain capital goods, all borrowing outside Zambia requires the approval of the exchange control authorities. Outward transfers of capital are controlled, but nonresidents are normally permitted to repatriate their investments when they have satisfied the authorities that the original investment was made with funds brought into the country from sources outside Zambia. The repatriation must be spread over a period longer than three years. Local borrowing by companies con- trolled either directly or indirectly f rom outside Zambia is restricted to a debt-equity ratio of 1 to 3. However, the Bank of Zambia permits borrowings in excess of this limit for certain priority sectors of the economy, provided that the borrowings secure higher employment opportunities and /or savings of foreign exchange. In general, residents are not permitted to transfer capital abroad and, with certain exceptions, are required to offer for sale to an authorized bank any foreign exchange which accrues to them. As a special measure, however, residents may purchase Zambian securities quoted on recognized stock exchanges abroad, provided that the securities so acquired are registered in the names of specified nominees and that in the event of subsequent disposal of these securities the sales proceeds are repatriated. All income earned f rom these invest- ments must be repatriated. Emigrants are granted exchange as follows: (1) Per- sons 50 years of age and over are allowed K 8,000 on departure, and subsequent annual transfers of K 5,000. (2) Married persons under 50 are allowed K 4,000 on departure, together with K 250 for each child, up to a maximum of K 5,000 for a fam i ly un i t. Thereafter, annual transfers of K 3,000, together with K 250 for each child, up to a max imum of K 4,000 for a family un i t, are permitted. (3) Unmarried persons under 50 are allowed K 2,000 on depa r tu re, and subsequent annual transfers of K 1,500. In addition to their emi- gration allowance, emigrants may remit gratuities, com- pensation payments, and terminal benefits up to a max imum of K 8,000 on depar ture, and up to K 5,000 as annual transfers. In addition, there are special facili- ties for expatriate farmers for the transfer of profits up to certain limits (see section on Payments for Invisibles, above). ZAMBIA Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Zambia for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require exchange control approval as well as import or export licenses issued by the Minister of Commerce; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Gold-bearing slime is exported by copper companies for refining and sale abroad. Foreign exchange for imports of gold may be provided with the permission of the Bank of Zambia. Changes during 1978 January 30. Authorized dealers were required to obtain the prior approval of the exchange control authorities for establishing letters of credit covering import bills of up to 180 days in cases where the aggregate amount of credits and the amount unremitted under all letters of credit established in the past against any overdraft facilities or lines of credit arranged with correspondents abroad exceeded K 10 million. January 31. Authorized dealers were advised that the fac i l i ty enjoyed by foreign nationals employed in Zambia on a contract, to remit one third of their annual earnings, would not be available to a foreign national who could be regarded as resident in Zambia. This restriction was partly modified on February 1 (see be low). January 31. The debt-equity ratio of 1 to 2 laid down by the exchange control authorities for allowing local borrowings by companies controlled directly or indirectly f rom outside Zambia was changed to 1 to 3. The Bank of Zambia, however, would permit borrowings outside this ratio if the company were engaged in agriculture or in manufac tur ing. January 31. Authorized dealers were advised that the Bank of Zambia would consider allowing remittance of liquidation proceeds of companies controlled directly or indirectly f rom outside Zambia only if the payment were to be made over a period of not less than five years. This requirement was partly modified on February 1 (see below). February 1. Authorized dealers were advised that the power delegated to them for allowing remittances of gratuities, leave pay, and terminal benefits to expatriates at the expiry of a contract, was not to be exercised in respect of foreign nationals who had been availing them- selves of resident allowances but not the facility of rem i t t ing one third of contract earnings. February 1. Applications for the transfer of the pro- ceeds of the sales of companies controlled directly or indirectly f rom outside Zambia, to residents of Zambia, would be considered only if the purchase was spread over a period of more than three years. 463 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA February 1. Residents wishing to remit funds in repayment of loans obtained in foreign countries for the purchase of housing or to meet other requirements prior to migration to Zambia were required to meet such obligations out of the income from those assets. If there was no such income, however, the authorities would consider allowing remittances. February 1. It was announced that with immediate effect all goods to be imported into Zambia, except those falling in the exempted categories, would be subjected to preshipment quality and quantity inspections and price comparisons by a government authorized inspec- tion agency. Authorized dealers were permitted to remit payments under letters of credit or otherwise only when an original "clean report of findings" from the inspection agency was produced. February 3. It was announced that the Bank of Zambia would consider proposals for reinvestment of unremitted profits or dividends arising from past foreign investments in the country if the reinvestment were in the agricultural or manufacturing sectors. Such approved reinvestments would qualify for repatriation of income in the same manner as income from existing foreign investments. March 17. The exchange rate for the kwacha was changed to K 1 = SDR 0.976311. The Bank of Zam- bia's revised buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were K 0.82949 and K 0.83573, respectively, per US$1. The Bank of Zambia also announced that it would make allocations of foreign currencies in settlement of out- standing payment obligations relating to imports and certain personal remittances at the previous rate of exchange. April 18. The exchange control authorities decided to consider applications from established residents employed on a contract, for remittance of one third of current earnings subject to forfeiture of the usual resi- dent allowance. April 28. Business travel allowances were raised from K 50 to K 55 a day; the allowance for medical travel was increased from K 25 to K 27.50 a day up to 25 days; and the education allowance was raised from K 3,500 to K 4,000 a year. October 10. The restriction on remittances to South Africa in excess of K 20,000 in payment for imports was lifted. November 22. Commercial banks were advised that foreign currency allocations made to them by the Bank of Zambia for settlement of past import obligations might be used for clearance of both the principal amount of the import bill and also the accrued interest thereon. 464 ©International Monetary Fund.
